summary: Paul Merson reignited his public spat with Andros Townsend after Townsend was brought on in the 83rd minute of Tottenham’s 0‑0 draw with Burnley, tweeting “did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes.” Merson had earlier angered Townsend by writing that if Townsend could make the England squad “it opens it up to anybody.” Townsend hit back on Twitter after scoring England’s equaliser in a 1‑1 friendly draw with Italy, mocking Merson’s critique of his international place. Although Merson later admitted he was wrong—praised the goal and held up his hands—he still couldn’t resist another dig following Townsend’s brief Burnley cameo.

Chelsea have submitted a formal £4 million bid for 22‑year‑old FC Tokyo and Japan international forward Yoshinori Muto, aiming to complete the transfer this summer. If the deal proceeds, Muto would be loaned to Chelsea’s Dutch partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, for next season. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane stresses Chelsea’s interest is unrelated to their recent £200 million, five‑year shirt‑sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre maker Yokohama Rubber. Since signing his first professional contract in 2014, Muto has made 37 J‑League appearances (16 goals), earned 11 caps (one goal) for Japan and been named in the league’s Best XI after scoring 13 times in his debut season. A Keio University economics graduate as of two weeks ago, Muto has scored three goals in four games this campaign but says he has yet to decide whether to accept Chelsea’s offer.

A large-scale Finnish study of over 12,000 healthy two‑year‑olds, published in Pediatrics, found that infants given antibiotics in their first six months—and those with repeated prescriptions before age two—were more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with boys showing the greatest weight—and slight height—increases. The researchers suggest antibiotics may promote weight gain by disrupting gut bacteria that normally consume calories and help regulate appetite. While causation isn’t proven, lead author Dr. Antti Saari warned that early and frequent antibiotic use “was associated with increased body mass in healthy children” and could contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic. Previous studies have also linked infant antibiotic exposure to higher risks of eczema and digestive problems, and growing over‑prescription raises concerns about antibiotic resistance.

A Queen’s Guard at Buckingham Palace slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, knocking his bearskin, dropping his rifle and falling in front of hundreds of tourists. Holidaymaker David Meadwell captured the entire incident on video, prompting gasps as the embarrassed soldier quickly scrambled to his feet. The slip was blamed on metal protectors nailed to his boots. The daily summer ceremony (held every other day in winter) features two detachments under the Captain of The Queen’s Guard—fully operational soldiers, not merely ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the guard’s tumble.

A&E Networks, Lifetime and History will jointly simulcast in 2016 a new, “original” and “contemporary” remake of the 1977 miniseries Roots—Alex Haley’s saga of Kunta Kinte and his descendants, which originally drew over 100 million viewers. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the 1977 version, serves as co‑executive producer alongside Mark Wolper, son of the original’s producer. This adaptation will more closely follow Haley’s novel and enlist African and African‑American history scholars for authenticity. Network executives say the goal is to honor longtime fans and introduce Kinte’s story to a generation shaped by Obama’s presidency, 12 Years a Slave and ongoing racial debates.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 he was pinned to a chair, groped and threatened by several male staff who tried to force him into a sexual orgy. The 27‑year‑old, then working for the Queen Mother’s household, escaped, resigned immediately and says his complaint was met with hostility and ignored. Haunted by the incident, he wrote to the Palace last year amid wider inquiries into historic VIP child‑sex abuse; after two rebuffs his case was finally sent to Scotland Yard. A retired aide has denied involvement. The Palace now says it will “exhaustively and co‑operatively” assist any police investigation; Scotland Yard declines to comment.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video parodying the ’90s Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air theme. Filmed over five takes as they drove around Happy Valley, Oregon, the clip riffs on conceiving in two months, discovering a positive test (“Now we’re three, not a pair”) and ends with a sonogram reveal. Originally made to tell distant loved ones, it’s garnered over 1.7 million YouTube views. Jesse, a great‑great‑grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and Melissa may follow up with a gender‑reveal video. Melissa had earlier captured Jesse’s reaction via a dog‑tag announcement, and a Pennsylvania couple made a similar Fresh Prince–style pregnancy video last year.

At a Beverly Hills Heritage Auctions sale, Vivien Leigh’s costume from the 1939 classic Gone With the Wind—a slate blue‑gray jacket and skirt ensemble now faded to light gray—sold for $137,000. It was one of more than 150 items from James Tumblin’s private collection; Tumblin, formerly Universal Studios’ hair and makeup chief, bought the dress for $20 in the 1960s and amassed over 300,000 Hollywood artifacts. Other top lots included Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit ($55,000) and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The auction marked the film’s 75th anniversary and honored stars like Hattie McDaniel, the first African‑American Oscar winner.

At the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday around 3 p.m., a two‑year‑old boy slipped from his mother’s arms while she dangled him over the cheetah exhibit railing and fell 10–12 feet into the pit. His parents rescued him before firefighters and paramedics arrived; he suffered minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury and remains in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach or harm him. Zoo officials, citing eyewitness reports, say the child was indeed dangled over the railing, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed after the incident.

A bright yellow Gatso speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham—switched off along with some 300 fixed cameras in the West Midlands in March 2013 when their technology became obsolete—has been mysteriously turned to face a private house. Since 2013, speed enforcement in the region has relied on a few mobile units, motorway cameras and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council, now aware of the misaligned, non‑functioning device, will send an engineer and may remove it; it will not be included in their upcoming digital‑technology pilot. The homeowners could not be reached for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six‑time Olympic gold medallist, will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced. Bolt said he’s “fit, healthy and ready to run,” praised last year’s meet atmosphere and Jamaica’s relay tradition, and vowed to “make the country proud.” JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed the world’s fastest man to the squad and promised “sprint magic” in the Bahamas. The full Jamaican team list will be released shortly.

Neymar and team‑mate Dani Alves attended Barcelona’s EuroLeague basketball El Clásico against Real Madrid on Thursday, joined by Neymar’s sister Rafaella, as Barça secured an 85‑80 win. Despite the defeat, Real Madrid remain top of their EuroLeague group on points difference. Earlier, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1‑0 friendly victory over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, surviving several heavy challenges. Before the international break, Luis Enrique’s Barcelona had beaten Real Madrid in the football El Clásico to move four points clear atop La Liga. Neymar and his Barça team‑mates return to league action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they chase a treble.

Italy’s coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants between Friday and Monday, fielding SOS calls Monday from 20 boats. Save the Children says 400 may be missing after survivors reported a 550‑person vessel capsized 80 miles off Libya; the coast guard, however, has found no evidence of such an incident. Migrant crossings to Italy have surged: the International Organization for Migration recorded over 10,000 arrivals in January–March 2015 and about 2,000 rescued in one April weekend in the Sicily Channel. Most migrants hail from West Africa, Somalia and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 have died this year—often due to bad weather, overcrowding and crew abandonment—and last week 978 were rescued in a single day.

Arsène Wenger says only Alexis Sanchez knows why he chose Arsenal over Liverpool, but he’s delighted the £32 million Chilean signed for the Emirates. After Barcelona let him leave, Sanchez was persuaded post‑World Cup to join Wenger’s side, immediately making an impact in England with 19 goals so far. Wenger admits Liverpool’s reported interest may have been used as leverage in Barcelona’s Luis Suárez talks. He praises Sanchez’s quality, work‑rate and game‑changing ability. Ahead of Arsenal’s clash with Liverpool, Wenger downplays any interest in Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers for rebuilding his team after Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, four‑time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt cycling’s prestigious hour record on June 7 at London’s Lee Valley VeloPark. Turning 35 in April, he aims to surpass Australian Rohan Dennis’ current mark of 52.491 km set in February under new UCI rules. Having closed his Team Sky career at Paris‑Roubaix, Wiggins will ride the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on the track. He expects a 6,000‑seat sell‑out—tickets (£49/£39/£29) go on sale April 19—and the bid will be shown live on Sky Sports. Meanwhile, Briton Alex Dowsett will make his own attempt on May 2 in Manchester.

Serena Williams, world No. 1 and two‑time French Open champion, admitted her 4‑6 7‑6(3) 6‑3 Fed Cup play‑off win over Sara Errani was a “big eye‑opener,” saying tough weather and clay unfamiliarity exposed her lack of readiness. Though she improved her head‑to‑head with Errani to 8‑0, Williams and Alison Riske were hammered 6‑0 6‑3 in the doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, costing the US a 3‑2 defeat and relegation to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez urged harder work despite having many top‑100 players, aiming to regain elite status next year.

River Plate have expressed interest in re‑signing 29‑year‑old Colombia striker Radamel Falcao, though admit a deal would be complex. Vice‑president Matias Patanian said, “We dream of Falcao… the doors are open.” Falcao spent eight years at River Plate (2001–09), scoring 34 goals in 90 Primera División appearances. Currently on loan at Manchester United, he has struggled this season with just four Premier League goals, and it’s unclear whether United will buy him or he’ll return to Monaco. Internationally, he’s in strong form, netting three times in two games to equal Colombia’s all‑time record of 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the 19‑year‑old X Factor finalist and pop star, has been named the official face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry‑shampoo campaign—her first-ever brand endorsement. Shot by the MILES agency against a blurred city backdrop, the international campaign showcases Henderson in various hairstyles and outfits and launched with a TV spot featuring her single “Mirror Man.” A regular Batiste user, she expressed excitement about the partnership, which her manager Mark Hargreaves praised as a natural fit between a platinum‑award artist and the UK’s top dry‑shampoo brand.

In Kenosha, Wisconsin, the Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres and his dog, thanking the community for its support after Torres fatally shot 26‑year‑old Aaron Siler on March 14. Torres—now on leave—had confronted Siler, who was wanted on a felony warrant and allegedly armed himself during a vehicle and foot pursuit. Siler’s family and friends, led by family friend Kathy Willie, condemned the billboard as “disrespectful” and called for its removal, saying it felt like a celebration of his death. The association insists the billboard was simply an expression of gratitude, while the state Division of Criminal Investigation continues to probe Siler’s shooting; a previous Torres shooting of a 66‑year‑old man with knives ten days earlier was ruled justified by the district attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed Monday in clashes with militants who crossed into southeastern Iran’s Sistan‑Baluchestan province from Pakistan; Iranian forces killed three of the attackers. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal—active in Pakistan’s Balochistan region, targeting Shiites and opposing Iranian influence—claimed responsibility. Tehran has urged Islamabad to apprehend the survivors, accusing Pakistan of failing to curb such cross‑border attacks. Islamabad condemned the incident as terrorism, says it is investigating on its territory and will prosecute any militants found there.

CNN reports that during a session of Japan’s Diet, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani said the Air Self‑Defense Force has never encountered a UFO of extraterrestrial origin—though it will scramble jets to visually inspect any unidentified flying object, which has so far turned out to be birds or other mundane objects. His remarks came in response to flamboyant Upper House member Antonio Inoki—a former pro wrestler, WWE star, mixed‑discipline pioneer, New Japan Pro Wrestling founder and colorful political figure—who asked whether jets had ever met alien threats or if research into alien visitors is underway; Inoki himself claims to have seen a UFO but isn’t sure aliens exist. This exchange echoes a 2007 debate in which then‑Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the constitutional legality of defending against an invasion from outer space.

A 35‑year‑old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after a porcelain toilet he was standing on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed. He had stood on the rim to avoid sitting on a “possibly unclean” seat, telephoned friends for help when injured, and received dozens of stitches in hospital. He initially admitted to squatting but later told police he was merely sitting—apparently to limit liability. Authorities ruled it an accident and reminded travelers that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15‑year‑old girl discovered a hidden bathroom camera under her sink. Prosecutors say Rebbie secretly filmed the girl undressing and showering over a three‑ to four‑year span—beginning when she was nine—and molested her in her bedroom from ages nine to 13. Investigators recovered 41 videos (34 showing victims showering), some with close‑ups of children’s genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. He admitted filming multiple juveniles but bought the camera specifically to record the now‑15‑year‑old. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy. His preliminary hearing is May 1; bail is set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new series, published as a book roughly titled Daughter and Salaryman, pairs po-faced teenage daughters in casual clothes with their sharply suited fathers captured mid‑air in dynamic—and sometimes comically pained—leaps against various Japanese landmarks. By turning the normally serious “salaryman” into a leaping, hero‑like figure, Aoyama aims to reveal fathers’ playful side, and the quirky portraits have already drawn widespread online interest.

Following Paul Downton’s dismissal as England’s managing director, attention has turned to the start of the county championship as Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially dropped by Downton in 2014, posed for Surrey’s season‑opening photo at The Kia Oval. Sitting thoughtfully at the end of the front row yet joking with photographers and teammates—including Chris Tremlett, Stuart Meaker, Jason Roy and Jade Dernbach—Pietersen looks to force his way back into England’s Test side. Surrey begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19 and face Oxford MCCU on Sunday, as Pietersen bids to return to international cricket ahead of this summer’s Ashes on home soil.

Romanian side Ceahlăul Piatra Neamț, 16th in the table and six points from safety, have sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. The 41‑year‑old former Inter Milan and Parma right‑back, capped 25 times by Brazil, was dismissed on Wednesday, reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, then axed again after Saturday’s 2‑0 loss to mid‑table FC Botoșani. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January as Ceahlăul’s third coach this season, will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinović.

Nabil Dirar, who played alongside Radamel Falcao at Monaco, says the striker must now regret his season‐long loan to Manchester United. Falcao, still struggling to recapture pre–knee injury form, has scored just four goals and United, facing a £46 million fee to buy him, are unlikely to make the move permanent. Dirar adds that, despite not feeling happy in France, Falcao would have benefited from staying at Monaco—where he’d have Champions League football and regular game time—though the Colombian may also have craved a more vibrant atmosphere.

New Zealand police are seeking help to identify a very tall man who robbed the Union Street dairy in east Christchurch at about 12:30 pm last Saturday. Security footage shows him wearing a fluoro‑orange sweatshirt and a distinctive oversized cartoon mask. He threatened the owner’s daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, then fled with the till drawer and up to $1,500 in cash. No weapon was seen. Anyone with information is urged to call Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or contact police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after a 15‑year‑old student reported that in April she kissed him and let him touch her breasts. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. On Monday she was arrested again after a second 15‑year‑old pupil accused her of having sex with him on January 18 and 19 in her car near another Dallas school. She was booked into the Irving County Jail, released on $50,000 bail, and it’s not yet known how she will plead. The school district says it took immediate action and her leave prevents any contact with students or district property.

A tourist in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, captured video of a large American crocodile gliding through the marina with a dead black dog—owned by a local bike­shop proprietor—in its jaws. New Zealander Tim Weston and his wife watched as the croc lingered for hours near the water’s edge, drawing a horrified crowd before disappearing. The clip has been viewed over 500,000 times on Facebook, prompting comments like “horrible” and “I hate crocodiles now.” Such sightings are common in Puerto Vallarta, which sits amid mangrove habitat and a nearby crocodile sanctuary; urbanization has brought these animals, which can grow up to six meters long, into ever-closer contact with people.

Steve Bruce insists Hull can still avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat at Southampton that leaves them just two points above the drop zone with six games to play – including trips to Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Bruce had aimed for ten wins but has managed only six; he believes “eight or nine might be enough” if the squad can stay positive. He attributes Hull’s struggles to long‑term injuries to key players (Diame, Chester just returning; Dawson, Jelavic and Snodgrass largely sidelined) but points to three strong years—promotion, a cup final and last season’s survival—as proof of their resilience. At St Mary’s, James Ward‑Prowse converted a penalty and Graziano Pelle scored late, while manager Ronald Koeman had to reprimand Sadio Mané for attempting to take that spot‑kick, saying he’ll remind the squad that “team rules cannot be broken by anyone.”

Ian Guffick, a 31‑year‑old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, let pupils—and even altered some himself—change their 11‑year‑olds’ SATs answers after the exam session had ended. A local authority investigation, prompted by a tip‑off, confirmed the breach, and the Department for Education annulled the school’s entire 2014 SATs results. Guffick admitted unacceptable professional conduct (though he said he was merely improving legibility), and a misconduct panel deemed his actions dishonest. Acting for Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, Paul Heathcote imposed a minimum two‑year teaching ban; Guffick has 28 days to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, who has managed just 19 Premier League appearances for Manchester United since joining from Aalesunds in 2010 and is now third‑choice behind David de Gea and Víctor Valdés, has found happier times off the pitch. The Danish keeper married Swedish model Misse Beqiri—who has Albanian roots and over 17,000 Instagram followers—after dating since 2012; they wed in a beach ceremony in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Lindegaard often shares snapshots of their life, most recently a relaxed day in Cheshire, even as he faces an uncertain future at Old Trafford following a collapsed January move to FC Midtjylland.

At Sotheby’s auction, 13 glowing blue letters that had topped Yankee Stadium from 1976 until its final 2008 game went unsold despite a $300,000–$600,000 estimate; the only bid—$260,000—came from a Sotheby’s employee. The 10‑foot‑tall letters are owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought them “on a lark” after the stadium closed, attended the sale, and had vowed to fly out to visit any U.S. buyer. Separately, a late‑1960s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling’s and Jordon Ibe’s recent off‑field lapses—Sterling was filmed inhaling nitrous oxide and both were seen using shisha—reminding them of their responsibilities as professionals. He met with them, but will not impose formal discipline and wants to draw a line under the matter. His immediate focus is Sunday’s FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa at Wembley, for which Steven Gerrard returns from a three‑match ban (though Rodgers has yet to confirm his inclusion). Reflecting on past near‑misses in the title race and cup competitions, Rodgers stressed that learning from defeat is integral to eventual success.

Mesut Özil returned to London after helping Germany to a 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia and shared a “Home Sweet Home” photo relaxing with his dog. The £42.5 million signing from Real Madrid in 2013 missed Arsenal’s recent win at Newcastle through illness—rumoured nightclub sightings were denied by Arsène Wenger—but has since hit form, contributing three goals and four assists after his injury lay‑off. Ozil says he “fits perfectly” into English football’s demanding schedule of frequent fixtures and no winter break.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has ruled out replacing coach Luis Enrique, saying the club are “very happy” with him. Enrique, who signed a two‑year deal last summer and is under contract until 2016, has Barcelona six games from the La Liga title and still in contention for three trophies. Bartomeu praised Enrique’s preparation—especially after the Champions League trip to PSG—and his work ahead of Saturday’s 2‑0 win over Valencia, in which Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi scored.

Liverpool vice‑captain Jordan Henderson has agreed a new deal keeping him at Anfield until summer 2020 on improved terms reportedly worth around £100,000 a week. The 24‑year‑old, signed from Sunderland in 2011 for £16 million, has been one of Brendan Rodgers’s most improved players this season, contributing seven goals and 13 assists from midfield. Henderson’s contract negotiations—underway since the season began with 14 months left on his previous deal—make him the third key player to commit long‑term after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is also the leading candidate to succeed Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy this summer. Talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the end of the season, though Liverpool’s chief executive Ian Ayre expects the England forward to remain at the club. Up to ten players could yet leave before the campaign ends.

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea on a three‑year deal last July but has struggled to secure the left‑back spot, says he is “happy at Chelsea” and intends to see out his contract despite Atletico Madrid’s interest in re‑signing him. After featuring for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, he and the rest of Chelsea now turn their attention to the nine remaining, “really difficult” Premier League fixtures, where manager José Mourinho demands full focus and a win‑by‑win mentality.

Nathan Hughes’s original three‑match ban for accidentally striking George North with his knee as he scored for Northampton on March 27 has been overturned on appeal. Although Hughes was sent off and suspended after North was knocked unconscious (his third concussion in two months), the Wasps successfully argued there was no intent or foul play. Intense criticism of the suspension—from teammates James Haskell and Andy Goode and former players Austin Healey and Joe Marler—helped prompt the appeal. An independent panel, citing fresh evidence, ruled the collision was purely accidental, rescinded the red card and cleared Hughes to return immediately. He sat out Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter‑final defeat to Toulon but, absent from the squad for Saturday’s Premiership trip to London Welsh, is now expected back for the April 26 visit of Exeter. Chairman Jeremy Summers stated that, on review, “no act of foul play took place.”

Seattle photographer Tim Durkan captured a deep red sunset over the city, part of an “amber haze” now visible across Oregon, Washington and British Columbia. The coloration comes from smoke carried on Pacific winds from grass‐fire–started wildfires in southeastern Siberia that, fanned by strong April 14 winds, quickly grew out of control, destroyed dozens of villages and were later extinguished. Smoke particles filter out shorter wavelengths (greens, blues, yellows, purples), letting reds and oranges prevail—an effect amplified at sunrise and sunset by the longer atmospheric path. As the smoke clears, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets’ intensity will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her brand‑new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway just over a month after purchase. On April 1, police recovered it thanks to a tip from Mick Sexton—but the thieves had spray‑painted the rims red, added red side accents and orange steering‑wheel highlights. Instead of anger, Schoenig posted on Facebook joking “I want to thank the car thieves for pimping out my vehicle…this b***h is pimpin now!” She’s having the car professionally cleaned to remove cigarette and marijuana odors. To honor Sexton, she’s debuting a “Sexton on Wheels” smoothie—banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream—at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. A friend describes Schoenig as “vibrant and happy” with a great sense of humor.

Manchester City’s star players – including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Touré – each stand to lose £500,000 in bonuses (around £12 million in total) if the team fails to reach the Champions League group stages, an incentive built into their contracts to satisfy Financial Fair Play rules. Under Manuel Pellegrini they have slipped to fourth place after seven defeats this year, including early FA Cup and Champions League exits, and now must secure at least a top‑four finish (top three qualify automatically; fourth enters a play‑off). With six matches remaining, City also face a transfer‑market battle with Manchester United for targets such as Paul Pogba.

Manchester United’s Under‑18s beat Manchester City’s 1‑0 in a “mini‑derby” at Altrincham’s Moss Lane on Saturday, in front of ~1,000 free‑entry spectators. United deployed a first‑team‑style three‑at‑the‑back formation, fielding 13 English players (10 Mancunians). City’s Marcus Wood and United’s Marcus Rashford both squandered early chances before England U17 Callum Gribbin curled home the winner from a free‑kick just before the hour. Cameron Borthwick‑Jackson rattled the bar and post with a long drive, while late City efforts from Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun went wide or struck the woodwork. The victory leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, and showcased several homegrown talents—echoing FA chief Greg Dyke’s call for more senior opportunities for 18–21‑year‑olds.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italy’s Gianluigi Buffon as “a legend of the game” and an inspiration after Buffon won his 147th cap in a 1–1 draw. Hart, who celebrated his own 50th England appearance in that match, said he’s still learning by watching Buffon’s example at age 37. He expressed pride in reaching 50 caps and ambition to continue playing well for club and country to add more.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food‐delivery market by partnering with Postmates to offer online and mobile delivery in 67 U.S. cities. Orders will incur a nine‑percent service charge plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 (varying by distance and demand). Until now Chipotle had declined third‑party delivery offers; Postmates uses independent contractors in an Uber‑style model. The move comes as other chains—Starbucks (Seattle, New York), Taco Bell, McDonald’s (“McDelivery”) and Burger King (via bkdelivers.com)—also roll out delivery tests. Celebrity diners Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have each been spotted at Chipotle locations this month.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8‑year‑old Martin Richard—the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings—have asked the Justice Department not to seek the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 related charges. In a front‑page Boston Globe opinion piece, they describe the loss of their son, their daughter’s severe injuries, and years of ongoing surgeries and grief. They propose that Tsarnaev be sentenced to life in prison without parole and waive all appeals, arguing that pursuing capital punishment would extend their family’s agony. The Richards stress they speak only for themselves and hope ending the death‑penalty pursuit will help their remaining children and the broader community move forward.

A mystery billionaire spent £400 million and three years converting a Boeing 747‑8—normally a 600‑seat airliner—into a one‑of‑a‑kind flying residence. The ultra‑luxury jet holds just its owner and dozens of guests in hotel‑style suites, lounges, a conference room, an onboard restaurant with private chef’s kitchen, a top‑deck “aeroloft” with eight beds, a master bedroom, multiple state rooms and lounges, and an office/guest cabin—all artfully reconfigured in place of standard passenger rows.

SpaceX on Tuesday launched a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station. Dragon, loaded with over 4,300 lb of supplies—including research gear and an “ISSpresso” coffee maker—will dock in about two days. In its first attempt to land the booster on a floating drone ship, the rocket touched down but tipped over and was destroyed (a similar attempt in January also failed). SpaceX will keep trying to recover sea landings before moving to ground landings to slash launch costs through rocket reuse. After about five weeks unpacking, the crew will load Dragon with 3,000 lb of experiments and waste for return and guide it to a Pacific splashdown. This sixth SpaceX ISS mission launched a day late due to weather.

Priscilla Presley, 69, will serve as witness at the inaugural wedding in the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel—part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis—at the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas (formerly the Hilton where Elvis played 830 sold‑out shows). In partnership with NBC’s Today show, she’s launched a contest for one “Elvis‑obsessed” couple to win the “ultimate wedding,” with the winners (to be announced next Monday) marrying there on Thursday, April 23. The prize includes the ceremony witnessed by Priscilla, a reception, a two‑night hotel suite stay, airfares and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who helped design the chapel’s look, insists it “is not a joke” and will feature no impersonators. Couples enter by submitting a video or photos plus an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice‑captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can still overtake Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2–0 win over Newcastle United at Anfield. In that match Henderson and keeper Simon Mignolet each made their 47th appearance this season, equaling the record for top‑five European leagues. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute with a piece of individual skill, and Joe Allen—notching his first Anfield goal—made it 2–0 twenty minutes from time. Henderson said the victory, coming after poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, was vital as City sit four points clear, while Allen admitted Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal turned down but was pleased to contribute after recent setbacks.

Roma ended a four‑month home winless run with a 1-0 Serie A victory over Napoli, crucial for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute by finishing a swift counter‑attack, and veteran goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis produced a string of spectacular saves—denying Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini—to preserve the clean sheet. The win moved second‑place Roma four points clear of city rivals Lazio; their previous home success had been seven games earlier, a 4-2 win over Inter on November 30. Napoli, without a victory in five matches, remained fifth. Security was especially tight—Campania residents barred from tickets and 1,000 police deployed—marking Napoli’s first return to the Olimpico since a fatal shooting last season. Substitute Lorenzo Insigne made his comeback from a knee injury late on.

Doncaster Rovers’ uninspired League One campaign continued with a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium. The uneventful 0-0 stalemate tested fan patience and left the club’s media team to post a comically brief 27‑second YouTube highlights reel—just 14 seconds of action (the kick‑off, a goal kick and the final whistle).

A fishkeeper on YouTube, Roland Giroux, has taught his blood parrot cichlid to enjoy being gently cupped and stroked inside its tank. After removing two tankmates that had been bullying it and hand‑feeding it frozen bloodworms, the cichlid became sociable, returning repeatedly to be massaged and even swimming up his arm or burying its face in his hand. Giroux now spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with and stroking the fish, which shows clear signs of relaxation and frustration if the interaction is skipped. The blood parrot cichlid—a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlids—was first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes has returned to England’s side in Barbados with his trademark aggression intact but under close management. A year ago he famously broke his wrist punching a locker in frustration, and more recently clashed with Marlon Samuels—an incident after which coach Peter Moores pulled him aside, offered guidance and saw him respond positively. England value Stokes’s natural exuberance and fearlessness—qualities that can yield both highs and lows—but insist his intensity must be channeled into runs and wickets. With selection debates over whether to play a second spinner like Adil Rashid, England hope to keep Stokes (and Chris Jordan) in the team as much as possible, nurturing their talents ahead of a summer that rarely requires two spinners.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the 33,000‑seat Cardiff City Stadium has sold out. Both nations top Group B with 11 points (Belgium lead on goal difference), and Wales are in their strongest position to reach a major finals since 1958. A 3‑0 win over Israel – featuring a Gareth Bale free‑kick – has fuelled hopes of one of two automatic qualifying spots and driven overwhelming ticket demand, the Football Association of Wales says. Although there was speculation of moving the match to the 74,500‑capacity Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevented any venue change within 120 days of kickoff, and the squad prefer the more intimate Cardiff City venue.

England U17 coach John Peacock has named a 20‑man squad for next month’s UEFA European U17 Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions—unbeaten in qualifying—are drawn in Group D with Italy (May 7), the Netherlands (May 10) and the Republic of Ireland (May 13). Squad:  
Goalkeepers: Paul Woolston (Newcastle), Will Huffer (Leeds)  
Defenders: Danny Collinge (Stuttgart), Reece Oxford (West Ham), Easah Suliman (Aston Villa), James Yates (Everton), Jay DaSilva (Chelsea), Tayo Edun (Fulham)  
Midfielders: Trent Arnold (Liverpool) and Herbie Kane (Liverpool)—recalled after the Elite Round—Daniel Wright (Sunderland), Tom Davies (Everton), Marcus Edwards (Tottenham), Nathan Holland (Everton), plus first‑timer Chris Willock (Arsenal)  
Forwards: Layton Ndukwu (Leicester), Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal)—also first called up—and Ike Ugbo (Chelsea)

Manchester City are pursuing 14‑year‑old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis—widely regarded as one of the club’s top youth talents and also tracked by Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously turned down Barcelona’s La Masia at age 12 to stay in school. City have held talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock over a compensation package as manager Manuel Pellegrini looks to secure him for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33‑year‑old Mexican transgender escort who worked in London, Paris and Miami, was found strangled and beaten to death on 28 March in a £400,000 flat in Romily Court, Fulham. London Ambulance Service pronounced her dead at the scene after injuries to her head and neck were discovered. A 23‑year‑old man has been arrested in connection with her killing, bailed, and is due to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, is appealing for anyone who saw Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan, who had moved to London from Mexico and described herself online as visiting from Miami in search of “upscale” clients, had recently posted about her love for London and Paris.

Dawn, a bereaved mother who’s suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show after discovering that a family friend and housemate, Jamie, had stolen £207 she and her partner had saved toward a £500 gravestone for their late son, Daniel James. She initially confronted Jamie and his girlfriend, Carol, but only after Kyle’s lie detector test confirmed Jamie’s guilt did he admit—via a Facebook message—to taking the money and shifted blame onto Carol. Jamie, a convicted burglar, was caught in the lie on live television, prompting Dawn to break down in tears and leave the stage. Deeply hurt and feeling betrayed, she lamented losing the funds meant to honor her child and expressed her devastation at the betrayal by someone she considered a close friend.

ISIS on Wednesday freed over 200 Yazidis—most women and children, the rest elderly or ill—whom it had held since overrunning their northern Iraqi towns last summer. Peshmerga commander Rassol Omar said Arab tribal leaders helped secure the release; all were received in Irbil by Kurdish regional authorities. Earlier this year and last, ISIS slaughtered, enslaved and displaced tens of thousands of Yazidis—an ancient, Kurdish-descended religious minority—in Sinjar and surrounding areas, triggering a humanitarian crisis as many fled into the mountains. An international coalition responded with supply airdrops, rescues and U.S.-led airstrikes. About 500,000 Yazidis now live in northern Iraq.

Harry Kane has broken into Tottenham’s first team and Roy Hodgson’s England side this season, notching 20 Premier League goals and earning nominations for both PFA Player and Young Player of the Year. Ahead of Sunday’s awards, Copa90 has released an animated video—“Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?”—that layers still photos to bring his on‑pitch celebrations and key strikes to life, including a long‑range effort against Chelsea, a header versus Arsenal and the goal he scored on his England debut. He’ll compete for the top prize alongside the likes of Eden Hazard and Alexis Sánchez.

Jamie Carragher has publicly backed Brendan Rodgers to remain Liverpool manager despite a third straight trophyless season and the club looking set to finish outside the Premier League’s top four. Speaking after collecting a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, Carragher argued that one game or campaign shouldn’t decide Rodgers’s future, noted that many summer signings have yet to settle, and insisted that the right recruits could deliver both silverware and a Champions League spot next term. Carragher—who has coached in eight deprived Merseyside schools through his 23 Foundation—also reflected on his own Bootle upbringing and his commitment to helping local youngsters realize their potential.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun confiscated by “over‑zealous” security staff at East Midlands Airport after it showed up on the X‑ray, and was frisked before being forced to hand it over so he wouldn’t miss his flight to Lanzarote. His father Phil called the checks “ludicrous,” saying staff seemed to pat down every child and were holding up a busy security line. The family spent Easter in Lanzarote and, on their return, bought James a replacement £6 semi‑automatic soft‑dart gun on eBay. The airport apologized, offered to post the original toy back from Doncaster, and defended the seizure under government rules banning replica or model guns in hand luggage.

A 31‑year‑old man identifying himself only as “Rich,” from Humpty Doo in Australia’s Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed strict requirements—must love pets, be a non‑drinker/non‑smoker, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house and in bed, enjoy the outdoors yet be “a princess when needed,” and be a good cook and handy. He offered accommodation, a company car, phone and laptop, free gym membership and “lots of benefits,” promising to “blow cash” on his partner and consider all reasonable applicants (except ex‑partners). In his self‑description, Rich says he’s 175 cm tall, well endowed, athletic, white, heavily tattooed, brown‑haired/‑eyed, teetotal, drug‑free, loves travel, outdoor sports, fishing and camping, owns property, makes good money, and is independent. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke has proposed raising the minimum number of “home‑grown” players in Premier League squads from eight to 12 and redefining “home‑grown” to those trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than 21. Although the Premier League opposes the changes, five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven‑Göran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—have written to Dyke urging swift adoption, warning that blocking the reforms will leave England trailing other nations and hamper its World Cup hopes. They point out that only 36.8 percent of recent Premier League starters are England‑eligible and argue that, while talents like Barkley, Sterling and Kane are emerging, they lack sufficient first‑team opportunities.

Demelza Poldark, who was barely showing a pregnancy last week, gives birth to her daughter within the first ten minutes of tomorrow night’s episode. Ross Poldark gazes lovingly at his newborn, declaring that Demelza makes him a better man—much to the delight of fans who’ve longed for his affections but must now accept he’s off the market. 

Viewers have pointed out the jarring timeline jump: one episode ends with Demelza’s pregnancy announcement, the next begins with her eight months along and, minutes later, in labor—effectively condensing the entire third trimester into a blink. This mirrors a previous storyline in which Elizabeth’s pregnancy likewise went from announcement to delivery between two episodes. Fans took to Twitter to quip that on Poldark’s timeline, “if you are pregnant…expect to have it in the next ten minutes.”

Leicester boss Nigel Pearson has urged his players to stay focused on their own matches and ignore the shifting form‑tables of their relegation rivals. After back‑to‑back wins—including Jamie Vardy’s injury‑time winner in a 3‑2 victory at West Brom—Leicester, bottom of the Premier League and three points from safety, have given themselves a realistic chance of survival. Pearson warned against over‑optimism and “flipping the emphasis,” stressing that their fate remains in their own hands as they prepare to host Swansea.

A gray whale named Varvara completed a nearly 14,000‑mile migration—from Russia’s Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico—setting the new mammal migration record and surpassing the previous 10,190‑mile humpback whale record. Researchers at Oregon State University, led by Bruce Mate, found that Varvara visited three eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she may belong to that population rather than the critically endangered western group of just 150 individuals. This unexpected overlap calls for closer genetic study to reassess gray whale classification.

Early on [date unspecified], about 1,000–1,640 ft of seabed along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Hokkaido’s east coast was lifted above the water—rising up to 30–50 ft—with a newly exposed strip roughly 100 ft wide. Geologists and local officials attribute the sudden emergence to a coastal landslide triggered when melting snow and ice caused a block of land to drop and pivot the underwater section skyward. Residents reported no sounds or tremors, and authorities say the event is unrelated to recent earthquakes and is not expected to advance further. Marine life such as seaweed and sea urchins remains attached to the raised land.

Dutch full back Gregory van der Wiel has firmly denied reports he’ll leave Paris Saint‑Germain this summer, telling L’Equipe that he “loves the club, the city and my team‑mates,” is “genuinely happy at PSG” and wants to sign a new contract. He acknowledged a recent spat with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea but says he’ll accept Blanc’s selections and is “ready whenever I am called upon.” PSG’s ongoing links to Barcelona’s Dani Alves, however, may yet affect Van der Wiel’s place at the club.

Carlos Tevez (31) has told Juventus he wants to terminate his contract (running until mid‑2016) this summer in order to return to his first club, Boca Juniors. Boca president Daniel Angelici says the deal is almost done once Tevez and Juventus agree to void his current contract. Despite being Serie A’s top scorer (17 goals) and in contention for both the league title and European success, Juventus have accepted his wish to leave and are already seeking replacements. Tevez, who began at Boca’s academy in 1996 and has always planned to finish his career there, would face no negative impact on his Argentina prospects, according to national coach Tata Martino.

Bayern Munich overturned a first‑leg deficit to thrash Porto 6‑1 at the Allianz Arena and reach the Champions League semi‑finals. Goals from Thiago Alcântara, Jérôme Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and a Robert Lewandowski double had Bayern 5‑0 up by half‑time, wiping out Porto’s two‑goal lead from the first leg. In the excitement, manager Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his grey trousers—exposing his underwear—and later quipped he’d need to buy new ones. He also removed his suit blazer as the game drew to a close.

Ten people, including four children, were injured in a three‑vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway 2 km south of Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. A 40‑year‑old man (chest and shoulder injuries) and a five‑year‑old boy (chest pain) were airlifted by the Rescue 500 helicopter to Brisbane’s Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27‑year‑old woman (arm injuries) and a six‑year‑old girl (abdominal pain). Six others—including an infant, two young girls and a man with hand lacerations—were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment; two women escaped unhurt. Fire crews used hydraulic cutters to free a trapped occupant. The highway was closed for several hours with diversions south of Fernvale.

Second‑placed Arsenal host table‑toppers Chelsea at the Emirates on Sunday (4pm), and playmaker Mesut Özil is already counting down the minutes on his brand‑new Apple Watch. The 26‑year‑old, who has four goals in 25 appearances this season, shared an Instagram post comparing the £299–£13,500 device to Michael Knight’s gadget from Knight Rider; it goes on general sale Friday. Arsenal trail Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining but have been buoyed by Jack Wilshere’s return—he was on the bench for their FA Cup semi‑final win over Reading after five months out. Club legend Ray Parlour hailed Wilshere as “the future of the club” but warned that sustained fitness will be crucial to fulfilling his potential.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford. This season he has issued three red cards: City (and Belgium) captain Vincent Kompany—sent off in an international qualifier and now suspended for Wales’s June match—and two Manchester United players (Tyler Blackett vs Leicester, Luke Shaw vs West Ham). Despite past accusations of favouring United, his only Premier League dismissals this term were both against them. Regarded alongside Michael Oliver as one of the league’s leading referees, he will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. United lead City by a point in the battle for second place behind Chelsea, buoyed by five straight league wins, while City have slipped from title contention to chasing a top‑four spot.

Bob Katter, federal MP for Kennedy, has accused the Queensland Government of treating state MP Billy Gordon “like a little black puppet on a string” after Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party following domestic‐violence allegations and the revelation he had withheld his criminal history from Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk. Gordon has since chosen to remain in parliament as an independent, threatening the Government’s razor‑thin majority. 

Katter—himself of Lebanese descent who says he has faced racism—published the remark on his party website, arguing it was unfair to assume Gordon would resign and likening the situation to past federal independents (Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott) who became government “puppets.” His choice of the phrase “black puppet” sparked criticism on social media, prompting Katter to defend it as a deliberate call‑out of racial overtones based on his own experiences as “dark” and from Cloncurry.

Dayna Dobias, a 19‑year‑old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but has defied expectations by creating upbeat dance videos—most recently dancing to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to challenge stereotypes and show that she’s “pretty much just the same as everyone else.” Having faced bullying and stares throughout her life, she hopes her work will inspire others to look beyond disabilities and treat people equally. Despite early warnings she might never walk, Dayna now dances, drives, attends college and has begun giving motivational talks at schools around Chicago.

MLS side Orlando City have made enquiries about signing Manchester United striker Javier “Chicharito” Hernández, viewing the Mexico international as a major commercial draw for their large Latin‑American fanbase under coach Adrian Heath. Despite a frustrating loan at Real Madrid, Hernández—who has one year remaining on his United contract—also attracts interest from eight European clubs (Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter), with United open to an £8 million sale. Separately, United have tabled a revised contract for 19‑year‑old midfielder Andreas Pereira amid reported interest from PSG, Juventus, PSV and Feyenoord.

Early Saturday at 12:15 am, a white Dodge Charger stopped at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles. While the driver and two passengers were fueling, at least three suspects approached, pulled a gun in an attempted carjacking, then doused the vehicle with gasoline and set it ablaze. No one was injured, but the car’s front end was completely destroyed. The driver’s grandmother reported the suspects sprayed gas after the failed carjacking. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is treating the case as arson, using surveillance video in its ongoing investigation; the suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a Lamoni, Iowa, chiropractor, has surrendered his state license after the Iowa Board of Chiropractic found that he traded sexual favors for treatment and conducted exorcisms on patients. In a signed agreement, he admitted these violations, vowed not to seek reinstatement for at least ten years and must prove that the misconduct no longer exists before practicing again. Investigators also noted he advised some patients to stop prescribed medications. Despite this, his three patient reviews on HealthGrades.com awarded him a perfect five‑star satisfaction rating. His former practice address is a residential home in rural Lamoni.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane flying in international airspace over the Baltic Sea was intercepted “unsafe[ly] and unprofessional[ly]” by a Russian SU-27 Flanker, the Pentagon says. U.S. officials accused the Russian pilot of aggressive, high‑speed close maneuvers; Russia’s Defense Ministry, via Sputnik, countered that the RC-135U was approaching its border with its transponder off and that the SU-27 merely circled to record its tail number—a claim U.S. European Command calls false. The Pentagon and State Department will lodge a diplomatic protest. A similar incident occurred last year when a Russian jet came within 100 feet of an RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk. U.S.–Russian aerial encounters are routine in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle, secured in a hard case locked to his truck safe, was stolen overnight on March 27 from his car at the Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama’s Utah visit. Thieves broke the rear passenger window, tied a rope to the case, and used another vehicle’s momentum to rip it free, leaving skid marks, rope fragments, and the broken handle behind. The agent’s backpack, gear bag and some clothing were also taken; his bags and clothes were later found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel—adjacent to Salt Lake City’s airport and FBI office—has no surveillance cameras. The rifle’s serial number is in the NCIC, and the Secret Service was notified, though it won’t say if security was stepped up.

In July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra, 71‑year‑old Luigi Costa allegedly murdered his neighbour Terrence Freebody by stomping on his head, cutting his throat and stabbing him. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen told the jury that Costa showed evidence of dementia and alcohol‑related confusion both before and during the attack—citing fluctuating moods on emergency calls and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet. Mullen concluded that Costa’s brain was compromised to the point that he could not understand his actions or their consequences. The prosecution claimed Costa feigned memory loss, which Mullen rejected. Costa’s mental state is central to his possible acquittal on insanity grounds.

Everton beat Burnley 1-0 at Goodison Park despite a 10th‑minute penalty miss by Ross Barkley, who stepped up instead of designated taker Leighton Baines (15/16 in the Premier League). Manager Roberto Martinez defended the choice, saying he likes having several willing penalty‑takers and that Barkley showed “incredible responsibility,” with Baines fully on board. Barkley’s well‑struck spot‑kick was saved by Tom Heaton, but Kevin Mirallas’s 29th‑minute goal secured the win. The incident evoked a similar episode in January when Mirallas missed another spot‑kick after grabbing the ball from Baines.

Holland America Line reports that two guests were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at 11:30 a.m. Thursday. The cruise line says the deaths appear to be a murder‑suicide. The cabin was secured and authorities, including the FBI, were notified; an FBI spokesman confirmed agents are investigating. The ship departed Tampa on March 29 for a 14‑day Southern Caribbean cruise. Cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, the former Netherlands striker and 2014 World Cup assistant coach under Louis van Gaal, began his tenure as Curaçao’s head coach by guiding the Caribbean side past Montserrat and into the second CONCACAF qualifying round for the 2018 World Cup. Curaçao won the two‑leg tie 4‑3 on aggregate—winning 2‑1 at home in Willemstad and drawing 2‑2 away—thanks in part to a late 87th‑minute goal from substitute Charlton Vicento. Born to a Curaçaoan mother, Kluivert’s team now faces Cuba on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, who won 15 major trophies with River Plate, Real Madrid and a decade at Inter Milan (including the Champions League, five Serie A titles and the Club World Cup), joined Leicester City on a one‑year deal last summer. With the Foxes seven points from safety and eight games remaining—and winless since January—he insists keeping them in the Premier League would feel “like another cup.” Confident despite their league position and an upcoming match against West Ham, he believes they can still avoid relegation. Settled in the East Midlands with his family, he aims to help Leicester secure survival—and possibly extend his stay.

A 23‑year‑old mother of two, “Gemma,” handed her infants to her 52‑year‑old mother, Debbie, at four months old and now faces being barred from seeing them. Debbie intervened after social services threatened to remove the children, citing Gemma’s ongoing binge drinking, partying and use of the legal high Mkat. She also accuses Gemma of stealing – including an iPad from one grandchild – and says her daughter has shown little maternal responsibility since her teens. Having raised the children herself, Debbie plans to forbid any further contact unless Gemma stops her destructive behavior.

Chelsea took a 1-0 lead against Manchester United when Eden Hazard finished off a move that began with John Terry’s strong, from‑behind challenge on Radamel Falcao. Terry’s foul sent Falcao to the ground; Cesc Fàbregas then retrieved the loose ball, fed Oscar, whose back‑heel released Hazard to score. At half‑time Sky Sports pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry and Jamie Redknapp all agreed Terry’s elbow‑assisted challenge should have been penalized: Souness called it a “decent forearm smash,” Henry sympathized with Falcao, and Redknapp judged it a clear foul despite Falcao perhaps needing more strength to stay upright.

On Thursday morning on Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas, Lady Antebellum’s tour bus caught fire after a rear tire blew out. Michael Barnett filmed smoke and flames pouring from the bus’s rear before stopping for safety, only later learning it belonged to the country band. Hillary Scott, her husband, the tour manager and the driver all evacuated safely before the bus burst into flames. The fire destroyed everything in the back lounge except Scott’s Bible. Fellow bandmembers Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not aboard. Scott posted a photo of the charred bus on Instagram, thanking God and those who helped, and Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the ACM Awards in Arlington, Texas on Sunday.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University proposes using orbiting satellites covered in mirrors and semiconductors to harvest sunlight, convert it into laser beams, and beam clean energy back to Earth—boosting solar panels or powering remote and disaster‑hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland succeeded, with further tests planned in Portugal; he warns that control of the satellites must be tightly managed to avoid weaponization. Separately, Tokyo’s Riken institute has outlined fitting the ISS with a low‑power laser and telescope to target sub‑centimetre orbital debris, nudging it into Earth’s atmosphere to burn up. Both systems are far too weak to harm living creatures or be used as weapons, unlike the planet‑blasting lasers of science fiction.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile with a “fanatical obsession” with young girls, has been missing since 6:15 pm last Tuesday after walking out of a private psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, where he was detained under a hospital order. He was admitted last August following his conviction for deliberately touching a three‑year‑old on a bus and for possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. Munden, about 5 ft 8 in, heavy‑set with dark hair (he may have shaved off his beard), is autistic with mild learning difficulties. Hampshire police have launched an urgent manhunt and ask anyone who’s seen him to get in touch.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling sued her for allegedly targeting wealthy older men, including former Clippers owner Donald Sterling. The suit claimed Donald Sterling bought Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover and a $1.8 million duplex, along with smaller items like a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 blender and a $12 lace thong. Stiviano maintained the gifts were legitimate and that she did not exploit Sterling. Shelly Sterling’s lawyer hailed the ruling as a victory for recovering “ill‑begotten gifts” and setting a precedent for injured spouses. Donald Sterling fell from grace when an audio recording captured him making racist remarks about Stiviano posting photos with African‑Americans, including Magic Johnson. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver then banned Sterling for life, fined him $2.5 million and forced the sale of his Clippers stake.

Thierry Henry, speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal’s goalless draw with Chelsea, called on his former club to overhaul their “spine” by signing a top‑class goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder and striker if they genuinely hope to win the Premier League. He held up Chelsea’s summer purchases of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fàbregas and Diego Costa as evidence that high‑calibre recruits win titles. Henry also questioned whether Arsenal could lift the league with Olivier Giroud as their leading forward—despite his 14 Premier League goals—arguing that, while Giroud “does a job,” he is not the calibre of striker needed to secure the title. Arsenal sit third, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand, and Henry insists Arsène Wenger must strengthen the squad to remain competitive.

A young woman has told Sydney’s District Court how years of sexual abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn have left her terrified for future relationships and struggling with depression and suicidal thoughts. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim kept the abuse secret until learning of his arrest, then spoke out despite fearing public exposure. She said she didn’t realize as a child that what happened was wrong or illegal, has been hospitalized for self‑harm since age 14, and feels her right to share her body has been stolen. The hearing is ongoing; those in crisis are urged to call Lifeline on 13 11 14.

Arsenal’s 19‑year‑old midfielder Serge Gnabry, who hasn’t played since a serious knee injury in the Champions League last‑16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March 2014, is closing in on a first‑team return. He has completed back‑to‑back 90‑minute outings for the Under‑21s—most recently a 1‑0 defeat to Reading—and says he’s “feeling better and better,” fully over his injury and looking forward to the next match.

Jacob Phillips, a 23‑year‑old University of Birmingham accountancy graduate from Barry, South Wales, died after falling about 70 ft down a cliff in Penarth when he fled a taxi to avoid paying the fare. After a night out in Cardiff with two friends in December, Phillips and his companions claimed they needed to use an ATM, then split up in the dark. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, pursued Phillips but lost sight of him. The following morning a dog walker found Phillips’s body at the base of the disused Northern Promenade (“The Dardanelles”). At the inquest, Coroner Andrew Barkley recorded an accidental death, concluding Phillips had been disoriented and unaware of the cliff’s sheer drop. At the time he worked for Liam Gallagher’s clothing label Pretty Green and was home in Cowbridge for Christmas.

Last summer HM Passport Office was overwhelmed by 3.6 million applications, creating a backlog of over 500,000 and delaying thousands of holidaymakers’ passports. Although ministers later offered free upgrades for urgent cases, many had already paid the £30 fast‑track fee and still missed trips. Between April and January only 2,191 compensation claims were approved (virtually unchanged from the previous year), totaling £203,066 (average £92.68; largest £5,463). Ministers rejected calls for blanket refunds, warning it would set a precedent. Meanwhile, the Passport Office made a £42.3 million surplus (April–October) and managers received £1.8 million in bonuses in 2013–14 (average £499; top award £3,500). Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz criticised the scant redress given to those left out of pocket.

A semi‑detached three‑bedroom house in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, is going to auction on April 30 with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. Its original features include a mint‑green-and‑black tiled bathroom, wood‑panelled hallway lit by stained‑glass ship motifs, living‑room windows with coats of arms, a retro kitchen complete with 1930s cupboards, oil‑fired central heating, a brick open‑face fire and vintage food tins (Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate & Lyle sugar, Colman’s Mustard) on a high shelf. While the house has been double‑glazed, auctioneers warn the cost of modernising may deter developers, making it ideal for antiques enthusiasts or a family seeking period charm.

Colin Kaepernick began his career as Alex Smith’s backup but took over as the 49ers’ starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith’s concussion. He stayed the starter for the rest of the year and led San Francisco to its first Super Bowl since 1994, where they fell to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there, and later lived in Texas and San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45‑mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, linking the New Jersey Turnpike (I‑95) at exits 16E/17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing direct access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American, Spanish‑language over‑the‑air television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises division.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and around Colchester, Essex. While attending Stanway School he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur; their 1991 debut Leisure garnered mixed reviews, but their self‑titled 2001 album—drawing on alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop—achieved worldwide success. Albarn’s solo debut, Everyday Robots, co‑produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014 and features Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir and samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu—also called Hamar and rendered in Arabic as مقديشو—is Somalia’s capital and largest city, hosting the country’s main national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their 1992 debut EP Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker (born August 14, 1964) is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA Award.

Both titled Shooter, these follow Force Recon veteran and expert marksman Bob Lee Swagger. In the 2007 film (Mark Wahlberg), Swagger is framed for murder by a rogue private‑military unit; in the TV series (Ryan Phillippe), he’s pulled out of exile to thwart a presidential assassination plot.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first‑degree murder and conspiracy in the deaths of seven people—Abigail Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Parent, Sharon Tate, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca—killed by his followers at his direction. He also received first‑degree murder convictions for the killings of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea. After his indictment, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn (b. August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker and political activist. He made his TV debut in Little House on the Prairie (1974), directed by his father Leo Penn, and his film debut in Taps (1981). After early roles—most notably Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982)—he earned critical praise for At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990) and Carlito’s Way (1993). His performance in Dead Man Walking (1995) brought his first Academy Award nomination and the Berlin Film Festival’s Best Actor award. Penn received Oscar nods for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), then won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (1908 – 2001), nicknamed “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer universally regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he spent three decades as an administrator, selector and writer in the game.

L.A. Reid is a music executive who has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is an American drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co‑founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage alongside Tim Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B‑Real and DJ Lord. Separately, “Rage” is also the name of a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.
The Millers was a CBS multi‑camera sitcom that aired 34 episodes over two seasons from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015. CBS cancelled it on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 – September 13, 2006) was an American Democrat who served as Texas State Treasurer and rose to national prominence delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She became the state’s 45th Governor (1991–1995), was its second female governor, noted for her outspoken feminism and memorable one‑liners, and was defeated for re‑election in 1994 by George W. Bush.  
Ann Richards (October 1, 1935 – April 1, 1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6, 1927–October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer and author who published four books—including two novels—between 1984 and 2002.

Simón Bolívar (24 July 1783 – 17 December 1830), nicknamed “El Libertador,” was a Venezuelan military and political leader who led the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Panama from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil’s Triangle, is a loosely defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous ships and aircraft have mysteriously disappeared.

Colin Kaepernick entered the NFL as Alex Smith’s backup but took over as the San Francisco 49ers’ starter midway through 2012 after Smith’s concussion. He led the team to its first Super Bowl since 1994 (a loss to the Baltimore Ravens) and, in his first full season in 2013, guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they fell to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an openly sponsored, nonpersonal audio or visual form of marketing communication used to promote or sell products, services or ideas. Unlike personal selling, its messages aren’t directed at specific individuals. It reaches audiences via mass media—traditional channels (newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor ads, direct mail) and digital outlets (search results, blogs, websites, text messages).
Private Lives began in 1930 as a three‑act comedy of manners by Noël Coward and the following year was made into a 1931 American Pre‑Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira in Chalkidice. At 17 or 18 he joined Plato’s Academy in Athens and stayed until about age 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato’s death, he left Athens and, at Philip II of Macedon’s request, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz (born February 16, 1982) is an American former arms dealer turned musician, inventor and entrepreneur. He created the BeatBuddy guitar‑pedal drum machine and now serves as CEO of the music‑technology firm Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson was the Los Angeles Lakers’ point guard for 13 seasons after being the No. 1 pick in the 1979 NBA Draft.  He won a championship and Finals MVP in his rookie year, added four more titles in the 1980s, then retired for four years before a brief 1996 comeback (32 games) and final retirement.  In 2009 Ebony named him one of America’s most influential Black businessmen; he holds various business interests and was a part‑owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994 by Jack Black (lead vocals, guitar) and Kyle Gass (lead guitar, vocals). They’ve released three albums—Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006) and Rize of the Fenix (2012)—and first rose to fame in 1997 with their eponymous TV series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (19 June 1566–27 March 1625) became King of Scotland in 1567 and, after the 1603 union of crowns, King of England and Ireland. Although Scotland and England remained separate states with their own parliaments, laws and courts, he ruled them in personal union and championed a single parliament for both. He largely realized his goals in Scotland but in England faced the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and repeated clashes with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017 (Big Brother 18) is the upcoming eighteenth UK series of the reality show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley (b. 4 October 1967) is a British actor, broadcaster and voice‑over artist best known for his Geordie‑accented narration of the UK’s Big Brother since 2000. He also provided Channel 4 continuity announcements until July 2011, when he left to continue narrating Big Brother on Channel 5, making him one of Britain’s most recognised voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked German federal state of 18,413 km² and about 4 million inhabitants, making it the country’s tenth‑largest and sixth‑most populous state. It borders Brandenburg, Saxony‑Anhalt, Thuringia and Bavaria, as well as Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships) and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec and Ústí nad Labem Regions). With a history spanning over a millennium in central Europe, Saxony also lends its name to one of Germany’s 13 wine regions—together with Saale‑Unstrut, one of the two northernmost and the only former East German wine areas.
East End Park was a former major league baseball stadium in Cincinnati’s East End neighborhood, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.

Jennifer Lopez launched her music career in 1999 with the album On the 6 and its chart‑topping single “If You Had My Love.” In 2001, she became the first woman to score a number‑one album (J.Lo) and film (The Wedding Planner) in the same week. Working animals are typically domesticated species trained by humans to perform useful tasks. These include assistance roles (guide and service dogs), power tasks (draft horses, logging elephants), and agricultural duties like milking or herding. Although wild animals can sometimes be tamed and trained for novelty or entertainment, they usually lack the reliability and gentle temperament of truly domesticated working animals.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A.—commonly called Juve—is a professional Italian football club from Turin, Piedmont. Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles in the late 1990s and early 2000s, notably in the films Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), and on the TV series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

The Apple II, introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.), was one of the first highly successful mass‑produced 8‑bit home microcomputers. Heavy metal is a rock music genre that emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the UK and the US. In the late 1970s, the new wave of British heavy metal—exemplified by bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon—continued and expanded its style.

The Armenian Genocide, or Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of roughly 1.5 million Armenians—mostly Ottoman citizens in the Empire and its successor, the Republic of Turkey. Ralph Fults (1911–1993) was a Depression‑era outlaw and escape artist who worked with Raymond Hamilton and Bonnie and Clyde as part of the Barrow Gang.
