Miracle at St. Anna follows four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division in World War II’s German‑occupied Italy. After taking refuge in a Tuscan village and forging ties with its residents, their story unfolds as a flashback recounted by the sole survivor in 1980s New York.

Many religious traditions—including Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, some Sufi dervishes, and the monastic communities of Jainism and Buddhism—follow a mendicant, or poverty‑based, way of life. Arizona is a southwestern U.S. state, ranking sixth in area and 14th in population among the 50 states. It became the 48th—and last contiguous—state on February 14, 1912. The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is NASA’s highest award. The Penibaetic System—known in Spanish as Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética—is the southernmost of the three mountain‐range systems comprising the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Muslims hold that the Quran was delivered verbally by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel over about 23 years, from 22 December 609 CE (when Muhammad was 40) until 632 CE, the year he died.

The human brain and spinal cord form the central nervous system. The brain itself comprises three main parts—the cerebrum (its largest region), the brainstem and the cerebellum. Beneath the cerebral cortex lie a range of vital structures, including:

• The diencephalon components: thalamus, epithalamus (with the pineal gland), hypothalamus, pituitary gland and subthalamus  
• Limbic system elements: amygdala and hippocampus  
• The claustrum  
• Basal ganglia nuclei  
• Basal forebrain structures  
• The three circumventricular organs

AMGTV is an American family‑oriented television network offering a diverse mix of programming—including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how‑to series, hunting and fishing shows, children’s programming, and more.

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), nicknamed “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer universally regarded as the greatest batsman ever. Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher (13 October 1925 – 8 April 2013), was a British stateswoman who served as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990 and as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990. Baiae was an ancient coastal resort and mineral‑spring spa on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples. Nearby, the Roman town of Herculaneum (modern Ercolano, Campania) was destroyed by Mount Vesuvius’s pyroclastic flows in AD 79, and its ruins lie alongside those of Pompeii and other sites such as the Palace of Caserta in the Naples area. Morse code encodes text as a series of on‑off tones, lights or clicks that a trained listener or observer can interpret directly, without special equipment. Its symbol lengths are inversely related to their frequency in English, speeding transmission. More resistant to poor signal conditions than voice and still human‑readable without a decoder, it’s commonly used by amateur radio repeaters for identification. In emergencies, its simple “key‑on/key‑off” signaling can be improvised, making it an especially versatile and easy telecommunication method.

On December 12, 2005 at 21:47 UTC, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan in the Hindu Kush. As of 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin enrolled about 840 students, most of whom lived on campus.

Earth’s early atmosphere and oceans were formed by volcanic outgassing but contained almost no oxygen, making them toxic to modern life. As the planet cooled, a solid crust developed and liquid water appeared; plate tectonics has since shaped continents, oceans and their ecosystems. Today, human-driven changes in the biosphere significantly impact the atmosphere (ozone layer, greenhouse gases), soils, and water systems. Water covers 71% of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk—also known by its Danish name Godthåb—is the capital and largest city of both Greenland and the Sermersooq municipality.

“Paris” is an album by Paris Hilton whose production blends elements of reggae, soul and pop rock.

The Freeport Doctrine was set forth by Senator Stephen A. Douglas on August 27, 1858, at the second of the Lincoln–Douglas debates in Freeport, Illinois. Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. Tom Baker is an English actor who, besides on‑screen roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks and television series.

Valencia (Valencian: València) is the capital of the Valencian Community, an autonomous community of Spain. It is the country’s third‑largest city—after Madrid and Barcelona—with about 800,000 inhabitants in the city proper and a metropolitan population of 1.7–2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was played by Kristy Swanson in the film adaptation and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It concluded with its third season: on April 26, 2012, it was announced that this would be the final season, and the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics—drawing on linguistics, computer science and electrical engineering—that enables computers to convert spoken language into text. Its applications include voice user interfaces (e.g. voice dialing, call routing), home‑automation control, audio search, simple data entry, structured‑document preparation, speech‑to‑text in word processors or email, and aircraft “direct voice input.” Recent advances are reflected both in a surge of academic research and in widespread industry adoption of deep‑learning methods by companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek and CDAC.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic‐book store owner who co‑founded and, from its inception in 1970, chaired what became San Diego Comic‑Con International. Originally launched that year as the Golden State Comic Book Convention by Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger and Mike Towry, it was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee as its lead character.

France’s Dubuisson shot a 67 to join overnight leader Van Zyl of South Africa atop at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy also carded his third straight 67, moving to 15 under alongside Kiradech Aphibarnrat after rebounding from early bogeys with an eagle and a birdie. Back from a July ankle‐ligament rupture, McIlroy is hunting his first title since May and tops the Race to Dubai by 271,214 points with three events remaining. England’s Chris Wood (−13) and Richard Bland (−12), tied for second overnight, now sit fifth and seventh.

Sheikh Ali Salman told the BBC that Bahrain’s government must offer “concrete solutions” and include a royal‐family representative for any meaningful national dialogue. He contrasted reformist Crown Prince Salman al‑Khalifa—who secretly agreed a seven‑point plan for a constitutional monarchy before Gulf troops intervened on 14 March 2011—with hardliners around the long‑serving, unelected Prime Minister, who fear concessions will spur further opposition demands. Despite youth disillusionment, Sheikh Salman urged peaceful demonstrations and engagement with reformist royals. He welcomed incoming US Secretary of State John Kerry’s potential for stronger rights pressure, sharply criticized the UK for relying on private diplomacy, and insisted on freeing 13 jailed opposition figures—without whom dialogue, he warned, cannot succeed.

Christopher Hogwood, a pioneering conductor of the early‑music movement, died at his Cambridge home after a months‑long illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow. In 1973 he founded and led the Academy of Ancient Music for about 30 years, producing over 200 period‑instrument recordings—including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle and a landmark 1980 Handel’s Messiah. He studied keyboard at Cambridge and with Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. Early in his career he played with the Academy of Saint Martin‑in‑the‑Fields and co‑founded the Early Music Consort of London, later directing the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society. He taught at Harvard, was honorary professor at Cambridge and professor‑at‑large at Cornell. Colleagues lauded his generosity, scholarship and enduring influence on historically informed performance.

In the year to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims—the lowest 12‑month total since 1976 and half the number seen nine years earlier—with only one case unresolved. Sharp instruments accounted for 51% of killings (29 cases), almost all involving knives, and 31% of accused were reported to be under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the long‑term fall in homicides and urged continued education, enforcement and cross‑sector support to challenge alcohol misuse and “casual” violence, while funding youth diversion and ensuring police and courts have adequate resources. Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned that earlier “record low” figures were later revised upward, noted rising sexual crimes at a 45‑year high, and pointed to a 27% increase in violent offences such as attempted murder and serious assault. (The 2014‑15 homicide count was revised from 59 to 62 after reclassification.)

Bournemouth went down 2-1 at Sunderland—Sunderland’s first Premier League win at home this season—despite taking the lead through Dan Gosling’s first goal in three games. Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty turned the game in Sunderland’s favor, and even after midfielder Steven Pienaar was sent off, the Cherries failed to convert a host of chances. Manager Eddie Howe lamented their finishing, pointed out they’d scored six against Hull just before this run, and stressed the importance of moving on.

Australian PM Tony Abbott defended Australia’s offshore migrant‑processing regime—detaining boat arrivals and resettling them elsewhere—as the only way to “stop the boats” and prevent drownings, a policy the New York Times called “brutal,” “inhumane,” and of “dubious legality.” He described the image of three‑year‑old Alan Kurdi’s death as “very sad” but said halting illegal boats had ended such tragedies in Australia. Separately, Abbott provoked Australian Jewish groups by declaring Islamic State “worse than the Nazis,” a comparison denounced as “injudicious and unfortunate” by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry; he nonetheless stood by his remarks, insisting he was not “ranking evil.”

The US has suspended its participation in bilateral talks with Russia aimed at maintaining a ceasefire in Aleppo, blaming Moscow and the Syrian government for renewed heavy bombardment of civilians and critical infrastructure—including a trauma hospital hit three times in a week—and for blocking humanitarian aid after the truce lapsed two weeks ago. Hundreds have died and some 250,000 people remain trapped in rebel-held eastern Aleppo. State Department spokesman John Kirby said Russia failed to uphold its commitments or rein in the Syrian regime, pursuing instead a military course and even striking a UN aid convoy on 19 September—a claim Russia denies, attributing the incident to ground fire. Russia’s Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova countered that Washington failed to improve humanitarian conditions around Aleppo, neglected to separate jihadists from moderate opposition forces and is now shifting blame. Although US personnel have been withdrawn from preparations for a joint implementation center, both sides say they will continue coordinating counter‑terrorism operations to avoid unintended clashes.

Policy Exchange’s “Ending Expensive Social Tenancies” report—backed by Downing Street—recommends selling off high‑value social homes (those worth above each region’s average) as they become vacant. Key findings and claims:  
• 21.8 % of the UK’s social stock (816,000 of 3.78 million homes) is “expensive,” valued at £159 billion (£70 billion in London).  
• About 3.5 % of stock (28,500 homes) becomes vacant annually, yielding up to £5.5 billion a year in sales and £4.5 billion after debt repayment.  
• The net proceeds could fund 80,000–170,000 new social homes, the largest building programme since the 1970s, and cut the 1.8 million‑strong waiting list by about 500,000.  
• A YouGov poll cited by the report found 73 % public support, including among current social tenants.  

Government spokesmen note councils already have this power and should use it to “invest in more social housing.” Housing Minister Grant Shapps highlights recent reforms—£19.5 billion in funding for up to 170,000 homes and fixed‑term tenancies—to reduce waiting lists.  

Labour and housing groups condemn the proposal as forcing low‑income families out of mixed communities, risking segregation. They argue the government’s broader policies have worsened the housing crisis and advocate funding via a bank bonus tax to deliver 250,000 affordable homes.

Gareth Colfer‑Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea—now the centre of a measles outbreak with 942 reported cases. Although laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, a post‑mortem could not establish it as the primary cause of death. An inquest has been opened and adjourned pending further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people in the area have required hospital treatment. Mr Colfer‑Williams, recently discharged after asthma care, developed a full‑body rash, saw an out‑of‑hours GP on 17 April, and was found dead the next morning. His family, including his vaccinated three‑year‑old daughter, do not know how he contracted measles.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue in Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence against a boy under 16, allegedly committed in 2001. He is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court.

Promotion‑chasing Gateshead (unbeaten in nine) hosted Guiseley (unbeaten in five) in a National League clash that finished 1–1. After 15 minutes a Guiseley throw‑in by James Hurst found Jake Lawlor, who tapped into an empty net. Gateshead threatened before half‑time—Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted denied Wesley York—but it was York who levelled on 62 minutes, curling home after defender Derek Asamoah slipped. Simon Walton (Guiseley) and Gus Mafuta (Gateshead) were booked; Michael Rankine, Luke Hannant, Adam Boyes and Derek Asamoah all came on as substitutes.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of Bristol City FC, plans to replace two stands at its current ground to boost capacity, instead of pursuing a new stadium at Ashton Vale (delayed by a town‑green application). Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced that, after council approval in November, they’ll sign the section 106 agreement imminently, then wait six weeks for any judicial review. If no challenge arises by March, redevelopment will begin in May.

Cuadrilla has suspended its shale‑gas fracking operations in Lancashire after a 1.5‑magnitude tremor—its second in two months—occurring near Poulton‑le‑Fylde. The company will review British Geological Survey (BGS) data before deciding whether to resume. In April, a similar quake (magnitude 2.3) struck about 2 km from the Preese Hall site at a depth of 2 km; BGS analysis attributes both events to rock fracturing caused by pressurized fluid injection, a known effect of fracking and other subsurface engineering. Cuadrilla’s chief executive stressed that operations are on hold while information is shared with authorities and experts, a process expected to take several weeks. Though US experience has sparked environmental concerns—chiefly potential methane leaks into drinking water—Britain’s Commons energy select committee has urged government support for fracking under strict regulation and industry best practice. The BGS continues to monitor seismic activity as a precaution.

Angus Carpenter, a 62‑year‑old Liverpool bagpiper who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was tried on three counts of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. A jury convicted him of one count—finding he gave the impression he was collecting donations for the charity—but acquitted him on the other two. Carpenter maintained he was merely busking and that the banner, approved by the campaign’s chairman, was a tribute to the victims, not a fundraising device. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3–0 at Portman Road. Grant Ward put Ipswich ahead before QPR keeper Alex Smithies miskicked a clearance for Luke Varney’s easy second. Cole Skuse’s long‑range strike was nodded down to Tom Lawrence, who finished calmly for 3–0. Ipswich—winless in seven of ten prior league games—dominated, spurning several further chances, while QPR rarely threatened; sub Sandro hit the post late on. The victory lifted Mick McCarthy’s side to 14th (above QPR in 15th). McCarthy praised Varney’s work rate and took confidence from the win; QPR’s Ian Holloway blamed defensive errors, called for greater mental toughness and conceded the second goal “calamity” ruined their chances.

23‑year‑old Wells scored 373 runs in last season’s T20 Blast at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He praised the club’s positive direction and the coaches’ elite‐performance environment for motivating the players.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, secured their second straight win with a 29‑12 victory over third‑placed Chinnor. Coach Paul Churcher singled out front‑row trio Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams—whose forward pack made over 70 tackles—for leading from the front. With seven of their next eight opponents sitting below them (and one match against league leaders Old Elthamians), Churcher acknowledged the dogged, emotional display wasn’t complete and urged the team to build on it or risk wasting last weekend’s momentum.

Police allege that 28‑year‑old Bangladeshi national Nazrul (aka Nazu) raped a 74‑year‑old nun during a March 14 attack on a Ranaghat convent in which money was stolen and the premises ransacked. Identified on CCTV, he fled to Bangladesh but was arrested at Kolkata railway station after a tip‑off. His arrest is the sixth in the case; police have named eight suspects (five of whom have all fingered Nazrul) and two remain at large. In May, authorities also detained Milon Sarkar as the gang’s alleged leader, though his exact role is unclear. The assault sparked widespread outrage and street protests across India.

An interactive video (with a non‑interactive fallback) features Robert Opie, founder of London’s Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explaining how the arrival of the domestic freezer, washing powder and cheaper imports reshaped UK shopping habits. Its interactive elements also chart shifts in the ownership and ranking of major UK brands. For best results view full‑screen, and see the provided links for further reading on China’s brand holdings, food‑freezing tips, the BBC Good Food survey of the UK’s top 20 consumer brands, and the Museum itself.

Two “cold‑call” scams in mid‑September targeted older women in Scotland: on 15 September a 71‑year‑old in Sandyhills was deceived by someone claiming to work for BT, and seven days later a woman in Stranraer lost money after a caller purporting to be BT technical support gained remote access to her computer. PC Siobhan Pellett warned that these fraudsters easily take substantial sums and urged everyone never to grant remote access or give banking details to unsolicited callers—legitimate banks and businesses never request such information by phone.

Duffy, 37, the Scotland assistant coach and former Leigh, Widnes and Salford player, has signed a one-year deal to lead third‑placed Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions. He’ll coach Featherstone’s final regular‑season game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers, with chairman Mark Campbell praising his “remarkable” work at Swinton. Duffy’s former assistant, Stuart Littler, succeeds him at Swinton.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and the coastguard search-and‑rescue helicopter, was dispatched to Sker Beach (near Kenfig Nature Reserve) to assist a rider found unconscious on wet sand. Suffering head injuries and severe cold, she received on‑scene treatment before being airlifted to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

At the UN’s World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva, delegates from over 160 countries agreed to reserve a radio frequency for a satellite‑based global flight‑tracking system. By allowing satellites to receive aircraft automatic dependent surveillance–broadcast (ADS‑B) signals—now sent only to ground stations or nearby planes—the new allocation will enable real‑time tracking anywhere in the world. The decision was driven by the 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which exposed that roughly 70% of global airspace lacks radar coverage. After debris from MH370 washed up on Reunion Island, Malaysia urged the ITU to find ways to transmit flight data in real time. ITU Secretary‑General Houlin Zhao hailed the move as a swift global response, and the International Civil Aviation Organization has set a November 2016 deadline for new rules requiring position reports at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez went missing at age five in 2002. Now 18, he was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, 53, in Cleveland after an FBI tip on October 30—prompted by problems Julian encountered applying to college. The FBI, Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed his identity and notified his mother. Bobby Hernandez has been arrested in Ohio, charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver’s license in 2012, and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail. At the time of Julian’s disappearance, his father told authorities he was taking him to preschool and then fled—a detail that had long made him a suspect.

On 2 March a fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site kept firefighters on scene for days, disrupted train services and prompted the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend the firm’s waste‑accepting permit. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which had inspected the Asset and Land‑operated facility nine times in the past year and found it “broadly compliant” with fire safety law, had earlier alerted the EA to risks for residents, transport and the environment. The EA will revoke the site’s environmental permit on 7 August (pending appeal), after which the company must cease operations and remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia has introduced two bills in the Duma tied directly to the crisis in Crimea and broader Ukrainian instability. The first would let Russia absorb neighboring territories whose leaders or a local referendum request accession—bypassing the current requirement for a formal interstate treaty—on the grounds that existing law “was drafted for peaceful times” and is too restrictive during a state’s collapse. The second bill creates a fast‑track Russian‑passport procedure for Ukrainians—eliminating the state fee, residency, financial‑support and single‑citizenship requirements, cutting the waiting period from one year to two months, and allowing applications at diplomatic missions before 1 August. Both measures are justified as support for Ukraine’s “fraternal” Russian‑speaking population and echo Russia’s 2008 interventions in Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

McLaren, once one of Formula 1’s most successful teams—with 182 Grand Prix wins (23.18% win rate), 12 drivers’ titles and eight constructors’ crowns—now struggles to qualify in the fourth (or occasionally third) row and score modest points. Their current slump began in 2013 when a flawed chassis combined with Honda engine problems reversed the fortunes of the legendary McLaren–Honda partnership that had delivered a near‑perfect 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost and further successes in 1998–99 with Mika Häkkinen and Mercedes power. McLaren’s history has been cyclical: early titles in 1974 (Emerson Fittipaldi) and 1976 (James Hunt), a decline that prompted Marlboro to install Ron Dennis, whose leadership brought dominance in the mid‑1980s, the Honda era, and the Mercedes era before 2009. High points since include Lewis Hamilton’s 2008 drivers’ title, but scandals—2007 espionage disqualification and 2009 “lie‑gate”—and a dry spell in championships have dented their record. Dennis, back in control after 2013, insists recent car design improvements and upcoming Honda engine upgrades will restore McLaren to title contention, vindicating Fernando Alonso’s 2015 return and preserving both his legacy and the team’s storied reputation.

Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, was shot in the head and chest outside Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool’s Old Swan on 27 January and later died in hospital. Merseyside Police have arrested three Liverpool men (two aged 29 and one 32), who remain in custody. Detectives believe the shooters waited about an hour outside the gym before Baker got into his car. They are searching for a silver VW Polo seen speeding away via Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road, and urge anyone captured on nearby CCTV to come forward with potentially key information.

The author offers five tech‑friendly ways to keep Christmas spiritual online. 1. Everyday Church Online, launched in the UK in September, streams Sunday services with a global chat room “foyer” (61 countries so far) and is running a Star Wars–themed Christmas series of three sermons titled “The Hope Awakens.” 2. Guardians of Ancora, a free Scripture Union fantasy game for 8–11 year‑olds (45,000 players in four months), sends “guardians” on Bible‑story quests—including two new Christmas missions to find Jesus’s birth. 3. Viral nativity videos—most famously German company Viral.de’s 2010 Facebook‑and‑tweet retelling (6 million views) and the Churches Advertising Network’s era‑shifting “Baby’s Giggle” spot (250,000 views)—use social media formats to tell the Christmas story. 4. Next Manga’s “Manga Messiah” app and e‑book brings Bible stories to life in Japanese comic style in 33 languages, with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to refugees. 5. Churches also use Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to share brief spiritual reflections, inviting people to pause and consider deeper truths.

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to convert 250 ha of common land into a circuit, with backers (including Blaenau Gwent council) offering 320 ha of replacement land. Experts disagree on whether building on the common would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales says it’s “difficult to conclude” that the replacement land matches the original’s value but isn’t opposing the project. Developers’ ecology reports claim a net biodiversity gain via nearby habitat enhancements—a view challenged by Gwent Wildlife Trust. After the inquiry, the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and Welsh government ministers will decide.

On 1 April Novaya Gazeta reported that Chechen authorities had detained over 100 men suspected of homosexuality, torturing them with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun and killing at least three. The Russian LGBT Network, which has been in touch with victims, confirmed the account and said it is helping people flee the region; it warned it will take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russian authorities fail to act. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied the allegations, insisting there are no gay people in Chechnya. Two days after the report, on 3 April, a council of Chechen Muslim clerics denounced the paper for insulting their faith and dignity and vowed “retribution” against its instigators—language Novaya Gazeta called a threat against journalists. Mufti Salah‑haji Mezhiev publicly affirmed the promise of punishment. Novaya Gazeta’s editor Dmitry Muratov replied in an open letter defending the investigation and urging dialogue. The paper noted that Chechens have been linked to the unsolved contract killings of its reporters Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova, and of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov.

Investing Solutions, a London letting agent set up in 2002 by Samir Patel, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity Patel founded in 2010 to help current and ex-offenders, have worked together to house single homeless men over 35. Fresh Start refers clients to Investing Solutions, which places multiple tenants in private rooms, bills housing benefit for each person, passes “the bulk” of rent to private landlords, and retains the difference. Operating across seven boroughs, Investing Solutions is one of the UK’s largest housing benefit claimants. For example, on one two-tenant property it claimed £2,114/month while paying the landlord £1,150, netting an annual gross profit of £11,568.

Tenants like Nigel McCann report uninhabitable conditions—rats, damp, no heating or hot water—and criticize the focus on profit over welfare. Nearly half of Investing Solutions’ two‑year, £4.2 million benefit haul came from Wandsworth Council, which says it monitors private-sector housing. Crisis charity calls the partnership “a new low.” Patel insists Fresh Start is independently governed, most rent is passed to landlords, and he is “concerned” about the property-condition claims. Fresh Start says it has housed 788 people since 2010 (222 in the past year) but won’t disclose how many went through Investing Solutions. The Department for Communities and Local Government emphasizes that local authorities must rigorously safeguard public funds in private‑sector housing.

Great Britain lost their final warm‑up ahead of EuroBasket qualifying, falling to the Netherlands after leading for much of the first three quarters. London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA veteran Ben Gordon added 13, including three straight threes in the third quarter that briefly restored GB’s lead. Worthy De Jong led the Dutch with 18 points and they opened the fourth quarter with a 10–0 run to secure victory despite a late GB rally. Coach Joe Prunty, who fielded his strongest line‑up before cutting to six games of qualifiers, praised Gordon’s impact but warned the team must “compete on every play” when qualifiers begin in Hungary midweek.

Conor McGregor filed a waiver with the Nevada Athletic Commission on Wednesday—just before the deadline—requesting permission to fight Floyd Mayweather at 154 lbs with 8 oz gloves. By rule, bouts at 154 lbs must use 10 oz gloves; only contests between 135–147 lbs can drop to 8 oz with approved waivers. Mayweather had already announced via Instagram his plan to wear 8 oz gloves but had not submitted paperwork. NAC executive director Bob Bennett, prioritizing fighter safety, will have commissioners debate the request on 16 August. In approving the bout, Bennett cited McGregor’s UFC sparring credentials—especially performances against Nate Diaz reported by trainer Virgil Hunter—along with his power, chin, age, height and reach. McGregor’s boxing debut, potentially the richest fight ever, will feature Hall of Famer Joe Cortez as referee after a sparring spat prompted Paulie Malignaggi’s exit from McGregor’s camp.

The passage chronicles the end of Fleet Street’s 300‑year reign as Britain’s newspaper heartland, marked by the closure of the Sunday Post’s London office and the redundancy of its last two reporters, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith. Once home to the first British daily (the Daily Courant, 1702) and nicknamed both “the Street of Shame” and “the pinnacle of a journalist’s career,” Fleet Street teemed with typewriters, printing presses, bars and pubs where reporters socialized and chased stories. Smith recalls sharing an address with Sweeney Todd’s fictional barber shop and sneaking into the men‑only El Vino; Sherriff remembers smoke‑filled newsrooms, paper‑laden lorries and a landscape now overrun by sandwich shops. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved key titles to Wapping, triggering a bitter print‑union dispute, and accelerated as papers adopted cheaper, computerized production and dispersed across London. Buildings once occupied by national titles now house supermarkets and restaurant chains. Ex‑editor Robin Esser emphasizes how crucial Fleet Street once was—providing 85% of public information—while Liz Hodgkinson’s reminiscences highlight the rowdy, male‑dominated culture of the 1970s and ’80s. As Smith turns freelance and Sherriff writes memoirs, the passage marks the final deadline on an era that shaped British journalism.

J.K. Rowling said recent messages—both abusive and supportive—remind her how many decent people there are. After donating £1 million to the Scottish “No” campaign (and the same to Labour in 2008), she was branded a “traitor” and blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed were SNP supporters, though she also engaged positively with others. She insisted on calling out bullying rather than protecting any party’s image, joked she’d bring marshmallows when someone suggested burning her books, and noted that the SNP’s victory in 56 of Scotland’s 59 seats makes it the UK’s third‑largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study tracking 4,300 young people since 1998 (the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime) found that poverty and police contact together deepen young people’s involvement in crime and exclusion:

• Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same offence and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than better‑off peers.  
• Household poverty remains a strong predictor of offending and of being not in education, employment or training (NEET) at 18, even after accounting for truancy, substance misuse and poor parental supervision.  
• Extreme poverty raises both victimisation and perpetration risks.  
• Gender matters: boys are three times more likely than girls to commit violence; poorer girls are twice as likely as affluent girls to do so.  

A separate University of Edinburgh report (AQMeN) showed that despite record‑low national crime rates, the most deprived neighbourhoods—often those with chronic health problems and high unemployment—continue to endure the highest levels of crime. The findings suggest that poverty and inequality remain central, mutually reinforcing drivers of youth offending and community harm, a dynamic not fully addressed by recent crime reductions or current government initiatives.

Karl “Karl” Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a Kilkee laneway early Sunday. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August; two other men arrested were released without charge and files are being prepared for the DPP. Det. Sgt. Padraig Frawley told Ennis District Court that shortly after 1 am Walsh and two others entered the Marian Estate searching for Haugh, encountered him and another man, and a fight broke out involving knives and golf clubs. Haugh suffered a stab wound to the back, and despite ambulance transport to Limerick University Hospital, he was pronounced dead at 6 am. Gardaí recovered a bloodied blade and handle at the scene.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA for Fermanagh, tweeted in May 2014 that DUP MP Tom Elliott—who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992—had “harassed and shot” people. Elliott, now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone with a clear MoD record, was alerted to the false claim by victims’ campaigner Ann Travers and DUP MLA Arlene Foster. The High Court heard that Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and ordered him to post a Twitter apology before Friday, admitting the allegation was “untrue and wholly without foundation.” Judgment on compensation has been reserved, and the insurer covering MLAs at Stormont has refused to indemnify Flanagan, a decision he is separately challenging. Elliott said he felt vindicated but was disappointed by the 19‑month delay in resolving the matter.

Hawick Knitwear, founded in 1874 and employing over 230 people, was acquired by managing director Benny Hartop last November. Strong sales of its Hawick‑branded sweater range, launched in January, together with growth in its private‑label business, have pushed weekly production from about 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters. The company exports across Europe (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain) and to the USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan. Hartop credits the surge in home and overseas orders to dedicated staff and expects the firm’s success to continue.

In December, 72‑year‑old Sylvia Blackburn—a mother of three who served as a school crossing patrol (“lollipop lady”) for 20 years—suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston when Brian Wright, 55, failed to stop his VW Golf at a red light and struck her as she escorted a mother and child across the road. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. At Luton Crown Court, Wright admitted hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, insisting he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall the light’s color. He told the court he is “truly sorry” for upending her life. The trial is ongoing.

Nato’s “Dynamic Mongoose” exercise in the North Atlantic pits ten allied warships—including the USS Vicksburg and Britain’s HMS Portland—against the German U‑boat U33, which must evade detection and “sink” high‑value targets using only fleeting periscope sightings. Rear Admiral Brad Williamson emphasizes the need for realistic anti‑submarine training in light of recent Russian submarine patrols near Sweden, Finland and the UK. Surface ships rely on sonar and sensors, airborne helicopters assist, and for the first time Nato has deployed unmanned underwater drones (“Harpo” and “Groucho”) from its research vessel for persistent, lower‑risk surveillance. A French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft provides long‑range coverage—highlighting a glaring gap in Britain’s defenses since retiring its own Nimrod patrol planes. Experts note Russia’s growing submarine fleet of some 60 vessels, including the newly launched “quietest submarine in the world,” poses a sophisticated, hard‑to‑detect threat. The exercise underlines both Nato’s collective readiness and the urgent need for the UK to restore its maritime patrol capability.

United Nations officials warn that genocide or ethnic cleansing may be unfolding in South Sudan after July’s outbreak of violence in Juba spread into Equatoria, forcing 340,000 people—an average of 2,500 a day—to flee across informal crossings into Uganda. Refugees’ accounts describe Dinka fighters targeting Equatorians and Nuers: men and boys killed, women raped, civilians hacked with knives. Uganda has responded by allocating each family a 30 m² plot and shelter within 36 hours, enabling many, like Faida Sarah, to cultivate crops almost immediately. Bidi Bidi has grown from a village into one of the world’s largest camps; Uganda now hosts nearly a million South Sudanese, straining water supplies. The UNHCR urges the international community to pressure South Sudan’s leaders to stop the mass killings. Despite deep trauma, schools operate in the camps and students—exemplified by 16‑year‑old Patricia Mercy’s war‑inspired poem—demonstrate remarkable resilience.

McKenzie, 38, a former Norwich and Peterborough footballer who turned professional in boxing in 2013, will challenge Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super‑middleweight title. In nine fights he’s unbeaten with eight wins and one draw. He is the son of ex‑British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three‑time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition government is funding Bridgwater Community Hospital as part of a £330 million NHS facilities programme, allocating £33 million to replace the cramped 1813 building. The new hospital—financed jointly by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust—will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery‑led maternity unit, a minor injuries unit, X‑ray facilities and space for mobile scanners. Staff describe the current premises as old, uncomfortable and costly to maintain, and say a modern environment would boost patient recovery and morale. In the past five years three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have been rebuilt and work has begun on Taunton’s Jubilee Building. Local GPs and therapists welcome the “one‑stop shop” model of care. Planning permission is being sought for a site on Bowers Lane, with completion targeted for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest shortly before 13:35 GMT outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre, after or while seated in a black Mercedes. Armed officers sealed off the scene and he was taken to Northern General Hospital, where he died. Neighbors said he belonged to a family gathering nearby and relatives rushed out to help after hearing the shot. The shooting adds to a recent spate of gun attacks in Sheffield—including incidents in Shiregreen, Southey Green (a suspected mistaken‑identity shooting of an elderly couple), and two January drive‑by shootings in High Green.

Three distinct “virtual warrior” groups are active in the Ukraine–Russia conflict:

1. Ukrainian Cyber Troops  
- Led by Yevhen Dokukin, they present as independent activists.  
- Hacks claimed: two Russian interior‑ministry servers and a Rostov police email account, yielding 35 GB of data (via volunteer group Inform Napalm) suggesting wounded Russian servicemen evacuated from Ukraine.  
- Tactics: widespread DDoS attacks against rebel websites; targeting rebels’ PayPal/WebMoney accounts; hijacking CCTV in eastern Ukraine to monitor troop movements; hijacking network printers in eastern Ukraine and Crimea to print pro‑Ukrainian slogans.  
- Allegations (denied by officials) that Ukrainian security services have used hacker‑obtained data to direct artillery fire.

2. Cyber Berkut  
- Self‑styled anti‑Western hackers named after former riot police, aiming to disrupt Ukraine’s military “genocide.”  
- Rhetoric mirrors Russian state media: motto “We won’t forgive or forget.”  
- Operations: hacked Ukrainian government sites during Joe Biden’s November visit with anti‑Biden messages; claimed retrieval of Biden‑team documents on U.S. military aid; hacked Kiev billboards to display “war criminal” accusations against Ukrainian officials; allegedly disrupted Ukraine’s electronic vote counting, leaked defence‑ministry casualty data, blocked President Poroshenko’s site; purportedly published an unverified Facebook chat implicating Ukraine in MH17’s downing.

3. Anonymous International (b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay)  
- Russian activists famous for leaking Kremlin documents.  
- Methods uncertain (hacking vs. insider leaks).  
- Focuses mainly on Russian domestic affairs but has released: a letter from a Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine; emails of former FSB colonel and rebel commander Igor Girkin.  
- Their site is blocked in Russia.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became visibly emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond delivered their valedictory speeches ahead of the 5 May election. McNeil, who has served since 1999, urged Holyrood to strengthen its committee system, ensure accountability, scrutiny and necessary opposition, and learn from Westminster’s example. Salmond echoed a theme from his first parliamentary speech, arguing that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse” and that both country and parliament are on a journey toward greater devolution. He welcomed powers transferred under the Scotland Bill but maintained it fell short of referendum-era promises. Mixing solemn reflections with humour—joking about competing with the UK Budget and the Cheltenham races—he closed by calling membership of Holyrood “the greatest honour in public life.” Marwick thanked him for serving Scotland “with distinction.” Also standing down is former Conservative leader Annabel Goldie, who quipped she’ll miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is gathering testimonies from residents, families and carers to inform her review of the quality of life and care in Welsh residential homes. She will assess physical and mental health, social relationships and the care environment, and speak with providers, staff and public bodies to develop recommendations that highlight both good practice and the harms of poor care. Mario Kreft of Care Forum Wales welcomes the review’s aims but criticizes its advisory panel for lacking any representatives with direct care‑home experience.

Harbro Group, based in Turriff, Aberdeenshire, reported a pre‑tax profit of £3.5 million for the year to June 2016—up £800,000—even as turnover slipped by £1 million to just over £100 million. The company’s international sales grew both within Europe and in newer markets. Harbro manufactures feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry producers, and operates 19 “Country Store” shops across Scotland, offering farming supplies, fireside goods, country clothing and footwear. In its accounts, Harbro notes an unpredictable agricultural outlook, acknowledges recent challenges, but affirms the industry’s resilience and the group’s readiness to face the uncertain impacts of Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead on Saturday at a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and urgently want to question 55‑year‑old Ian John McLoughlin (aka Ian John Baker), warning the public not to approach him. He is described as a white male about 6 ft tall, average build, with straight greying collar‑length hair, and believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three‑quarter trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short‑sleeved shirt. Residents have been urged to contact police or Crimestoppers and additional patrols are being carried out in the area.

In a Tuesday address to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington, IMF Deputy Managing Director David Lipton warned that the global economy’s “weakening baseline” puts it at a “delicate juncture.” His comments follow China’s latest trade figures, which showed exports plunged 25% year‑on‑year. The IMF has already signaled it will likely cut its 3.4% global growth forecast when it updates projections in April—an outlook with significant implications for businesses reliant on China’s growth.

Council leader Dave Stewart told a scrutiny meeting that, in light of the chain ferry’s troubled launch, crossings at Cowes will be free until 2 July to gather feedback and recognise the problems. He said the council has commissioned an audit review, calling the service’s start “frustrating and disappointing.” Since its 14 May debut the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and damaged cars. East Cowes shopkeeper Angie Booth warned her business and others have lost nearly six months’ trade and asked about compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is being discussed, emphasised the vessel is a prototype with expected teething problems, and noted that electrical faults have been fixed, ramp extensions authorised to prevent vehicle scraping, and seamanship issues addressed.

At about 07:30 GMT on Thursday, a multi‑vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott killed a 32‑year‑old man at the scene. A 33‑year‑old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening while officers investigated.

Matching Models in London, a “temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” has drawn criticism and possible legal action for job ads specifying physical attributes—e.g. a “classic look, brown long hair with b‑c cup” personal assistant and a “sexy female driver” to chauffeur a Porsche for £40–50K. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned these ads as “appalling, unlawful and demeaning,” and is seeking clarification of the agency’s hiring practices. Campaigners and lawyers argue such criteria breach the 2010 Equality Act by discriminating on age, sex and appearance. Founder Nathalie Jansen insists clients demand specific looks—citing requests for a “Jackie O” fit or a blonde, blue‑eyed Greek—and points to corporate clients like MTV, Louis Vuitton and Harrods. EHRC chief Rebecca Hilsenrath urges the agency to abandon sexist criteria and comply with modern equality law.

A gunman identified as Mahesh, an office assistant at Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, opened fire in a school hostel on Tuesday evening, barging into 18‑year‑old Gautami’s room and shooting her in the head, then wounding another student, Sirisha, who remains in serious but stable condition. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded in custody until 12 April. Motive for the attack is unclear. Such gun crimes in Indian schools are very rare; India has strict gun laws, though firearms are often used in personal feuds. A similar campus shooting in 2007 near Delhi left a 14‑year‑old dead.

GLAAD’s “Where We Are on TV” study of scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series airing or in casting between June 2016 and May 2017 found:

• 278 regular or recurring LGBT characters, with transgender representation rising from 7 to 16.  
• Over 25 lesbian and bisexual women were killed off, including Poussey Washington (Orange is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth).  
• A record‑high proportion of Black characters on broadcast TV, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder.  

GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis called the progress “heartening” but noted that numbers “are only part of the story.”

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not seek re‑election after facing expected deselection at a local party meeting. He is under scrutiny for his role, as former borough council leader, in approving a £10.25 million loan of public funds to Northampton Town FC—money now missing amid a police probe into alleged financial irregularities. The stadium rebuild remains incomplete. Mr Mackintosh denies wrongdoing and says it’s “the right time” for a new representative.

In April in Balch Springs, Texas, officer Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car of teenagers leaving an underage‐drinking party, killing 15‑year‑old Jordan Edwards. Responding officers had entered the house to investigate when Oliver, believing he heard gunshots, shot into the vehicle. Police initially claimed the car reversed “aggressively,” but video showed it was driving away. Oliver was dismissed for policy violations days later and is charged with murder plus four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for the other occupants. He faces 5–99 years if convicted—potentially becoming the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. No trial date is set; he’s free on bail and his lawyer has not commented. District Attorney Faith Johnson said justice is proceeding thoroughly, while family lawyer Lee Merritt cautioned that it’s been over 40 years since a Texas officer was convicted of murder.

Mrs. Trump has announced that she and Barron will remain in New York until his school year ends, without specifying a move‑in date for the White House. Social media users criticized her choice, arguing the First Family should live at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, but others praised her focus on Barron’s education—echoing her campaign‑season choice to stay in Trump Tower for his sake.  

Historians note only two earlier First Ladies—Martha Washington (before the White House was built) and Anna Harrison (whose husband died before moving in)—never lived there. Other examples of children staying away to finish school include President John Tyler’s family and Dolley Madison’s son. In recent history, Chelsea Clinton and the Obamas’ daughters lived in Washington from inauguration day, though the Obamas moved in early to avoid mid‑term school changes.  

The official role of First Lady is a ceremonial hostess, but modern incumbents have championed causes—Lou Henry Hoover began the public role, Eleanor Roosevelt expanded it, Nancy Reagan focused privately before her anti‑drug campaign, and Michelle Obama led educational initiatives. Mrs. Trump has signaled cyber‑bullying as her interest. If needed, aides or family—such as Ivanka Trump, who acted as “proxy wife” during the campaign—could assume duties. Previous presidents’ families have balanced private family routines (like the Obamas’ nightly dinners) with White House life, showing the residence and role can flex to each family’s needs.

A 72‑year‑old man died at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service has asked Police Investigations and Review Commissioner Kate Frame to examine Police Scotland’s initial response to his call. Police Scotland says it is fully cooperating, and the commissioner’s report will be submitted to COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, forecasting gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h)—particularly to the west of the mountains—with an unusual easterly direction likely to intensify impacts. Forecasters warn of probable road and sea travel disruption across Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight gusts brought down a tree in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain shut for most of Monday for cleanup.

Derrick Walser opened the scoring short‑handed for the Giants before Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In period two, Mike Forney’s power‑play breakaway made it 2-1, only for Andy Bohmbach to tie it again. Later goals by Mike Radja and James Desmarais put the Giants up 4-2, and David Ling pulled one back for Nottingham. The teams face off again Saturday in the second game of their double‑header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers on 27 and Belfast on 25.

Nico Rosberg won a chaotic Chinese Grand Prix after Daniel Ricciardo overtook him at the start but suffered a puncture on lap 3. Lewis Hamilton, forced to start from the back following a lap‑1 broken front wing and hampered by further damage from collisions, made five pit stops but could not recover, leaving him 36 points behind Rosberg with 18 races remaining. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first‑lap clash with team‑mate Kimi Räikkönen, who fought back to fifth aided by Ferrari’s soft‑tyre strategy. Daniil Kvyat and Ricciardo completed the podium. Vettel later berated Kvyat over his aggressive inside move on lap 1, while Mercedes boss Toto Wolff explained Hamilton’s lost pace was due to extensive aerodynamic damage.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former Germany international, publicly came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit to spark discussion of a topic long ignored in German football. He is the most prominent player to do so, and received widespread praise: teammates Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, ex‑Germany FA president Theo Zwanziger, Bundesliga chief Reinhard Rauball, former England striker Gary Lineker, Joey Barton, John Amaechi and his old club Bayern Munich all lauded his “courageous” move. Their support underscores hopes that his announcement will help combat homophobia, still a problem in Germany despite past controversies—most notably Philipp Lahm’s 2011 advice that gay players stay closeted and second‑tier player Marcus Urban’s 2007 coming‑out. Chancellor Merkel’s spokesman and openly gay MP Volker Beck also applauded Hitzlsperger, with Zwanziger optimistic that sexual orientation will soon be irrelevant in the sport.

Gary Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season as Brighton secured promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years (their promotion was confirmed by a recent win over Wigan). With his contract expiring at season’s end, he hopes to sign a new deal, confident Brighton can stay up and even wrap up the title— they currently lead second‑placed Newcastle by four points with two games remaining. Sidwell joined permanently in June 2016 after a 2015–16 loan from Stoke, having previously played in the Premier League for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke. He feels his unexpectedly strong impact this season merits another contract and looks forward to “thrashing out” the details over the summer.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. After 12 minutes Nathan Delfouneso teed up Jamille Matt to open the scoring, and Colchester levelled soon after when Kurtis Guthrie finished from a corner. Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe made several key saves, including denying George Elokobi late in the first half, while Tom Aldred missed a gilt‑edged chance shortly before full‑time. In injury time Colchester were reduced to ten men when substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister. Substitutions and a few yellow cards punctuated an otherwise evenly contested match.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. Having previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, he could debut for Colchester United in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first‑round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3‑1 defeat at Accrington. For all the latest transfers, see our dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer in March spurred the UK Police Memorial Trust to accelerate plans for a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The trust has appealed for £1.5 million toward the £4 million cost of a monument inscribed with the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff who’ve died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. Its centerpiece will be a brass screen with leaf‑shaped plaques bearing individual names, which families can keep. Home Secretary Amber Rudd has pledged £1 million in government funding, and the memorial is expected to be completed by 2019. Chairman Sir Hugh Orde said it will honor policing’s vital contribution and become a lasting part of national life.

Manchester United sit 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League with eight games remaining after a 1–0 win at Sunderland, their 25th victory in 30 matches. Sir Alex Ferguson praised the squad’s focus—50 of 54 points won in the last 18 games—and looks ahead to Sunday’s Manchester derby and the chase to surpass Chelsea’s 95‑point record. Injuries to Rafael, Anderson and goalkeeper David de Gea at Sunderland mean changes for Monday’s FA Cup quarter‑final replay at Chelsea, with Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernández (and potentially Rio Ferdinand) returning to the squad. Ferguson credited determined defending and courage for the win.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt told the BBC that Google paid £10 million in UK corporate tax between 2006 and 2011—“what is legally required”—and would pay more or less only if the UK changed its tax laws. He said taxes aren’t optional and that it is up to politicians, not companies, to set and defend clearer rules. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the Commons Public Accounts Committee, has proposed a new body to scrutinise major firms’ tax arrangements in private to prevent them hiding behind confidentiality. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland, has been criticised for minimising its UK tax bill. Last week EU leaders agreed to tackle avoidance via automatic information exchanges between tax authorities. Schmidt has also urged international tax reform so that companies pay where they carry out economic activity and take risks, and called for a simpler, more transparent system.

NHS Improvement says last year’s £3.6 bn agency‑staff bill must be cut by £1 bn by year-end. An October cap—limiting pay to 55% above normal shift rates for all but senior managers—has saved £600 m so far, but trusts remain 10% off target. Agency staff cost more due to agency fees and employer contributions, and it’s unclear if reductions have driven up other pay costs. The regulator’s figures exclude in‑house “bank” staff and overtime. Later this year it will publish league tables of trusts’ agency spending and data on the top 20 highest‑paid agency workers amid reports of excessive quoting—e.g. £130/hour for a surgeon (cap £76) and £70/hour for a junior doctor (cap £35). Chief executive Jim Mackey warned that “much more is to be done.”

Longford’s modern glass-and‑concrete town centre, conceived in the Celtic Tiger era, now stands largely empty after the crash. Local trader Matt O’Brien reports a 30% fall in men’s-clothing sales and one lay‑off, but says business has improved over the past year thanks to diversification into children’s wear and dress hire. Fianna Fáil criticizes the Fine Gael–Labour government for spending €500 million on water meters instead of broadband and accuses the IDA of failing to attract foreign investors to Longford in four years. The government points to Center Parcs’ proposed €200 million, 1,000‑job tourism development (opening 2019, pending planning) and touts the region’s waterways and infrastructure as tourist draws. Traders, however, urge free street parking to bring more shoppers back, arguing that while a recovery is under way, further measures are needed.

Eight teams play a double round‑robin (each meets the others twice) from 25 April to 22 May (most games 15:30 BST, some 10:30), with the top four advancing to the play‑offs (Qualifier 1 on 24 May; Eliminator on 25 May; Qualifier 2 on 27 May) and the Final on 29 May in the same stadium. BBC Sport carries all scores and results.

Leading individual stats so far:
• Top run‑scorers: Warner 294, Kohli 267, de Villiers 249  
• Most sixes: Warner 12, de Villiers 12, Kohli 8  
• Highest innings: de Kock 108, Warner 90* and Gambhir 90*  
• Top wickets: McClenaghan 9, Kumar 8, Rahman 7  

Four current/former England players are involved:
• Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad)  
• Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians)  
• Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils)  
• Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants)

Since 2013 the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reports plastic carrier bag use has risen by 200 million. Most bags can’t be recycled, end up in landfills or waterways, and harm the environment. From October, England will introduce a 5 pence charge per bag—following similar schemes in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland that cut bag use—to encourage reuse and reduce environmental damage.

A yellow “be aware” wind warning across Wales brought gusts peaking at Mona on Anglesey, ripping part of a school roof off at Rhosgadfan and cutting power to hundreds of homes. Irish Ferries canceled six Holyhead–Dublin sailings, diverting passengers to cruise ferries. Arriva Trains Wales imposed speed restrictions and warned of delays between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, and the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge briefly operated under lane and speed limits. Winds eased by Friday evening, lifting those bridge controls, but blustery conditions forced Rhyl’s Boxing Day sea dip to be postponed by 24 hours.

Michael B. Jordan told The Hollywood Reporter he’s “super excited” to join Black Panther and hopes to “put a different spin on it,” though he wouldn’t reveal his role. The project reunites him with Creed director Ryan Coogler, and he’s eager to work alongside Oscar‑winner Lupita Nyong’o (12 Years a Slave) and Chadwick Boseman (now Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War). Jordan previously played the Human Torch in last year’s Fantastic Four, and Nyong’o voiced Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther opens February 2018.

Alexandra Palace’s 1875 theatre and adjoining BBC studios are at the centre of a £26.6 million east‑wing restoration—part of a wider plan to make the site a new cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund is providing £18.8 m, Haringey Council £6.8 m and the Alexandra Park & Palace Charitable Trust will raise the remaining £1 m by summer 2017. Renovations include repairing the studios, converting the glazed east court into public and exhibition space, and restoring the theatre—which retains much of its original décor and stage machinery after decades of disuse—to host drama, opera, musicals, cinema, comedy and live music, with a hoped‑for reopening in 2018.

James Milner, 30 and a former Manchester City player, made his England senior debut in 2009 and earned 61 caps, featuring in two World Cups and two European Championships (though he played just three minutes at Euro 2016). Announcing his international retirement as “common sense,” he wished manager Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters well. Milner also holds the England Under‑21 appearance record with 46 caps since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in a 5‑0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

In Glovertown, Newfoundland, Marcy Smith’s home was suddenly engulfed in flames after burning rubbish in a wood stove—a task she’d done many times before—and her smoke alarm failed. Her son David, awake on a FaceTime call, spotted the fire and roused the family, allowing them all to escape in their pajamas; their house was lost and their dog and cats did not survive. The community has since donated clothing, shoes and a bicycle for David. Smith lauds her son’s quick thinking, saying he’s the sole reason she and her daughter made it out alive.

Energy drinks firm Red Bull was reported to be weighing a £200 million bid for West Ham United. Co‑owners David Sullivan and David Gold acquired a majority stake in 2010 for £105 million and now hold over 85 percent of the club. Since moving to the London Stadium, West Ham have also been linked to Qatari and Chinese takeover talks, though Sullivan has said only a minority stake might be sold to clear debts and that he and Gold plan to pass ownership on to their children.

The fan‑voted ceremony, jokingly dubbed “definitely not the Oscars” by host Jillian Bell, doubled as a summer‑movie promo, premiering clips of Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck and Avengers: Age of Ultron. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner—best movie, best female performance, Trailblazer Award and best kiss (Shailene Woodley/Ansel Elgort)—with Woodley dedicating her speech to author John Green. Other top awards went to Bradley Cooper (best male for American Sniper), Channing Tatum (best comedic for 22 Jump Street), Meryl Streep (best villain for Into the Woods), plus wins for Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart picked up the Comedic Genius Award, bringing his children onstage, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award alongside his Avengers co‑stars.

Cammy Smith, 21, a Scotland Under‑21 forward, has been on loan since July and has already scored five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and tallied four goals in 89 appearances for them. St Mirren manager Jack Ross described Smith as a “brilliant acquisition,” praising his maturity and the extra attacking option he provides. Championship bottom‑club St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council says that with warmer weather its Jetpatcher machines can now tackle potholes, aiming to fill about 145 holes per day over the next four months. Extra staff will also repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016 on EnQuest’s Thistle platform, 125 miles northeast of Shetland, six Wood Group contractors led by rigging supervisor Steve Innes were exposed for hours to low‐level alpha radiation (NORM) while removing pipework during a planned shutdown. The men, who initially worked without proper PPE, only learned of the hazard two‑thirds of the way through the job. They now face cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests; Innes says EnQuest breached its duty of care and has struggled to find work since raising concerns.  

EnQuest states the exposure was under 1% of HSE’s reportable level, that it informed the HSE at the time, and has since added precautionary controls. Wood Group says it prioritized medical assessments, downmanned the platform, and joined EnQuest in a detailed investigation. The Unite union has called for greater transparency on offshore safety incidents. The HSE confirmed it was notified but deemed the event non‑reportable under RIDDOR and opened no formal investigation.

The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari in 2007 for US$650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past. In 2012, the dealer’s manager, Aaron Freedman, admitted trafficking in stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece, which is believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. After the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) formally requested its return in May—and following discussions between the ASI and Singapore’s National Heritage Board—the ACM decided to restitute the sculpture. Although there is no definitive proof it was looted from that temple, the museum acted on Freedman’s confession. The work was one of 30 items ACM acquired from the dealer (none of the others are known to be stolen), all of which the ASI was permitted to inspect. The museum also plans legal action to recover its purchase price.

A magnitude‑4.8 earthquake hit at 15:48 local time, at a depth of 15.5 km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana, 35 km north of Lucca. It was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena; several lower‑magnitude aftershocks followed. In Garfagnana phone lines and power were cut, and nearby schools were evacuated and inspected; there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy, long prone to seismic activity, suffered nearly 300 deaths in the 2009 L’Aquila quake and over 20 fatalities in two magnitude‑6 tremors last May in the same region. Alessandro Amato of the National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology described this latest event as “medium‑strong” and “fairly shallow.” Italy is still contending with the fallout from the L’Aquila disaster, where six scientists and an ex‑official were convicted in 2012 of providing “inaccurate, incomplete and contradictory” risk assessments that left many residents indoors and contributed to the high death toll.

On 8 September 2016, 62‑year‑old Sheffield gardener Austin Grant finally saw fruit setting on his plants in South Yorkshire—despite earlier doubts about the climate—though the fruit remains unripe. He described the moment as “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has delayed the PC release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March, saying it needs extra weeks of testing and polish. In the meantime, eagerly awaited online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch. New PC screenshots promise higher detail—1080p at 60 fps, up to 4K and triple‑monitor support—and minimum system requirements have been published. Originally released on 17 September 2013, GTA V became the fastest‑selling entertainment product ever, earning $1 billion in just three days.

Tony Simpson, 76, has won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for Squint (19), a roughly 7‑ft‑tall work depicting a medieval “leper squint” hole. A past 1991 shortlist artist and three‑time longlistee, Simpson chose this familiar, manageable piece from a larger series for the competition. Judge Ansel Krut praised its subtle, minimal “tone poem” quality despite its challenging subject. Simpson plans to spend the award on canvases, stretcher bars and high‑quality paints. The biennial prize, founded in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards; past winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig, and Sir Peter Blake—now patron—won its junior title in 1961.

Early on Thursday, the offices of two pro‑AK Party Istanbul newspapers—Yeni Safak and, 20 km away, Yeni Akit—were attacked almost simultaneously. Four masked assailants set a fire at Yeni Safak (quickly doused by firefighters), and gunfire shattered windows at both buildings, leaving spent bullet casings behind. No casualties were reported. Police cordoned off the scenes and are hunting the perpetrators, though no group has claimed responsibility. In September, pro‑government protesters had attacked the offices of Hurriyet, accusing it of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24‑year‑old ex‑Burton forward, previously contracted to the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer on 1 January. He spent the season’s first half on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and is Bignot’s first signing for the club.

Arsène Wenger, under contract at Arsenal until next summer, has dismissed links to the England manager’s job, praising interim boss Gareth Southgate’s growing experience after England’s win over Malta and draw with Slovenia. Wenger believes competency outweighs big names and says Southgate’s upcoming World Cup qualifier against Scotland and friendly with Spain will prove his suitability for the permanent role. At club level, Wenger confirmed he will offer 21‑year‑old right‑back Héctor Bellerín a new contract amid interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, and revealed midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss another one or two games with a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, and the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that, from next month, freight services on the Northern Isles route will revert from Seatruck to Serco Northlink under a new charter designed to guarantee all seafarers at least the UK minimum wage. This ends a dispute in which the RMT union alleged some crew were paid under £4/hour and Seatruck—operating the cargo vessels Hellier and Hildasay for Serco Northlink—contended the national minimum wage did not apply to its largely non‑UK workforce. Serco Northlink, which has held the six‑year, £243 million Northern Isles contract since 2012 and runs three ferries plus two cargo boats on a Scottish government–subsidised route, had offered to backdate and top up wages, an offer Seatruck declined. Financial and regulatory details are being finalised before the new arrangements take effect.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after a confrontation at Rockley Park in Poole on 7 May. The incident involved him and his longtime partner, Samantha Mitchell, 57, and her son, Jamie Mitchell, 35, who intervened. Jamie pleaded guilty to common assault and, with his mother, admitted perverting the course of justice by initially telling police Dickie had pushed Samantha. He later said he was merely trying to separate them, causing a “tragic accident.” After a Winchester Crown Court jury convicted him, he reacted visibly to the verdict. Sentencing is set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter behind disco‑funk classics and Michael Jackson hits, died in London last week at 66 following “a brief aggressive battle with cancer,” his publisher Warner/Chappell said. Born in Cleethorpes, he credited his father’s late‑night radio broadcasts for sparking his musical gift. After working in a Grimsby frozen‑food factory, he answered a Melody Maker ad and joined Heatwave in the mid‑1970s, writing their hits “Boogie Nights,” “Always & Forever” and “Groove Line.” In 1978 Quincy Jones recruited him for Jackson’s Off the Wall, and he penned “Rock With You,” “Off the Wall” and “Burn This Disco Out.” He followed with “Thriller,” “Baby Be Mine” and “The Lady in My Life” on Thriller, which sold 32 million copies in the US. His songs were also recorded by Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin and others. He won a 1990 Grammy for “Birdland,” earned two 1986 Oscar nominations, and was nicknamed “The Invisible Man” for his low profile. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya and others; his private funeral has taken place, and his family requests privacy.

A multidisciplinary team—including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Prof Alayne Street‑Perrott, researchers from Exeter, Reading and Brazilian universities—has uncovered more than 450 large, geometric ditched enclosures (“geoglyphs”) up to 2,000 years old in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. Hidden beneath bamboo forest until recent deforestation, these earthworks yield few artifacts and lack defensive layouts, suggesting sporadic, likely ritual use rather than permanent settlement—perhaps akin to Maya or Stonehenge gatherings. Soil analyses (phytoliths, charcoal levels, carbon isotopes) indicate they were built under tall canopy, challenging visibility‑based purpose theories. Further, the region’s diverse plant assemblages—sustained over 6,000 years—imply deliberate “agroforestry,” concentrating valuable species in a “prehistoric supermarket,” a legacy still evident in today’s forest biodiversity.

21-year-old Australian Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career‑high 12th, defeated world No. 29 Sam Querrey 6‑4, 6‑4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round. Fresh from winning the Japan Open and closing in on the top 10, he admitted feeling tired and “a bit bored” due to poor sleep, late arrival and a long commute to Shanghai’s Qi Zhong Stadium. Last year at the same event he was fined $1,500 for calling the tournament a “circus.”

Scientists and charities warn that the HPV vaccine, currently given to girls aged 12–13 to prevent cervical cancer, also protects against head and neck cancers—which are rising, especially among younger non‑smoking men (average age 55). Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru and Cardiff University’s HPV team will deliver a letter urging the Welsh government, now awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation, to extend the programme to boys. Dr Mererid Evans highlights shifting demographics, and Jon Antoniazzi notes HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden, calling for immediate action. Since 2008, 85% of Welsh girls have been vaccinated; the government says it will consider any proposed changes once recommendations are published.

Jak Trueman was a 15‑year‑old West Calder High School pupil who’d been fighting a rare blood cancer (gamma delta T‑cell lymphoma) since last August. With his mother Allison, sister Aimie and girlfriend Hannah Boyd, he documented his treatment and his upbeat spirit on a Facebook page, “Jak’s Journey,” which drew over 28,000 Likes. Jak’s love of Rangers FC and visits from former and current players, along with outings—from hospital stays in Edinburgh and Glasgow to visits to the Kelpies, supercar and quad‑bike rides, and a romantic meal—featured alongside school moments, tuba performances and more.  

On 23 January, doctors confirmed his cancer had spread systemically and ceased further treatment; he and his family then urged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.
