On the eve of his death, Jak managed to attend a prom held in his honour—greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson—long enough to see his family collect his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and a trophy for overcoming adversity before feeling too unwell to stay. His mother later announced his passing on Facebook. A charity football match at Livingston FC’s Energy Assets Arena is planned to raise further funds in his memory.

Egypt edged Uganda 1-0 in a dour Group D contest thanks to Abdallah El Said’s late (89ʹ) finish from a Mohamed Salah assist. Earlier, Uganda’s Joseph Ochaya had a goal correctly ruled out for offside. Seven‑time champions Egypt, who struggled to break down a resolute Ugandan defence, now meet Ghana with top spot still undecided; Ghana had already sealed their quarter‑final berth by beating Mali 1-0. Uganda, playing their first AFCON since 1978, are eliminated and face Mali next, with Mali needing a win plus a two‑goal victory for Ghana over Egypt to keep their own hopes alive.

Lancashire County Council has identified the former Glenburn Sports College site and the unused Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College for a new railway station, following a Network Rail study that also considered a town‐centre location. Skelmersdale’s original station closed in 1956, and the town—designated a new town in 1961—remains one of the largest in northwest England without rail service. In partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, the county plans to run two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. Cabinet member John Fillis highlighted the preferred site’s scope for expansion, strong highway access and local connectivity. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land.
On Saturday morning, police searching a warehouse near Ashbourne discovered plants in an “elaborate grow house” and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28‑year‑old German woman of Kurdish origin was found late Sunday with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38‑year‑old ex‑partner—also a German citizen of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender—has handed himself in and is in custody. Authorities have secured the scene, are seeking witnesses, and say the motive remains unclear.

A study of 4,600 Australian workers by Cass Business School, Warwick and Wisconsin universities found that women ask for pay rises as often as men but are 25% less likely to receive one. By comparing full‑time with full‑time and part‑time with part‑time workers—and controlling for employer size, industry, parental status and qualifications—the researchers refuted the idea that women are simply more reluctant to negotiate. Using data from the 2013–14 Australian Workplace Relations Survey (the only national dataset recording pay‑rise requests), they concluded the gap reflects discrimination rather than female reticence. They also found that under‑40 men and women now ask for and obtain raises at equal rates, suggesting younger women may be changing negotiation norms.

Oxford City Council has spent most of its allocated funds on ground investigations for new burial sites but has found none suitable. The only two cemeteries with remaining space—Wolvercote and Botley—are projected to fill by 2018 and 2021. Despite ongoing efforts, all council‑owned candidate sites have been ruled out on grounds of size, ground conditions, high water tables or restrictive covenants. Once the last plots are used, burials will be limited to reopened family plots, a few reserved spaces and ashes interments. Oxford’s burial capacity was last expanded in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will run in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19–22 July and will feature acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. For the first time, visitors can use an augmented‑reality app on phones or tablets to scan signs and posters around the site and unlock videos, band interviews and other online content. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan says this “extra feature” will both enhance the on‑site experience and allow people worldwide to access festival information, buy tickets and sample its atmosphere before and during the event.

Many Clouds, a 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding, collapsed and died of a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage” immediately after narrowly beating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. Veterinary staff treated him on the track, but he was pronounced dead shortly afterward. The British Horseracing Authority—via acting chief veterinary officer Tony Welsh—said such catastrophic bleeds are rare, can affect horses with no underlying health issues, and warrant further research into causes and prevention. Although Many Clouds had previously shown post‑race ataxia (over‑heating and wobbling) and received treatment, he exhibited no such symptoms on the day and was otherwise deemed healthy. Owned by Trevor Hemmings, trained by Oliver Sherwood (who called him “the horse of a lifetime”), and ridden by Leighton Aspell, his major victories included the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup. Despite speculation that his past overheating might have contributed, the official report attributed his death solely to the rare haemorrhage.

In autumn 2004 in Portsmouth, a 15‑year‑old girl met David Ayrton in a garage; Ayrton (now 34 and known as Davina) is accused of raping her while two friends slept. She denies the charge. At Portsmouth Crown Court, Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody—likely at a male prison in Winchester—citing suicide and flight risks, with sentencing set for 4 March. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, changed her name in 2012 and during the trial discussed her sexuality, stating she has made no physical transitions or taken related medication. The victim, who had drunk about one and a half cans of Foster’s, says she clearly recalls shouting for Ayrton to stop. In 2014 Ayrton told a care‑home worker in Fordingbridge about the attack.

In Rio de Janeiro, the Serbian doubles pair fell 6-4, 6-4 to Brazil’s Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares, coming a day after Novak Djokovic was upset by Juan Martín del Potro in the singles. Earlier this season, world No. 1 Djokovic suffered a surprise third‑round Wimbledon loss to Sam Querrey but rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto ahead of the Olympics.

Over 20 chainsaw carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US will compete this Saturday in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms, using only chainsaws to sculpt logs into animals and people. Last year’s champion, Pete Bowsher of Moffat, returns to defend the Claymore Trophy.

George North–named here as Webb–has been sidelined since suffering a serious foot injury during a World Cup warm‑up against Italy in September but is now “back up and running” in a pre‑season phase, aiming to return in time for Wales’s Six Nations opener against Ireland on 7 February. The 27‑year‑old has asked his physios to accelerate his rehab by a couple of weeks and will assess his progress weekly. Capped 16 times by Wales, he has just renewed his national dual contract with his home province, the Ospreys, and the Welsh Rugby Union—turning down other offers—to keep himself in prime contention for international selection.

On Tuesday morning near Sumas, Washington, US border agents stopped two men carrying backpacks holding 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA bound for San Francisco. One suspect dropped his pack, fired at agents and fled; the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested on the spot. A joint US–Canadian manhunt led to the capture of Nathan Hall in Abbotsford, BC, who carried a false California ID. Authorities then arrested Kali Henifin and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert—allegedly enlisted to pick up and drive the drugs for $11,000. All four face federal conspiracy, drug possession and distribution charges along a known smuggling route.

• NSPCC’s Childline counselled over 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year—almost double the 2,400 cases in 2011–12—with the true number believed to be much higher.  
• Some victims are as young as seven, reporting torment, humiliation and fear of attending school.  
• Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen warns that cyber‑bullying “follows them home” and urges parents, teachers and schools to intervene, as bullying left unchecked only worsens.  
• The report is released at the start of Anti‑Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance in partnership with parents, schools and other organisations.  
• A young caller’s account—being told online to kill themselves and feeling parents don’t understand—underscores the severe emotional impact and need for support.

Prime Minister Netanyahu’s office asked Jerusalem’s Planning and Housing Committee to postpone a vote on authorising 492 new homes in the Ramat Shlomo and Ramot settlements to avoid further straining relations with Washington just before US Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli‑Palestinian conflict. This move follows the US abstention—rather than a veto—on a UN Security Council resolution condemning all West Bank and East Jerusalem settlements as “illegal” and a “flagrant violation” blocking a two‑state solution. Netanyahu, infuriated by the abstention, accused the White House of drafting and pushing the resolution—a claim the State Department denied. In protest, Israel summoned foreign ambassadors, recalled its envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal and cancelled Ukraine’s prime minister’s visit. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution as paving the way for the 15 January peace conference in France and urged a clear timetable to end the occupation.

On the eve of the Queen’s 90th birthday, Prince William told the BBC that his grandmother’s “duty, service, tolerance and commitment” have been a “guiding example” for what a good monarch should be. He acknowledged newspaper jibes about being “work‑shy” but said he takes his future role seriously and aims to live as normally as possible until he is fully engaged with royal duties.

To mark the milestone, Royal Mail issued ten commemorative stamps—including a sheet showing four generations of the family (the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince George)—and the Queen, with the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor’s main delivery office to celebrate 500 years of the postal service, attended a bandstand opening by schoolchildren and heard them sing “Happy Birthday.”

On her actual birthday she and Prince Philip will unveil a plaque for The Queen’s Walkway—a 6.3 km trail celebrating her record-breaking reign—and light the first of over 900 beacons. On Friday, President Barack Obama and the First Lady will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn both paid tribute at Prime Minister’s Questions, while the republican group Republic accused the BBC of unbalanced, celebratory coverage.

West Ham United eliminated Cheltenham Town from the EFL Cup with a 2–0 win. After a bright start by the League Two side, Diafra Sakho opened the scoring before half‑time—his first goal since November—assisted by Sam Byram, and Andre Ayew quickly added a second. Cheltenham, unchanged from Saturday’s 3–0 league loss, threatened through Harry Pell’s volley and Dan Holman’s late slide-in but never seriously tested keeper Adrian. Slaven Bilic’s side, making seven changes after recent Premier League defeats, could have won by more but saw clearances from captain Kyle Storer and saves by Jonathan Flatt. Cheltenham’s exit ended League Two’s representation in the competition; the clubs’ only previous meeting was a 2–1 West Ham victory at Upton Park four years ago.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, was killed when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, turned his VW Transporter across the A5 at Cerrigydrudion without seeing the motorcyclist. Werner, a father of four, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim’s family, accepting it was a momentary lapse, saw no value in imprisonment; Werner expressed remorse and had no explanation for the crash.

• Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, travelled to Syria in January last year and fought with the Islamic State‑affiliated Rayat al Tawheed under the kunya Abu Daigham al‑Britani.  
• He regularly posted masked propaganda videos and images—appealing for donations, glorifying jihad, even showing a severed head—aimed at recruiting young British Muslims.  
• Monitored by MI5, Khawaja faked his own death online and in June attempted to return covertly via Bulgaria with help from his cousin, taxi‑driver Tahir Bhatti.  
• Upon arrival at Dover he was arrested and charged; he has admitted four offences (a solicitation‑to‑murder charge now lies on file), while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.  
• Considered “one of the most dangerous British jihadists” by police, Khawaja is held in Belmarsh’s high‑risk terrorism unit and faces a potential life sentence.

Twenty-two‑year‑old Jackson, who scored four goals in 36 appearances as Wrexham finished eighth last season, has become Barnsley’s third signing for next term after rejecting a new Wrexham contract. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and directness, saying he will suit Barnsley’s style, with the move announced ahead of their League One play‑off final at Wembley.

National Trust volunteers have been removing sealed—but in some cases leaking—detergent bottles washing up on Poldhu Cove and other nearby Cornish coves (Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove and Marazion) after a container was believed to have gone overboard in stormy seas in May near Land’s End. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirms the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of “Vanish” but says there’s no definitive proof the stranded bottles came from it. Cornwall Wildlife Trust and the National Trust warn of the risk posed by detergent to sensitive marine life. Cornwall Council, the MCA and Natural England are monitoring the situation, have instructed volunteers to clear the beaches, and advise the public to keep children and dogs away and not to handle the bottles. Vanish has not yet commented.

At about 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, a crash left several people with minor injuries. The road was closed, with traffic diverted via the A897 between Helmsdale and Melvich, and Police Scotland are investigating.

28‑year‑old French centre‑back Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton after helping the Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. Since joining from Charlton in 2014 he has made 83 appearances in all competitions, including 14 last season when, as Phil Parkinson noted, he “came in and made an excellent contribution towards the end of the campaign.” He follows David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan in agreeing new deals ahead of Bolton’s Championship season.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have fallen out in the Lords after previously teaming up to defeat the government on EU citizens’ rights and requiring parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of “conceding everything,” while Labour’s Baroness Smith said the Lib Dems were offering “false hope.” Cooperation collapsed when MPs wouldn’t back those amendments: the Lib Dems vowed to press on, Labour deferred to the Commons. A Labour source called the Lib Dems’ stance “grandstanding” for campaign material, and Baroness Ludford retorted that Labour was “waving through” a hard Brexit alongside the Conservatives. Although the parties have allied on other issues—from higher education to housing—Baroness Ludford expects continued collaboration where possible, but Labour insiders foresee “residual tensions” and only “business‑like” engagement going forward.

• Defence is a low election priority—polls rank it behind the economy, the NHS and immigration—and party manifestos offer little substantive detail.  
• Rising global threats (mass migration, Islamic extremism, a belligerent Russia) contrast with cuts to UK forces: Army down from 102,000 to 82,000 personnel; Royal Navy to 19 ships; RAF to 7–8 fast‑jet squadrons; no Maritime Patrol Aircraft.  
• UK defence spending has fallen from 4th to 6th largest globally and is projected to dip below NATO’s 2%‑of‑GDP guideline (to 1.7%, possibly 1.5%); only UKIP and the DUP pledge to maintain 2%, requiring an extra £25 billion over five years.  
• The MoD budget is unprotected amid broader deficit‑cutting plans, making further cuts (an estimated £2–3 billion annually) likely—even though the Conservatives promise a 1% annual rise in equipment spending, no further army reductions, and Trident renewal.  
• Nuclear deterrent plans lack consensus: Conservatives and UKIP back four replacement submarines (~£20 billion); Labour may reduce to three; Liberal Democrats would end continuous at‑sea patrol; SNP and Greens would scrap the deterrent. A post‑election Strategic Defence Review is expected.  
• Two new Queen Elizabeth‑class aircraft carriers (due by decade’s end) risk being under‑crewed and under‑equipped—only 12 F‑35s planned versus a 36‑aircraft capacity—fueling warnings of a “hollow force” despite high‑end platforms.

FC Barcelona has denied any fiscal wrongdoing in the 2013 signing of Neymar, saying its aim was merely “to cover eventual interpretations” of the contracts. The club initially paid €57 million (£48.6 m) to Santos and £34 m to Neymar’s parents; with signing‑on fees, wages over a five‑year deal and agents’ fees, the total cost reaches £106.8 m. After a Spanish judge ruled there was enough evidence to pursue the case, Barça made a supplementary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56, while insisting its original payments were correct. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid allegations of misappropriation (which he denies). Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 La Liga games and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, died as a passenger in a Ford Transit when it was struck head‑on at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by 79‑year‑old Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw’s family—his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon—and the van’s driver, Andy Harrington, who was seriously injured, are urging mandatory medical and on‑road driving tests for older motorists. Currently in the UK, drivers over 70 submit a self‑assessment form every three years with no medical or practical test. The DVLA says there is no evidence older drivers are more accident‑prone and has no plans to change this, while Age UK stresses the importance of safe driving to maintain older people’s independence. For more, see Inside Out on BBC One East Midlands on 25 January.

• Concerns have been raised over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants for incontinence after many women suffered serious side effects.  
• Two patient members resigned in protest at what they called a “watered‑down” independent review report.  
• Professor Alison Britton of Glasgow Caledonian University will audit how the review reached its conclusions and identify future lessons.  
• The final report advises against routinely offering mesh for pelvic organ prolapse, urges that women be given a full range of treatment options and information to make “informed choices,” and recommends mandatory reporting of adverse events.  
• Despite campaigners’ calls for an outright ban, the Scottish government will implement these recommendations; only the UK’s Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency can prohibit the procedures.  
• Tracey Gillies, who chaired the review in its final stages, apologized for failing to achieve consensus, noting she did not consult her predecessor, Lesley Wilkie.  
• Two more patient representatives and a consultant quit the group, alleging parts of the report were removed.  
• In Scotland over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women have received mesh or tape implants; over 400 are currently pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, ran 14:49.12 at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena to break Yvonne McColgan’s 25‑year‑old British indoor 5,000 m record by 14 seconds. McColgan welcomed the new mark but questioned whether Muir’s solo effort—she was the only one to finish in a mixed 3 km race—and the absence of onsite drug testing met UK Athletics’ criteria. British Athletics has indicated the time is expected to be officially ratified, noting no doping control is required for British records. McColgan praised Muir’s performance and believes, given her 3:55 1,500 m speed, she could lower the 5 K to around 14:30 and contest world medals. She also likened Muir’s solo race to her own 25‑year‑old record—when she lapped competitors including a young Paula Radcliffe—and welcomed that a fellow Scot had surpassed her mark. Muir, already Britain’s 1,500 m record‑holder and a Rio 2016 Olympic finalist, continues to advance on the world stage.

German rider Michael Jung took individual gold aboard Sam—a late replacement mount after Fischertakinou fell ill in July. France’s Astier Nicolas claimed silver and U.S. rider Phillip Dutton bronze. Britain’s 47‑year‑old William Fox‑Pitt, competing just 10 months after an induced coma, delivered a clear show‑jumping round on Chilli Morning but had fallen from first after dressage to 21st by incurring cross‑country time penalties and ultimately finished 12th. Ireland’s Jonty Evans was ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray defeated 29th‑seeded Fabio Fognini 6‑2, 4‑6, 6‑1, 7‑5 in two hours 39 minutes on Centre Court, sealing match point at 20:57 BST. Fognini twice threatened a deciding set—saving break points and earning five set points in the fourth—but Murray won five consecutive games to reach the Wimbledon last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Earlier, Britain’s Johanna Konta also progressed to the second week for the first time with a 6‑4, 6‑1 win over Maria Sakkari. Murray described the match as “tense” and “up and down,” praised his resilience under fading light and looks ahead to a short rest before Monday’s match.

On 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST, paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven. Police found patrons still on the premises and till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST, well past licensing hours. The court ordered the bar closed for three months. Licensee Colleen O’Neill, 43, was charged with two counts—and James Thomas, 44, with one count—of allowing liquor consumption outside permitted hours. The defence conceded the bar had not been properly run. The judge, condemning O’Neill’s “appalling record,” lamented his inability to impose a custodial sentence. O’Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt wrapped up the Ulster Unionist launch of their “Real Partnership” manifesto by declaring “domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” and framing the election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive fiasco. His off‑the‑cuff remark that, if forced to choose, he’d rather enter Stormont with the SDLP than Sinn Féin drew criticism from colleague Danny Kennedy—prompting Nesbitt to quip that Kennedy’s public distancing merely proved he’d been listening. Nesbitt refused to retract or regret his comments, urged voters to back the UUP and any candidate they trusted locally, and reported strong support in unionist areas. He warned voters to remember the RHI’s £85,000‑a‑day cost and a decade of DUP–Sinn Féin government. The manifesto pledges to tackle health‑care waiting lists, boost PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritise the York Street interchange, defend LGBT rights, protect all groups post‑Brexit, and “clean up Stormont” from incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and corruption.

Northern Ireland’s Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to ask the Assembly to approve a legislative consent motion that would extend the automatic posthumous and living pardons for men convicted of now‑abolished sexual offences—known as “Turing’s Law”—to gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, bringing it into line with provisions already announced for England and Wales. This move is intended to right past wrongs more swiftly than a standalone Assembly bill.

23‑year‑old Laura Muir of Kinross ran 4:19.12 for 1500 m—second to Kenya’s Faith Kipyegon—smashing Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish record (4:22.60) and moving to second on Britain’s all‑time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). Already holder of Scotland’s 1500 m and mile records and fifth at last year’s World Championships, she aims to clinch a Rio Olympic spot at the British trials (24–26 June). Muir opened her season with an 800 m win in Montbéliard, will race 1500 m in Stockholm next week, and balances elite training with her fourth year of veterinary studies.
A selection of your photos from the 26 Scottish beaches classified as having “most excellent” water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC told the inquiry that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi—who deny wrongdoing—had no personal motive to kill ex‑FSB officer Alexander Litvinenko but that “reasons aplenty” made the Russian state the likely sponsor of the 2006 polonium‑210 poisoning in London. Litvinenko, who had defected in 2000 and publicly attacked the FSB and President Putin, drank contaminated tea and died three weeks later. Horwell cited two separate poisoning attempts, a radioactive trail, unknown public health risks and the suspects’ failure to address the scientific evidence. Extradition bids have failed, they remain in Russia, and the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed permanent captain of Australia’s one-day and Twenty20 teams in place of the injured Aaron Finch, with David Warner, 28, named vice‑captain. This follows Michael Clarke’s retirement at 34 after Australia’s 3–1 Ashes defeat in England. Smith, who captained three Tests last summer during Clarke’s injury, has scored 2,952 runs in 32 Tests at an average of 54.66. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and Warner’s maturation despite past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited‑overs series following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting 20 August.

He repeatedly declined to say whether homosexual sex is a sin—telling Channel 4 News “we are all sinners”—but told the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show he’s “passionate about LGBT‑plus rights” and will make defending—and extending—equal marriage a top Liberal Democrat priority. He wants to remove the “spousal veto” that forces a trans person’s spouse to consent to keep their marriage after transition. Asked why he opposed the 2007 Equality Bill (which would have curbed anti‑gay discrimination by businesses), he said he backed equality but voted against it after his party’s amendment, aimed at protecting individual liberties, was rejected. He insists he supports equal legal access for everyone, regardless of sexuality.

Accord Healthcare is reopening the former Sanofi drug‐manufacturing plant in Fawdon, which closed in 2015 with the loss of 450 jobs, and aims to rehire many ex‑Sanofi employees. A company spokesman expects the investment to have an “extremely positive” local impact. Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes welcomed the move as a boost to the city’s science and healthcare reputation, noting Accord’s status as a global pharmaceutical player. Accord Healthcare currently develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 products to around 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, the council’s former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, leaves Friday at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive’s office) and Ewan Sutherland (head of HR and customer services) are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn said these departures highlight the council’s difficulty retaining senior staff and predicted more exits, while chief executive Angela Scott thanked all three for their dedication and professionalism.

Martin, the English rider, suffered a crash at this year’s TT and has endured persistent mechanical troubles with his Fireblade. Although he initially told MCN he was quitting road racing, he later clarified on Facebook that he simply won’t race Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will also sit out next month’s Ulster Grand Prix. Describing the TT as “a bloody disaster” (aside from a historic Mugen outing), Martin felt he was reduced to a test rider. After further tests at Cadwell convinced him the bike wouldn’t be competitive at Ulster, the team withdrew him without prior notice. He says there’s no unfinished business in road racing and plans to focus on classic and “oddball” events.

In Saturday’s governor elections, Nigeria’s opposition All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 races—a sharp reversal for the long‑ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which managed eight governorships (mostly in the south‑east), held oil‑hub Rivers State, while Taraba remains undecided and Imo was declared inconclusive. This follows APC leader Muhammadu Buhari’s presidential victory over Goodluck Jonathan; Buhari takes office on 29 May. The APC’s sweep across the north and in Lagos relegates the PDP to a regional force. Although violence was lower than in past polls, 66 incidents were reported. After 16 years in power, marked by defections, corruption allegations and failings against Boko Haram, the PDP faces a period of introspection and rebuilding.

Mighty’s report alleges that Olam and its main stakeholder Temasek have unwittingly supported unsustainable, haze‑causing palm oil practices by sourcing from unvetted third‑party suppliers, exacerbating the slash‑and‑burn fires in Indonesia that annually shroud Singapore and Malaysia. Olam—buying 99% of its palm oil from outside suppliers and holding under 1% of the global market—is accused of creating a “secretive market” for rogue producers. CEO Sunny Verghese insists on a strict “no burn, no peat, no deforestation” policy, has disclosed 14 suppliers, and vows to remove non‑compliant growers. Temasek, while endorsing no‑burn principles, says it does not direct Olam’s operations. The broader palm oil industry—projected at $88 billion by 2022—faces criticism for deforestation, labour abuses and fire‑clearing, amid calls for stronger enforcement. The report also targets Olam’s Gabon ventures, alleging rainforest clearing for plantations, which Olam defends as limited, transparent partnerships.

On 27 August 2016 (last updated at 12:34 BST), following a new law allowing dogs to dine at restaurants—as long as they remain outdoors—a restaurant began offering “puppy platters.” A video clip showcases the canine‐friendly spread.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful with a knee problem, having only managed substitute appearances in the last two matches. Striker David Nugent could return from a groin injury after missing Monday’s draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield—who came off the bench to score a late equaliser against Huddersfield—is pushing for a recall.

Pakistan’s telecom regulator has lifted its 2012 Supreme Court‑ordered YouTube ban, saying it’s no longer needed now that Google has launched a Pakistan‑specific YouTube site. All ISPs have been told to restore access, while the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority can now request removal of “offending material” through an online process provided by Google. YouTube insists it will only take down content that breaches its community guidelines or is judged illegal after review, and will log all government removal requests in its Transparency Report. Activists are calling for full disclosure of the terms between Google and the government. The original ban followed protests over the amateur film Innocence of Muslims, which was deemed blasphemous under Pakistani law.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss‑Italian chair of FIFA’s Ad‑Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing calls from Liberian FA president Musa Bility to resign because he shares nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility cites Article 7.4 of FIFA’s Electoral Regulations—which barred committee members with conflicts of interest in 2015 when Scala and Claudio Sulser stepped aside to avoid any appearance of bias toward Swiss incumbent Sepp Blatter—and threatens to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw within three working days. Scala’s spokesman counters that no FIFA rule prohibits members from sharing a nationality with candidates and that Scala only withdrew in 2015 as a voluntary, precautionary measure against an incumbent president. Bility, who was himself barred from running in November, has endorsed Prince Ali and urged African votes for him. The election to replace Sepp Blatter will be held on 26 February in Zurich, with 209 FIFA members casting ballots among five candidates: Prince Ali, Gianni Infantino, Jérôme Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint‑spraying area at Harford Attachments on Spar Road, a company that makes buckets for diggers. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon, after a forensic search at the site. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham said forensic inquiries and witness statements indicate a flashover explosion—caused by a build‑up of toxic fumes and an ignition—produced a fire‑ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive has sent inspectors and electrical safety experts to gather further evidence.

Tunisia and Morocco both overcame bans to enter the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers after resolving separate disputes with CAF. Tunisia had been threatened with expulsion for protesting a controversial last‑minute penalty in their 2015 quarter‑final defeat to Equatorial Guinea. The Tunisian federation apologized—clarifying it never accused the referee of corruption, only questioned his appointment—and patched things up with CAF president Issa Hayatou. Morocco had been banned and fined $1 million for refusing to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears; the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and cut the fine to $50,000. Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa described the setback as minimal. Equatorial Guinea ultimately staged the 2015 finals with just 64 days’ notice. In December’s 2017 draw, Tunisia landed in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti—where a successful campaign would secure a record 13th straight finals—while Morocco drew Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F.

In the 95th minute of Chelsea’s 3‑1 win at the Etihad, a brawl erupted after Sergio Aguero’s late challenge on David Luiz. Both Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off; Chelsea’s Cesc Fàbregas escaped further action. Pep Guardiola apologized for City’s role. Aguero (28) received a four‑match ban for his second violent‑conduct dismissal of the season, and Fernandinho was handed a three‑match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales has some of the poorest cancer survival rates in the developed world, in part because patients without clear “red‑flag” symptoms wait weeks for diagnostic tests. After studying Denmark’s successful rapid‑diagnosis centres, Cwm Taf Health Board has launched a six‑month pilot in Cwm Cynon (and a parallel trial at Neath Port Talbot) allowing 40 GPs to refer worried patients directly to a diagnostic clinic at Princess of Wales Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days. An estimated six patients per week will receive same‑day investigations, speeding up diagnosis and treatment. Only 35% of those with concerning symptoms in Cwm Taf currently get a timely diagnosis, so the scheme aims to catch patients earlier and improve outcomes. If it succeeds, all regional health boards will adopt the service.

England crushed Pakistan by their second‑largest Test‑run margin at Old Trafford, winning with a day to spare to level the four‑match series. After declaring on 589‑8 and 173‑1, England bowled Pakistan out for 198 and 234 on a placid pitch. Joe Root, promoted to No. 3, was named man of the match for his 254 and an unbeaten 71, plus four catches and a wicket; captain Alastair Cook made 105 and 76*. Broad praise came from Michael Vaughan, Geoffrey Boycott and coach Trevor Bayliss. Pakistan, whose only fifty‑plus scores in the series so far are from Misbah‑ul‑Haq and Asad Shafiq, lamented poor shot selection and confidence. They face Worcestershire on Friday before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August. Vaughan nevertheless expects a tight series.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the 2017 British and Irish Lions tour to New Zealand, with Rob Howley named as interim back‑room coach. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will act as head coach for the third time—having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013—and says he’s honoured to take on the role again. The Welsh Rugby Union is finalizing appointments of assistant coaches for McBryde’s summer tour management team, with full confirmations expected next week. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips and chairman Gareth Davies believe that giving Welsh coaches this Lions experience will strengthen and inspire Welsh rugby, as past tours have done for both coaches and players.

Hull came from behind to beat Southampton 2–1 at the KCOM Stadium, ending a six‑game league losing run and securing their first win since 20 August, though they remain in the bottom three. Southampton had taken an early lead when Charlie Austin converted a penalty in the sixth minute after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida. Hull lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first‑half injuries, bringing on Robert Snodgrass. Snodgrass revitalised his side, equalising in the 61st minute from a Sam Clucas cross and then setting up Michael Dawson to head home from his free‑kick one minute later. Scotland goalkeeper David Marshall made several vital saves, and Clucas cleared off the line in stoppage time. Manager Mike Phelan praised his players’ character and singled out Marshall and Snodgrass; Claude Puel lamented his side’s loss of concentration after their Europa League win over Inter Milan. After the international break, Hull travel to Sunderland and Southampton host Liverpool.

At around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, a collision between a motorcycle and a tractor killed the (locally resident) motorcyclist; the tractor driver was unhurt. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses, and the B1191 remains closed both ways between the B1192 (Tattershall Road) junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 (Jubilee Way) junction in Horncastle.

Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov abruptly halted an investigation into alleged abuses of power exposed by secret recordings—citing a need to “end the agony” before June’s early elections. His decision, announced in a televised address as a defense of “national interests,” drew immediate condemnation from opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and mobilized protests in Skopje, and from EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia’s EU membership prospects. The crisis began in 2015 when Zaev released tapes suggesting ministers arranged vote‑rigging, murdered to cover up scandals, and illegally wiretapped around 20,000 figures. The government denies the charges and accuses Zaev of destabilization; he insists the recordings reveal high‑level corruption, fund mismanagement, politically motivated prosecutions and even homicide cover‑ups.

After sacking Bob Bradley, Swansea have appointed coach Curtis and assistant Paul Williams as caretakers for Saturday’s match against Bournemouth while pursuing ex‑Derby boss Paul Clement as their next permanent manager. Curtis warned that dropping into an increasingly strong Championship would make an immediate return very difficult and blamed constant managerial changes since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure, a diluted “Swansea Way” and insufficient player replacements for the club’s recent struggles. He recalled Swansea’s rise from near‑bankruptcy in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011 on the back of exciting, possession‑based football and, confident his current squad can avoid relegation, uses the club’s “Jack to a King” documentary to impress upon new signings how vital top‑flight survival is for both club and community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3‑2 to Leyton Orient: Jay Simpson’s first-half brace was cancelled out by Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, but Armand Gnanduillet’s late winner sealed the Daggers’ drop and kept Orient’s play-off bid alive. Under John Still—who previously guided them from the Conference to League One—Dagenham finish with the division’s worst goal difference and a misfiring attack. Still is already targeting an immediate return from the National League, while interim Leyton Orient boss Andy Hessenthaler urges consistency following recent managerial changes.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool in February as a youth coach—his first role since retiring in November after a 19‑year playing career. Jurgen Klopp welcomed the move, noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and his need to learn the trade. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and left in 2015 for LA Galaxy after winning multiple domestic and European trophies, had been linked with MK Dons but felt it was “too soon.” He is also working toward his UEFA A coaching licence.

Morton opened the scoring when McManus netted from close range after 15 minutes, and Ross Forbes’s deflected strike soon made it 2–0. Alloa’s Kyle McAusland pulled one back before half‑time, but McManus struck again and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to secure a comfortable home win for Morton.

• Ofsted investigations in the Midlands have identified 18 unregulated “schools,” mainly in Muslim communities; three in Birmingham, found in squalid conditions, have been closed and their proprietors face investigation for running illegal schools (punishable by up to 51 weeks’ jail).  
• Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector, warned these are likely the “tip of the iceberg,” expressing grave concern over children’s safety and risk of abuse or radicalisation.  
• Current law requires any setting where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week to register as a school; some “part‑time” or “flexi” centres legally support home‑educated pupils, but others exploit home‑education rights to operate illicitly.  
• Ministers are consulting on extending regulation to places teaching more than 6–8 hours weekly; the consultation closes mid‑January.  
• The government has funded a dedicated six‑inspector team to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups, and the Education Secretary has instructed Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases (with her consent required to proceed).

Lilliard Gin operates from a converted cowshed at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, using one of the UK’s smallest production stills to create small‑batch gin. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes sources wild botanicals from the nearby Teviot Valley to capture the local “terroir.” The distillery opens ahead of proposals for the first new Scottish Borders whisky distillery since 1837. John Henderson of Born in the Borders praises its local‑sourcing ethos and synergy with the on‑site brewery. The name Lilliard honors a legendary heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor and reflects the team’s strong female leadership.

In August 2013 at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, 51‑year‑old Gary Green—having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints and registering more than twice the legal alcohol limit—reversed a tractor into Harry Whitlam, killing him. The Health and Safety Executive found that at about 09:15 on 9 August, Whitlam was walking towards a worker in a closed‑off area of the farm where his mother, Pam Whitlam (a café employee), also worked. Prosecuted under health and safety legislation because the incident occurred on private land, Green admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described Green’s conduct as “reckless” and the case as “extremely tragic.” Pam Whitlam said her family had been “changed forever” and hoped they could remember Harry for more than the day of the accident.

Luis Suárez’s appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) against FIFA’s four‑month ban for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup was only partly successful. CAS upheld the overall suspension—including nine competitive‑match bans—but overturned the prohibition on all “football‑related activities,” allowing Suárez to train, play in friendlies, attend matches and engage in promotional events. He will join Barcelona’s first‑team training this Friday and be formally presented at Camp Nou on Monday, with his competitive debut likely in El Clásico on 26 October. He remains ineligible for organized competitive fixtures until his bans conclude and must still serve eight of nine suspended international matches, though he can now appear in Uruguay’s friendlies versus Japan, South Korea and Saudi Arabia. FIFA’s original sanction was deemed “excessive” by CAS; however, players’ union FIFPro lamented that CAS did not reduce the overall ban or mandate treatment. Suárez’s legal team argued FIFA misapplied its rules, insisting the punishment was disproportionate. This latest ruling follows his previous suspensions for biting two players (2010, 2013) and an eight‑match ban plus fine for racially abusing Patrice Evra in 2011.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake‑Smith and his partner Anna won a 380 m obstacle‑style wife‑carrying race—beating Lithuania’s Vytautas Kirkliauskas (carrying his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene)—after a week’s training on a local track. The course features haystack hurdles, a steep climb and water pistols, and allows any gender combination of carrier and carried. Rich and Anna will represent Britain at the World Championships in Finland this July.

Transport Minister Stephen Hammond has reassured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that when paper tax discs are abolished in October 2014 and replaced by a monthly direct‑debit system (as announced in George Osborne’s Autumn Statement), any resulting drop in refund‑processing work will lead to changes in job roles and require retraining—but not compulsory redundancies. Instead, staff reductions will be handled by redeploying affected employees into other DVLA growth areas. Hedges welcomed these assurances, noting the benefits of direct debits and disc‑free motoring and saying the minister’s commitment will comfort concerned DVLA workers.

Hungary’s foreign minister Péter Szijjártó told Reuters the EU should not meddle in what he called “domestic issues” and that Poland has pledged to veto any attempt to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. The standoff centers on three laws: tightened asylum‑seeker controls (including housing migrants in sealed shipping containers), a higher‑education bill that could force the Central European University’s closure, and draft NGO legislation branding groups as “foreign‑backed.” Thousands of Hungarians have protested these measures. Szijjártó insisted Hungary will not roll them back, arguing they fall under national competence. Under EU rules, any move to suspend voting rights requires unanimous approval—a hurdle Poland is prepared to block. Meanwhile, Commission Vice‑President Frans Timmermans has warned that, absent reforms, Brussels may take action in the coming weeks.

Disney’s live-action Beauty and the Beast opens in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Bill Condon (Dreamgirls, Twilight) directs, with filming beginning in May at Shepperton Studios. Cast includes:  
• an as-yet-unnamed star as Mrs Potts (the teapot, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in 1991)  
• Oscar‑winner Kevin Kline as Maurice (Belle’s father)  
• Emma Watson as Belle  
• Dan Stevens as the Beast  
• Luke Evans as Gaston  
• Josh Gad as LeFou

Adrian Gill, the Sunday Times columnist famed for his fearlessly witty and often controversial writing, has died after being diagnosed last month with what he called the “full English” of cancers. Despite undergoing chemotherapy, he continued to write; his final column, on coming to terms with his illness, is due to appear in tomorrow’s paper. Martin Ivens, editor of the Sunday Times, and colleagues including Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell, John Witherow and Andrew Neil paid tribute to his incomparable wit, compassion and towering influence on British journalism.

Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill overcame dyslexia to study at Central Saint Martins and the Slade School of Fine Art, beginning his career in the 1980s with art reviews, then writing for Tatler before joining the Sunday Times in 1993. His fearless style sparked numerous controversies—from recounting shooting a baboon in Tanzania to provocative remarks about the Welsh, the Isle of Man and a TV presenter—and even got him ejected from a Gordon Ramsay restaurant.

Gill’s personal life saw two marriages: to author Cressida Connolly in 1983, and to future Home Secretary Amber Rudd in 1991, with whom he had two children, Flora and Alistair. In later years he was with Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins, Edith and Isaac; the couple became engaged shortly before his death.

Amarmandakh “Amraa” Sukhbaatar, lead singer of Mongolian band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked on‑stage in Ulan Bator by a Russian diplomatic officer who struck him with a bottle and kicked him, leaving him with serious brain injuries and in a coma for about ten days. He had been wearing a traditional Mongolian red deel embroidered with a swastika—a symbol of eternity in Mongolia long predating Nazism—and both he and his father, lawyer and bandmates denied any Nazi sympathies or “Heil Hitler” shouts. The Russian embassy called press reports “distorted” and is investigating, while Mongolian police say the suspect wasn’t detained because the victim’s injuries aren’t life‑threatening (not because of immunity). The rapper’s lawyer insists the diplomat be prosecuted under Mongolian law.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid occupied the airport’s northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday to protest its expansion plans. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security‑restricted aerodrome area and will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police said it will review airport security following the incident.

Glamorgan piled up a score largely thanks to opener Nick Selman’s second first‑class century, 101 off 144 balls (after being dropped on eight), with Aneurin Donald’s 36 the next highest. Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles exploited overcast conditions to take regular wickets, while lower‑order batsmen Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten eked out a consolation bonus point for Glamorgan. Michael Hogan led the side in Jacques Rudolph’s absence. By stumps, Gloucestershire were clinging on in fading light and the contest remained finely balanced. Selman noted the slow pitch eased after the first 25 overs and hopes to carry his form through the season; Taylor praised the “bit on offer” for bowlers, was pleased with three off‑stump strikes and relishes further red‑ball chances as Gloucestershire strive for a competitive reply.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police after online chats with Tennessee’s Hope Line Crisis Centre revealed his plan to make a false report and ambush officers on the Dee Estuary, shooting them. At Mold Crown Court on Friday he admitted two charges related to these threats, made twice late at night while drunk, and will be sentenced next week. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody; Hughes has a 2009 firearms conviction and had been on bail for other firearm charges—of which he was later cleared—when the threats were made. His lawyers maintain he never intended to kill anyone or himself.

Surrey posted 255–7, thanks largely to a 130‑run stand between Ollie Pope Davies and Ben Foakes (90), before Yorkshire’s reply was derailed by Stuart Meaker’s three wickets in nine balls. Tim Bresnan’s 68 and Matthew Waite’s 38 provided resistance, but Yorkshire were all out for 236. Surrey, missing a chance at Lord’s since 2002, now advance to the final. Skipper Gareth Batty praised the timely contributions of Davies, Foakes and his bowlers; Yorkshire captain Alex Lees lamented his top order’s failure despite strong bowling.

A 56 ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST after its onboard pump failed to handle incoming water. An RNLI lifeboat crew fitted a replacement pump and towed the vessel back to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, the 24‑year‑old Scottish middle‑distance runner who is in her final year of veterinary medicine, will miss next April’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her exams fall in May. At this summer’s World Athletics Championships she placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m. Returning to university next week, she says she’s disappointed but must prioritise her degree, though she believes she has two or three more Olympic cycles in her. Muir is aiming for the World Indoor Championships in March—potentially in Birmingham—and is “in reasonable shape.” In her most recent race, the London 5000m, she finished third in 14:52.07, a new outdoor personal best, after five races in ten days, and feels there is “a lot of potential for the future.”

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are nowhere near last season’s title‑challenging standard and must settle for top‑four (and Champions League) qualification as a realistic success under Brendan Rodgers. With Luis Suárez sold and Daniel Sturridge often injured, Rodgers has failed to replace their combined 52 goals, recruiting Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert and Fabio Borini—none of whom match the finishing, work‑rate, pressing intensity or set‑piece threat of last season’s front two. Defensively, big‑money signings Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren have yet to shore up a back line that remains as leaky as before, while goalkeeper Simon Mignolet offers shot‑stopping but little command of his area.

Looking ahead to Chelsea, Savage names a side of Mignolet; Johnson, Skrtel, Toure, Moreno; Can, Gerrard, Sterling, Coutinho, Lallana; Borini, dropping Lovren despite his fee. He stresses the need for balanced full‑back runs and a solid midfield four but still sees Chelsea as overwhelming favourites and predicts another painful Anfield defeat.

On Steven Gerrard, Savage believes the midfielder—haunted by his slip that cost the title six months ago—is far from finished. At 34, Gerrard’s challenge is both physical (maintaining mobility and recovery) and mental (overcoming doubts about his legs), yet his leadership, fitness and desire mean he remains pivotal to Liverpool’s short‑ and long‑term plans.

East Ayrshire Council plans to build a £45 million campus on Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, comprising primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre. It intends to seek the McIlvanney family’s permission to name the campus after local-born writer William McIlvanney, who began his career as an English teacher before becoming a full‑time novelist in 1975. Dubbed the “Godfather of Tartan Noir” for works such as Remedy Is None and the Laidlaw trilogy, McIlvanney was also a poet, journalist and broadcaster. He died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

On Monday a deteriorating British sea mine dating from the 1940s–50s was spotted off Gourock, prompting precautionary measures:

• Three streets near the town’s swimming pool were evacuated and residents within 500 m told to stay indoors with windows open.  
• Exclusion zones were set up on the river and a half‑mile at sea; small boats were barred, and ferry sailings from Gourock and Rothesay (Caledonian MacBrayne) were disrupted.  
• Police stressed there was no immediate danger.  
• Royal Navy diving officers, unable to determine the mine’s remaining explosives, decided to relocate it to a safer site before disposal.  
• Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345 million—£2 million less than for Rio—to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, setting medal targets of 51–85 Olympic and 115–162 Paralympic podium finishes (Britain won 67 and 147 in Rio). Funding cuts hit archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby, while cycling loses over £4 million (now £25.98 million). Badminton, despite winning men’s doubles bronze in Rio and receiving £5.74 million previously, has had all its funding withdrawn, prompting “staggered” protests from Badminton England and calls to “fight for” player ambitions. Judo—another Rio bronze sport—sees a slight increase. UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl stresses tough prioritisation to safeguard medal potential; Sports Minister Tracey Crouch backs the strategy. Meanwhile, basketball, handball and volleyball—already unfunded—claim UK Sport ignores team sports despite earlier reviews. Seven new disciplines (including baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton) are under consideration, with £9 million still to be allocated based on medal prospects.

Three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive at East Cliff in Bournemouth will be demolished by The East Cliff Project LLP to make way for a six‑storey, four‑star, 90‑room hotel and two assisted‑living blocks (nine and seven storeys, totalling 122 apartments). Despite English Heritage’s warning of “severe harm” to the designated conservation area, and objections from 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society, councillors voted 7–3 in favour, citing benefits to tourism and better housing for older people. Planning chair David Kelsey described the existing buildings as no longer functional, and noted the council received 246 letters supporting the scheme.

Private Matthew Boyd, 20, a Royal Gibraltar Regiment soldier from Carrickfergus, was beaten unconscious outside The Cellar bar in Brecon shortly after 2 a.m. on 8 May by 24‑year‑old Jake Vallely, who had been on a seven‑hour drinking binge and had boasted of being the “hardest man in Brecon.” CCTV showed Vallely punching Boyd to the ground and continuing to beat him before dragging away his motionless body and fleeing. Vallely’s friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter after the jury heard he was not present during the assault. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Detective Superintendent David Guiney described the attack as “a despicable act” that shocked the Brecon community. In a tribute, Boyd’s family remembered him as loving, loyal and full of life, lamenting a promising career cut short and praising the town’s support as its real strength.

Barnet Council’s chief executive, Andrew Travers, has left “by mutual agreement” after election‑day errors saw voters turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names weren’t on the register. An independent investigation—whose lead is still to be appointed—will report to the General Functions Committee by the end of May and will also review preparations for June’s EU Referendum. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will act as interim chief executive. The council apologised, offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents and faced criticism over the fairness of the poll. Travers, who blamed faulty registration lists, said he was proud of the borough’s growth and transformational programmes during his three-and-a-half‑year tenure.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2–1. Josh Gillies put the visitors ahead with a free‑kick before half‑time, but Sean Newton levelled for Wrexham with his own set‑piece just before the break. In the second half, Ryan Bowman headed home Craig Baxter’s cross to secure the win. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s second‑half passing and overall quality, while Wrexham’s Gary Mills lamented his team’s drop in performance after half‑time and their failure to convert chances.

The BBC’s Global AgeWatch Index 2014, published on 1 October 2014 (last updated at 19:45 BST), ranks the social and economic welfare of people aged over 60 in 96 countries. Norway tops the list, while Afghanistan ranks worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb’s planned broadband network will start with at least 600 satellites—eventually growing to over 2,000—to deliver global high‑speed internet (with every school connected). Meeting this scale demands a shift from “gold‑plated” bespoke spacecraft to high‑volume, low‑cost production: Airbus and OneWeb have opened an auto‑style assembly line in Toulouse (with two more in Florida) aiming to build three satellites per shift at under US$1 million each, using robots and a retooled supply chain. The first ten should launch by April, more in November, then dozens per Soyuz flight (32–36 at a time) to reach about 300 satellites by early 2021, 600 by 2022 and over 800 by mid‑decade. With US$1.7 billion in equity raised and loan talks ongoing, OneWeb claims a first‑mover edge amid competitors like SpaceX and Boeing. Registered in the UK’s Channel Islands and licensed by the UK Space Agency, the venture will bolster the UK’s space ecosystem. To address debris concerns, OneWeb commits to de‑orbit satellites within two years, adding hardware and a capture adapter for safe retrieval.

John Swinney, Scotland’s finance secretary, warned that the UK government’s recent spending review adds “unprecedented pressure” on Scotland’s budget, which he says will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019‑20 than in 2010‑11 (4.2% of that cut still to come, over £1 billion). He argues deficit reduction could have been achieved with smaller cuts and pledges to protect schools, hospitals, policing, tuition‑free university and a record health budget. The UK government responds that Scotland’s block grant will be almost £30 billion, rising by £390 million next year ( £750 million including underspend), and insists this deal is better than independence. Labour’s Jackie Baillie urges Swinney to move beyond “anti‑austerity posturing,” deliver a long‑term budget and offer real tax‑based alternatives to both the Conservatives and SNP.

Many people with severe disabilities cannot use standard accessible toilets because they lack space, changing benches and hoists. “Changing Places” toilets—with extra room, a bench and a hoist—are recommended (BS 8300:2009) for larger buildings but not yet compulsory, so only 893 exist in the UK despite an estimated 250,000 people needing them. Campaigners such as Lorna Fillingham have petitioned for mandatory inclusion in new shopping centres, cinemas, stadiums and other large venues and have given evidence to Parliament. Users’ families describe the indignity and stress of changing on filthy floors or in cramped cars, while pop‑up solutions and venues like Cardiff’s Millennium Stadium show the relief proper facilities bring. Architects argue that without compulsory regulations, designers ignore recommendations, and businesses cite space and cost barriers. Arsenal FC’s conversion of two standard toilets into one Changing Places facility demonstrates that, with support, existing venues can overcome design constraints and greatly improve accessibility.

A coalition of Italian consumer groups has filed an antitrust complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald’s of forcing franchisees into long‑term contracts, charging excessive rents and high fees, and thereby restricting their ability to switch to competitors—allegedly resulting in poorer consumer choice and higher prices. McDonald’s defends its model as a long‑standing, mutually beneficial “sharing of risk and reward” with franchisees. The complaint, backed by the SEIU and several European unions, urges the Commission to investigate McDonald’s alleged abuse of its dominant market position. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald’s European restaurants, which generated $9.27 billion in revenues from franchised outlets globally in 2014, and the Commission has announced it will review the submission to decide whether to launch a full investigation.

A poster reading “#prayforjosh” was erected last week by the A2 in Holywood as part of a viral campaign supporting 13‑year‑old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, County Down. Josh was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when an appendix operation at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital revealed and removed a large primary tumour and five smaller growths. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church (where Josh’s father serves on the pastoral staff) to rally prayer and support. Senior pastor Gary Beattie said the posts have been shared 948 times and viewed over 79,000 times worldwide. A mystery donor funded the billboard at Holywood playing fields, and Josh’s classmates at Bangor Grammar have since used the hashtag on Twitter. Friends, family and strangers around the globe continue to follow and support his recovery.

• The MoD will close Brecon Barracks—home to troops since 1805—as part of a wider shake‑up of its UK estate.  
• Conservative MP Chris Davies calls the decision “abhorrent,” is launching a petition, and warns it disrespects the barracks’ long history, risks local unemployment and could harm Brecon’s military tourism, though its 85 civilian and 90 military staff face no immediate job losses.  
• Nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school will remain open.  
• Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon says the reorganisation will establish a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, close Cawdor Barracks (Pembrokeshire) in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025.  
• Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports the need to restructure but warns closures will create “gnawing uncertainty” for affected communities.

The House of Lords EU Committee report warns that UK fishing communities—who voted strongly for Brexit—risk being sidelined in the wider negotiations, even though Brexit could let Britain reclaim control of its 200‑mile exclusive economic zone. Fishing accounts for just 0.5% of UK GDP and employs 12,000 people, but its dependence on shared stocks, exports (mostly to the EU) and imports for domestic consumption means continued market access is vital—and likely to require trade‑offs, such as allowing more EU‑registered vessels into UK waters in exchange for zero‑tariff sales.

The report urges retention of key elements of the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy—scientifically advised total allowable catches, quota systems and international cooperation—to avoid fragmenting UK management into four separate regimes for England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Recent EU quota deals, which boost UK plaice, haddock and prawn catches, and industry statements of optimism underscore expectations that full control over UK waters could deliver fairer shares, sustainable management and stronger coastal communities.

A government spokesperson says Brexit offers a chance to review fisheries management to secure fair quota access, sustainable stocks and a healthy marine environment while maximizing British companies’ freedom to trade in the single market.

• In June 2013, 29‑year‑old former CIA contractor Edward Snowden revealed to the Guardian that he had leaked secret NSA documents.  
• The documents show the NSA collects, on a massive scale, individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers and social‑networking information.  
• Under a court order, the NSA also obtained millions of Verizon phone‑call records (durations, locations, numbers).  
• Prism, a separate NSA programme, reportedly gives the agency “backdoor” access to servers of nine major tech firms (Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, Apple), capturing private posts, web chats and searches; all firms deny knowledge of such access.  
• NSA Director Keith Alexander and DNI James Clapper defend the programmes as vital to preventing terrorism but decline to detail how they work; some experts suggest access may be limited to named targets or court‑ordered data requests.  
• Data‑protection laws typically regulate corporate handling of customer data, not secret government surveillance; most privacy policies reserve the right to comply with legal orders.  
• President Obama and UK Foreign Secretary William Hague argue law‑abiding citizens need not worry, while Senator Feinstein says phone records are accessed only when links to terrorism are suspected.  
• Because user data often resides on US‑based or US‑jurisdiction cloud servers, the US Patriot Act and FISA Amendments give US authorities broad access to non‑American data with minimal transparency.  
• The EU has expressed concern and is seeking more details; Britain’s GCHQ involvement remains unconfirmed.  
• Privacy groups warn that Prism confirms fears of global data exposure, arguing there is no way to “opt out” of mass surveillance.  
• Snowden says he acted out of horror at pervasive surveillance, fearing a society where “everything I do and say is recorded.”

OpenAI is a non‑profit AI research venture backed by Elon Musk (Tesla/SpaceX), Peter Thiel (PayPal), Infosys and Amazon Web Services. Freed from profit pressures by a $1 billion pledge (only a small portion to be spent soon), it aims to advance digital intelligence in ways that benefit humanity as a whole. While founders stress AI’s potential for “positive human impact,” leaders such as Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned that unchecked AI could pose an existential threat—though other experts consider that risk remote. OpenAI’s stated goal is to develop AI as an extension of individual human wills, distributed as broadly and safely as possible.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, who suffered a serious brain injury in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June—walking for nearly half an hour with an assistant’s help. Although the blast initially robbed him of speech, he has fully recovered his personality and now speaks unaided. He spends 12 hours a day on gym work and rehabilitation, walks with crutches, and raises funds for military charities as patron of Pilgrim Bandits. Since his torch relay, he’s received over 5,000 Facebook friend requests (the profile limit), thousands of website hits and messages, and hundreds of torch‑invitation emails—support that his mother describes as “phenomenal” and which has “buoyed him up.” Facebook recommends he create a public page or enable subscriptions for further outreach. The London 2012 torch relay will cover 8,000 miles in 70 days with 8,000 bearers en route to the 27 July opening ceremony.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held at 15%—46.2 million people—after three years of increases; real median household income fell 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, rose 1.6% (its first annual increase since 1993), while the uninsured rate dipped to 15.7% from 16.3%; poverty had peaked at 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new contract keeping him at the club until 2019. A short‑format specialist, he holds England’s three fastest ODI centuries—most notably a 46‑ball hundred against Pakistan. Cricket director Ashley Giles hailed him as “one of the most talented cricketers,” citing his decisive role in Lancashire’s T20 Blast triumph and his positive dressing‑room influence. After an IPL stint with Mumbai Indians, Buttler returns for Friday’s T20 Blast home fixture against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham and Cornwall) lie in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting sale. Bidders registered interest by 23 January, and viewings are due in late February and March, with a final decision expected in spring. No preservation proposals have emerged. The government’s Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to test the domestic industry’s capacity. Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt supports UK recycling but hopes one ship can be repurposed as an artificial reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income, while still achieving best value for taxpayers. The Ministry of Defence will “consider all options” for the best financial return but has not disclosed bid details. Type 22 frigates were originally anti‑submarine vessels that evolved into versatile surface combatants—with anti‑surface, anti‑submarine and anti‑aircraft weapons, strong command and control facilities, and crews of around 280. Last year the carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3 million.

Since 1987 Fiji has endured chronic racial and political instability marked by four coups: in 1987, indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian‑dominated government and briefly imposed a constitution favoring indigenous supremacy; in 2000, businessman George Speight led a revolt that held the government hostage, damaging the economy—especially tourism—and Fiji’s international standing; and in 2006 a bloodless military takeover occurred. Suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 for stalling on democracy, Fiji was readmitted after pledging and holding free elections in 2014. The population—now a slight indigenous Fijian majority after Indo‑Fijian emigration—lives mostly on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu in largely segregated communities, with very small Chinese and Rotuman minorities. Economically, Fiji relies on sugar and tourism but also mines gold, silver and limestone and supports services and light manufacturing; persistent trade and budget deficits make it one of the world’s largest per‑capita aid recipients.

Syria’s Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that, despite missing the deadline to hand over its full chemical‑weapons stockpile, the government “is doing its best” to meet UN and OPCW timetables. He said two shipments en route from Damascus to Latakia came under fire—one reportedly intercepted by “terrorist groups”—and urged foreign powers to factor Syria’s wartime conditions into their expectations. Mekdad also rejected US criticism of regime barrel‑bombing in Aleppo, insisting the military targets terrorists, not civilians, despite reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights of 246 deaths (including 73 children) in five days and footage of bombs hitting the Masaken Hanano district. State media denied rebels had seized most of Aleppo’s central prison, even as opposition sources claim fighters now control the facility holding some 3,000 detainees. With roughly 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical arms to eliminate—and only 30 tonnes shipped out so far—the US and Russia have pressed Syria to meet a late‑June destruction deadline. Mekdad affirmed Damascus’s commitment to fulfil all its obligations.

The 46th Booker Prize, newly open to all authors writing in English regardless of nationality, will be awarded on Tuesday at London’s Guildhall. The six‑strong shortlist comprises:

• Madhur Jaffrey Mukherjee (The Lives of Others), 5/2 favourite: a 1967 Calcutta family drama against a backdrop of political activism  
• Howard Jacobson (J), futuristic love story in a world where the past is forbidden  
• Ali Smith (How To Be Both), two interlinked narratives—Renaissance artist and 1960s child—in reader‑determined order  
• Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), New York dentist confronts atheism and a fraudulent social‑media identity  
• Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), college‑student narrator Rosemary and her unusually arranged family (best‑selling shortlist title with over 55,000 copies sold)  
• Richard Flanagan (The Narrow Road to the Deep North), WWII love story on the Thailand–Burma Death Railway

Since the shortlist was announced on September 9, all titles enjoyed sales spikes (e.g. Mukherjee’s rose from 97 to 507 copies in a week). Pundits like David Brauner have debated the list’s strength and whether the prize should reward pure literary merit or “readability.” The judging panel, chaired by A.C. Grayling, includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven and Erica Wagner. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. Coverage of the ceremony, hosted by the Duchess of Cornwall, begins at 21:30 BST on the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

A man known only as PJS is challenging a Court of Appeal decision that lifted a media ban on naming him in England and Wales. The Supreme Court has agreed to hear whether it will grant his appeal and, in the meantime, an interim injunction preventing publication of his identity remains in force.  
Background: in January a High Court judge refused to bar The Sun on Sunday from revealing PJS’s alleged extramarital activities—“occasional sexual encounters” with a person called AB since 2009, including a single three‑way with AB’s partner CD. PJS successfully appealed that refusal, obtaining an anonymity order, but publishers then asked for it to be lifted on grounds that the story was already in the public domain in the US, Scotland and online. The Court of Appeal agreed, finding that confidentiality had “probably been lost” and that a permanent injunction was now “unlikely.”

Fosse Park, a retail estate by junction 21 of the M1 that opened in 1989, was bought in August for £345.5 million. The new owners have met Blaby District Council to resolve planning issues and are preparing upgrades to parking, traffic flow and unit façades. Council leader Ernie White hopes these changes will improve “the gateway” into the city, replacing “backs of sheds” with a better welcome. Paul Clarke of Crown Estates adds they’ll focus on easing congestion and revitalizing common areas and facilities, which he says have grown “rather tired.”

Malaysia delayed the release of Disney’s live‑action Beauty and the Beast after it emerged the film includes an “exclusively gay moment.” Although the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) has since approved the movie—with a minor edit to the gay scene—and assigned it a P13 rating, no new release date has been set. Homosexuality remains illegal in Malaysia, prompting criticism from netizens and a tourism minister who called any ban “ridiculous.” Local cinemas are offering advance‑ticket refunds. Director Bill Condon says the scene involves LeFou wrestling with romantic feelings for Gaston.

Landlords in Southampton who let homes to more than three unrelated people must pay up to £1,000 for an HMO licence or risk fines of up to £20,000. The council estimates there are around 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally and has prosecuted one company and 13 individuals. Shelter reports tenants in unlicensed HMOs often face eviction fears and poor maintenance amid a shortage of affordable housing, prompting five to six helpline calls daily.
