Mandatory HMO licensing applies nationally to three‑storey houses occupied by five or more unrelated people; in Southampton it covers two designated zones introduced in 2013 (Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling) and 2015 (Shirley, Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett).

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are seeking to avoid a second election. Martin says Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but won’t back its programme. Water charges—particularly whether to abolish them or set up a commission on Irish Water—are the main sticking point. In the election two months ago, Fine Gael won 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour 7; no party has a majority and no taoiseach has been elected.

The ferry Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on one of its car decks about 27 km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon. The blaze spread so quickly that the captain ordered a full evacuation: passengers and crew boarded lifeboats and were rescued by several ships—including the ferry Puglia—and are being returned to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people (one seriously) were airlifted to hospital, and psychologists have been dispatched to the port to offer counselling. Owned by Italy’s Atlantica di Navigazione, the Sorrento sent distress signals at 13:50 local time (11:50 GMT), and officials warn the ship may sink where it lies. The cause of the fire remains unclear.

The Electoral Commission has warned that weak links between the 381 local electoral registers and the separate online registration system have led to widespread duplicate applications—between December 2016 and the May deadline, 4.9 million registrations were submitted but the register grew by only 1.4 million, implying 30–70% were duplicates. This has imposed heavy administrative and financial burdens on electoral officials. Although no evidence yet supports widespread double voting in the June general election—which saw a record 46.8 million registered voters and a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997—the Commission takes allegations seriously and urges anyone with information to contact police. It recommends clearer online information, a verification function (as used in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland), better integration of registers, and for electors with two registrations (e.g. students or those with second homes) to choose in advance which constituency they will vote in at general elections. Labour, while recognizing the offence of voting twice, cautions against measures that would make it harder for young people to register, since the snap poll saw 2.9 million new applications and significant registration surges in student-heavy constituencies.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, a former University of Nebraska star and NFL running back (St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, San Francisco 49ers through 1999), is believed to have killed himself in prison early Wednesday. After his NFL career he faced repeated legal troubles—convictions for driving into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend—and was serving over 30 years when he was placed in solitary after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge had just ruled there was enough evidence to try him for that death. Nebraska coach Tom Osborne said Phillips was intelligent and talented but “had some anger issues and couldn’t overcome the demons in his life.”

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier and the Mercian Regiment’s 30th mascot in an unbroken line dating back to 1858, was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams at the regiment’s eight‑year anniversary in Chester. He joined in February 2014, holds his own army number, is paid for rations and takes seasonal leave on the Chatsworth Estate. During his service he’s switched on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights and met Prince William at the unveiling of a 1914 Christmas Truce memorial.

Liverpool staged a dramatic 4-3 Europa League quarter‑final win over Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, echoing their 2005 Istanbul comeback. Trailing 2-0 after nine minutes to Mkhitaryan and Aubameyang, Jurgen Klopp rallied players and fans—invoking the spirit of ’05—to erase the deficit with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho and Mamadou Sakho, before Dejan Lovren headed home in injury time. The night blended emotion, noise and colour, framed by a moving Hillsborough minute’s silence and an extended “You’ll Never Walk Alone.” Klopp’s touchline fervour and message—“We decide when it’s over”—fostered belief that overwhelmed Dortmund despite their early class. Post‑match, Klopp and opposition coach Thomas Tuchel praised the atmosphere’s power. Klopp hailed the victory as “special” and a foundation for future Anfield moments. Individual highlights included Origi’s fourth goal in three games and Coutinho’s creative spark; weaknesses persisted at left‑back and in defensive positioning. With Sevilla, Villarreal and Shakhtar Donetsk awaiting in the semi‑finals, Liverpool not only pursue the Europa League title but also a return to the Champions League. Klopp has already banned players from touching the “This Is Anfield” sign until they win silverware.

Following a Joint Ministerial Committee meeting in London, Brexit Secretary David Davis pledged to hold monthly “two‑way” meetings with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, sharing analysis and gathering input as the UK government shapes its EU‐exit strategy. He described the session as constructive despite differing views. Scottish minister Michael Russell welcomed the process but insisted the UK must clarify whether it intends to stay in the single market or customs union, arguing single‐market membership is vital for Scotland’s economy. Meanwhile, the UK government’s appeal against a High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 will go to the Supreme Court, where Scotland—through Lord Advocate James Wolffe—will seek to intervene in opposition.

A team at the University of Nottingham is conducting detailed health assessments on 13 cloned sheep—including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise and Diane) derived from the same adult ewe as Dolly—to determine whether cloned animals age or develop age‑related diseases prematurely. Dr Sandra Corr examines each sheep for signs of joint swelling, crepitus or lameness, while researchers perform regular X‑rays and full‑body fMRI scans. They are especially monitoring cardiovascular disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis, the three co‑morbidities most commonly linked with aging. This work follows concerns that “age‑memory” in adult DNA used for cloning might make clones biologically older at birth—a worry raised when the original Dolly developed osteoarthritis and died at six‑and‑a‑half. The results, due next week, will shed light on whether Dolly’s health issues were unlucky or inherent to the cloning process.

Trainer John Gosden’s unbeaten 4-7 favourite Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes by 1¾ lengths from Vintage Folly on very soft ground, giving Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori their fifth Musidora victory. Dettori praised her class and predicted she’ll improve on better ground. Instead of the Epsom Oaks, Shutter Speed will now target the French Oaks at Chantilly over a mile and a quarter, while her stablemates Enable and Coronet head to Epsom. Meanwhile, William Haggas’s Tasleet (14-1), ridden by Jim Crowley, comfortably won the Duke of York Stakes from Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden is monitoring ground conditions for his colt Cracksman ahead of Thursday’s Dante Stakes—just 16 days before the Derby—and may bypass the trial if the going remains testing.

In the run‑up to the EU referendum 10 days out, sterling has been highly erratic—initially slipping against the dollar, euro and yen, recovering mid‑afternoon, then falling again—leaving it down 0.2% at $1.4226, 0.6% at €1.2605 and 1% versus ¥151. Volatility has spiked to levels last seen in the 2008 crisis. Polls showing the Leave camp edging ahead have rattled markets: Betfair now puts Remain’s chances at 68.5% (down from 80% a week earlier), and analysts warn further tight polls will amplify sterling’s swings. Hedge funds are short‑selling, and traders say markets are on “full Brexit alert,” with sterling off more than 2% in two sessions. Asian equities tumbled (Japan –3.5%, Hong Kong –2.5%) and London’s FTSE 100 closed down 1.1% at 6,044.9 (Lloyds –4.2%). Leave figures counter that the pound is merely back to March levels, which they say benefits exporters, a view bolstered by April’s narrowing UK trade deficit driven by rising exports.

Braintree Town, currently sixth in the National League and one point shy of the play-off places, suffered a third successive defeat to Barrow—who extended their unbeaten run to nine—after conceding within five minutes of a six‑or‑seven‑hour trip. Manager Paul Cowley, while acknowledging the difficulty for his part‑time side, praised their “remarkable” progress to date and vowed to embrace and enjoy the challenges ahead.

From April 2015, responsibility for nearly all planning decisions in Northern Ireland will transfer from the civil‐service Planning Service to elected local councils. Proponents such as Michael Corr of the architecture and planning centre PLACE welcome this as a democratising “huge opportunity” for locally led development and community plans, provided politicians understand urban regeneration. Critics, recalling 1960s council‐led housing discrimination, warn that without a rigorous code of conduct and full transparency, councillors could favour certain communities or developers. Friends of the Earth’s James Orr stresses the need for clear rules on conflicts of interest and prompt disclosure of political donations—currently capped at £7,500—to guard against undue influence. A recent law leaves it to the Northern Ireland Secretary to decide when to require parties to reveal their donors.

A one‑year‑old cat named Teenie was found in Winchburgh on 14 March with two pellets in her shoulder and one through her left hind leg, which vets had to amputate. Owner Sarah Nisbett says Teenie is now relearning to hop around the house and fears for neighborhood safety after three shots were fired in a housing estate. Scottish SPCA chief superintendent Mike Flynn condemned the “callous” attack, urged anyone with information to come forward, and called on the Scottish government to introduce airgun licensing—already consulted on last year, when 87 percent of respondents opposed the proposal—to help ensure only legitimate air‑weapon owners and aid police in tracing irresponsible users.

Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool on a long‑term deal after the club triggered his release clause, making him their second‑most expensive signing and seventh of the summer, shortly after Raheem Sterling’s £49 m move to Manchester City. The 24‑year‑old Belgium international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa—having joined from Genk for £7 m in 2012—and, back from an Achilles injury that ruled him out of the 2014 World Cup, netted 15 times last season to help Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final. Manager Brendan Rodgers, keen to remedy last season’s goal drought following Luis Suarez’s departure and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, has also added Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino and recalled Divock Origi. Former Villa boss Paul Lambert and ex‑Liverpool striker John Aldridge praise Benteke’s strength, pace and finishing, believing he will thrive under the pressure and enhance Liverpool’s attack.

A recent study of 671 state and independent schools, commissioned by Tablets for Schools and led by Barbie Clarke, finds that tablets are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools (rising from about 430,000 devices in 2014 to an expected 900,000 by 2016), with 9% of schools providing one tablet per pupil and the highest adoption in academy schools. However, researchers could not link tablet use to clear academic gains, though head teachers report that tablets boost motivation—especially among disengaged pupils—and increase family involvement when taken home. Nearly half of schools not yet using tablets plan to do so soon. A separate study suggests touch‑screens help boys and poorer children learn to read. In fully‑equipped tablet schools, one quarter of secondary pupils call themselves internet “addicts,” and two‑thirds bring devices to bed. Ofcom data show 70% of 5‑ to 15‑year‑olds have home tablet access. Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School, argues tablets are more portable and user‑friendly than laptops, foster student empowerment and mirror the technology pupils use at home and will encounter in the workplace.

The Museum of Liverpool’s “Growing Up in the City” exhibition features 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s, tracing over a century of childhood in Liverpool and its changing social history. Highlights include the oldest image—a fancy‑dress portrait from 1887 of Florence, George and Gertie Rollo of Waterloo Park—and a circa‑1900 portrait of a young maid at work. Curated by Kay Jones, who selected the images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool collections, the show balances scenes of play with the realities of child labor. The exhibition runs through 25 September.

The Gulls have signed 27‑year‑old centre‑back Myles Anderson—an ex‑Aldershot, Exeter and Italy‑experienced defender who left Barrow by mutual consent—and 21‑year‑old striker Ruairi Keating, recommended by Micky Adams and formerly of Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps (pending international clearance). Manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson as the “leader‑type” he needed and described Keating as “raw but incredibly hungry.” The club sit four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six games.

Bolivia’s new child‑labor law, approved by Congress and signed by Vice‑President Álvaro García Linera in President Morales’s absence, allows 12‑year‑olds to work under contract with parental authorization. It also toughens penalties for violence against children, setting a 30‑year maximum sentence for child homicide. The reform reflects Bolivia’s status as one of South America’s poorest countries—where over 500,000 children already work in urban (shoe‑shining, food stalls) and rural (mining, agriculture) roles—and aims to help eradicate extreme poverty. While the International Labour Organisation recommends a minimum working age of 15 (or 14 in developing countries), it is reviewing whether Bolivia’s law breaches international child‑labour standards.

Rosie O’Donnell, 50, fell ill at home after experiencing sudden nausea and aches. She searched online for “women’s heart attack symptoms,” took aspirin and saw a cardiologist the next day, who placed a stent in an artery that was 99% blocked. In a blog post featuring a poem titled “my heart attack,” she revealed it was a “widow maker” and admitted she hadn’t called 911, urging women to recognize symptoms and seek emergency care. O’Donnell, known for roles in Drop Dead Diva, Will & Grace and Nip/Tuck, recently hosted The Rosie Show on OWN, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide‑Wellington, a Harrow teenager invited to a well‑run party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, was fatally stabbed in an alley off Belvedere Way/Tylers Gate at about 00:30 GMT after an earlier group of youths had been denied entry. He died an hour later. Another 16‑year‑old partygoer was also stabbed and remains in stable condition in a north London hospital. Det Chief Insp Chris Jones has appealed for anyone in the alleyway at the time to come forward. A 21‑year‑old man and two boys (15 and 16) have been arrested on suspicion of murder (the minors bailed until mid‑December), and a 14‑year‑old is held for offensive weapon possession.

Denmark overhauled its cancer‑diagnosis pathway after survival rates lagged behind Europe, especially for patients with vague or hard‑to‑pinpoint symptoms who faced long waits. A Welsh team visiting Aarhus learned that, from 30,000 cases studied, over 25% fell into this “hard‑to‑diagnose” group. Denmark’s three‑route model includes:

1. Fast‑track pathways for “alarm” symptoms, with legally mandated diagnosis within 30 days of GP referral.  
2. Diagnosis centres (since 2007) at hospitals and clinics offering rapid, comprehensive testing for cases GPs cannot immediately diagnose.  
3. “Yes‑no” centres providing same‑day simple tests or scans for patients with minor symptoms that rarely—but critically—turn out to be cancer.

This reorganisation, achieved within existing resources, has reduced diagnostic delays, prevented system overload, and driven faster improvements in survival rates. Wales’s Cancer Network believes similar cooperation between GPs and specialists could help it catch up with Europe’s best performers.

On 31 March 2014, after the UK government decided to disband the Office of Fair Trading, Powys Council won a competitive bid to take over its estate‑agent regulation role, receiving £170,000 annually. Powys will have the power to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest or non‑compliant agents. Consumer complaints will still go to local trading‑standards departments, which will prosecute or—if they identify breaches of the Estate Agents Act—refer cases to Powys. James Munro will head the new team and hopes this contract will lead to further external work opportunities for Powys.

NHS Employers has backed a Nuffield Trust review finding that, with extra training, the 1.3 million–strong NHS support workforce (for example, nurses covering hospital doctor duties and pharmacists helping GPs) could take on a wider range of tasks to ease junior doctor rota gaps and GP pressures. The report argues this shift aligns with the growing focus on long‑term condition management and notes doctors make up only about 10 percent of staff, so others must do more—provided funding is available. Author Candace Imison and NHS Employers CEO Danny Mortimer highlight benefits for patient care and staff roles, while BMA and Unison leaders caution against undermining doctor training or treating role expansion as a cheap quick fix.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT, also blocking the A36 until 14:00 GMT. The shutdown disrupted commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First said some services have since returned to normal, but full recovery may take a few hours; MD James Freeman hopes for a complete evening‐commute service and thanked the public and staff for their support.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) has estimated that the proposed £1.3 bn Swansea tidal lagoon could kill 21% of migrating salmon and 25% of sea trout each year, based on what it considers the best available evidence. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, saying NRW refused to share its methodology and calling the estimates “unrealistic and grossly misleading,” while its own computer models suggest a worst‑case mortality rate of 2% for all fish species. The project is being pitched as a pilot for larger, more cost‑effective lagoons around the UK coast. UK government ministers are reviewing a six‑month viability study of the scheme, due to be published soon. Wales’s Environment Secretary, Lesley Griffiths, has voiced strong support for the lagoon but is urging clarity from Westminster. NRW, for its part, says it has shared extensive data and methodology with TLP over the past 18 months, had its analysis independently reviewed, and remains confident in its figures and legal duty to protect the Welsh environment.

Stormont’s Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster has announced plans to establish an industry‑led agri‑food marketing body, developed by the Agri‑Food Strategy Board and modelled on Scotland Food and Drink. Northern Ireland’s agri‑food sector—spanning farming, fishing, retail and distribution—supports nearly 100,000 jobs, and the new body aims to provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing across government and private stakeholders. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the initiative as vital for export‑led growth and improved marketing coordination, but noted it may affect other organizations, including her own department, and looks forward to further discussions with the AFSB.

On Saturday afternoon, the Woodland Trust will invite volunteers to plant 40,000 native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, Derry, one of four new woods across the UK in a four‑year project to plant millions of trees commemorating those who died in WW1. Under the pledge “We will stand for those who fell,” this site honors the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland killed in the conflict. Director Patrick Cregg describes it as a hands‑on opportunity to create a woodland with carpets of poppies and wildflowers where wildlife can thrive and visitors can reflect. Saplings are provided, volunteers are asked to wear stout footwear or wellies, and limited parking is available off the Glenshane Road. The growing forest will stand as a living tribute to Ireland’s soldiers, their families and loved ones.

Hilary’s debut thriller Someone Else’s Skin – the first in a series starring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackling domestic violence and “honour crime” – won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate. Judges, including Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham, praised its “emotionally exhausting and powerful” story, “finely” and “tightly written” prose and deft atmosphere. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23‑year VI Warshawski series—credited with pioneering a strong female action‑hero detective—and for founding Sisters In Crime. Festival chair Ann Cleeves hailed a “really strong” shortlist.

Mitchell Santner, a 24‑year‑old left‑arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, broke his finger in only his second game for Worcestershire Rapids in 2016—an injury director of cricket Steve Rhodes says derailed their qualification hopes. After playing in June’s ICC Trophy in England, Santner will rejoin the Rapids next summer and aims to make up for lost time with both bat and ball. In August, Worcestershire also signed Australian paceman John Hastings as their principal overseas player for all formats in 2017.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in 2008 in Kiev when a speeding, unlit car with stolen plates struck him as he tried to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder; his wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had stepped back into a restaurant for a missing glove. At an Exeter inquest, coroner Dr Elizabeth Earland recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, citing Pring’s inebriation, overwhelming circumstantial evidence and witness accounts describing a deliberate, high‑speed (75 mph) hit‑and‑run.

His wife—19 years his junior—met him online in 2006 and married him in 2007 after a four‑day engagement. She initially claimed to be a teacher but was in fact a lap dancer and stripper. Pring’s family and close friend insist she arranged his murder to inherit his assets: within days she tried to claim his estate (including the first £200,000), sold his Range Rover, cleared his flat and transferred funds, and was later revealed to be having an affair. Ziuzina declined to attend the inquest, saying she’d already given statements to Ukrainian police. Ukrainian authorities closed then reopened a murder inquiry in 2011; it remains officially active but is not being actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, has battled illness since age three and suffered a third relapse in April. After a UK T‑cell transplant failed, he urgently needs further experimental T‑Cell Therapy at Seattle Children’s Hospital, which isn’t available in the UK. An anonymous donor has now paid for his treatment, leaving his parents “overwhelmed” and “extremely grateful.” The hospital has granted financial clearance and treatment will begin as soon as a date is set.

Apple has extended its optional two‑step verification to iCloud backups to block tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker, which were used to steal celebrities’ private photos. Once enabled, logging in on a new device requires both your password and a four‑digit code sent to a trusted phone or via Find My iPhone, and grants access only if a 14‑character recovery key—kept safely by the user—is available. ElcomSoft’s founder confirms the update prevents his software from listing devices or downloading backups and now triggers email alerts on any backup download, though he warns that losing or having the recovery key stolen could lock out—or expose—the account. Security experts urge Apple (and others) to make two‑factor authentication the default rather than optional, and Apple says it will more aggressively promote two‑factor setup, stronger passwords and greater user awareness.

Billericay Town chairman Dan Groves says the “finer points” of a proposed deal—under which 30‑year‑old Wright would buy 20% of the club and join its board—are still to be released. The Isthmian League Premier Division side sit eighth, three points shy of the play‑offs. Wright, runner‑up on I’m A Celebrity … in 2011, previously played non‑league football for Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multimillionaire Glenn Tamplin, who’s committed to investing £10,000 a week, and in March signed ex‑England defender Paul Konchesky.

Sports Direct’s owner, Mike Ashley, has been asked to give evidence by the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee—chaired by MP Iain Wright—about his company’s warehouse working practices, following a BBC investigation. A letter sent to Ashley gives him until 21 March to accept one of several proposed hearing dates; so far he has declined to agree to any. Wright’s letter notes that, in keeping with committee transparency, the session would be held publicly at Westminster, and warns that failure to attend could lead to further action, including a contempt of Parliament complaint. Sports Direct has declined the BBC’s request for comment; the company had earlier pledged to review its workers’ rights under Ashley’s oversight.

Boris Nemtsov began compiling a dossier, Putin. War, documenting Russia’s military role in Ukraine after Crimea’s 2014 annexation; after his assassination, his associate Ilya Yashin and colleagues completed it. Drawing on media reports and firsthand testimony, it argues that regular Russian army units—directed by Russian generals, not local separatists—were decisive in Donetsk and Luhansk, with volunteers paid up to $2,000–3,000 a month and overall spending of 53 billion roubles. The report names military units and shows weaponry, though verification is difficult; promised compensation to families of dead soldiers never materialized, leaving them too fearful to speak out. With only 2,000 printed copies—many publishers fear reprisal—the opposition seeks donations to expand distribution, but faces an audience divided between acceptance of “volunteers” and the view that Putin is exploiting the war to shore up his popularity. Previous Nemtsov investigations into Kremlin corruption and Sochi’s cost were acclaimed but failed to spark mass protest, and his latest dossier may meet the same fate.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), a 34‑year‑old from Wath‑upon‑Dearne, was found dead from head injuries at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A 41‑year‑old man and a 23‑year‑old woman were arrested by South Yorkshire Police in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Welsh first minister Carwyn Jones said he hadn’t seen Theresa May’s Article 50 letter before publication and wasn’t invited to help draft it, calling this exclusion of devolved administrations “unacceptable.” Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the prime minister has consulted Wales several times and explicitly mentioned it in the letter to EU Council president Donald Tusk, pledging to “consult fully” on which powers should stay at Westminster or be devolved—“with a significant increase in decision‑making power” for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Key questions remain over which powers (e.g. farming, economic aid) will transfer and whether funding will follow them. Jones fears post‑2020 funding cuts, though Labour has promised to maintain EU‑style regional aid. A forthcoming Great Repeal Bill white paper may clarify the devolved powers, which for now remain undefined.

On Friday night in Newry’s Nursery Drive and Parkhead area, two cars were damaged during what the PSNI described as an attack on officers carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the “mindless attacks” on PSNI personnel and the local community, and the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they’re doing.

Mr Charney, American Apparel’s founder and former CEO, was ousted last year amid employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. In a San Francisco court filing, the board says he won’t return and presents evidence of illicit emails to female staff and racially derogatory taunts, accusing him of repeated sexual‐harassment and anti‐discrimination policy violations. Mr Charney’s lawyer calls the board’s claims false and accuses the company of invading his privacy to extort leverage. The filing responds to Charney’s defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. Earlier this month, the company secured a restraining order barring him from making negative public statements or seeking to oust board members.

Coverage will be on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30–19:30 BST. Earlier this month in Patras, Greece beat GB 92–64, but three Greek players won’t feature at the Copper Box, giving Britain a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor—Stratford‑born and eager to play at home—says the match will help them prepare for EuroBasket 2017, with several players making their London debuts and a great atmosphere expected. This is Britain’s only home game before they travel to a four‑team tournament in Poland, their final warm‑up ahead of EuroBasket, which starts in early September in Istanbul.

Before 2007, mobile phones were used only for calls and texts. When Steve Jobs debuted the first iPhone at the Moscone Centre, it wasn’t yet available for journalists to handle—but the BBC’s technology editor secured a brief look from Apple’s marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and showcased it on the Ten O’Clock News. Critics accused the BBC of undue product hype, prompting a defense that some innovations – like Ford’s Model T in its day – deserve news coverage when they signal a step change in daily life.

In retrospect, that comparison was apt: the iPhone ushered in the smartphone era, putting powerful computers into more than two billion hands and transforming industries from photography to media. A 2007 stage photograph taken on a digital SLR contrasts sharply with a 2017 iPhone shot: the latter, though by “the same incompetent photographer,” required no post-production and could be shared instantly. Earlier cameraphones and mobile internet devices existed, but Jobs’s focus on an intuitive interface made people actually use them for more than voice and SMS.

Despite initial reservations about the launch’s hype, the author now values witnessing that pivotal moment. While companies like Amazon and Google continue to push AI‑driven innovations, it was on that sunny January morning in San Francisco that the mobile‑connected era truly began.

Tests by the RSPCA confirmed that cats around Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray had ingested a toxic substance. Seven‑month‑old Meereen, who came home shivering and foaming at the mouth, was diagnosed with antifreeze poisoning and died three days later. Four other local cats have died in recent weeks, and it remains unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, check for antifreeze leaks in their cars, and clean up any spills.

Syriza, despite having campaigned against harsh terms, is on the verge of approving new creditor‑imposed austerity—VAT hikes, pension cuts, farm‑subsidy reductions, privatisations and market liberalisation—yet Athens remains protest‑free. Meanwhile tourism is booming (Athens airport expects 25 m arrivals vs. 21 m last year). Greeks are awaiting full disclosure of the concessions Alexis Tsipras made to secure an €86 bn third bailout—a reversal driven by July’s bank closures and economic collapse (“TINA” logic). Tsipras retains popularity even as fiscal austerity continues and a credit crunch from partially closed banks threatens Christmas imports. Lasting recovery, many argue, requires creditor debt relief—ideally writing off a third to a half—and restraint from Eurozone triumphalism.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell from 1990–1999 and again in 2005–06, will make a brief return to EastEnders for Peggy Mitchell’s final episodes. Dame Barbara Windsor’s character reappeared to tell her son Phil (Steve McFadden) that her cancer has returned and will die in emotional spring scenes. Kemp said he “could not turn down” the chance to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother one last time and is looking forward to filming “classic EastEnders episodes.” Executive producer Dominic Treadwell‑Collins described Grant as an “EastEnders legend” whose homecoming will see Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their very best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24‑year‑old Alice Ruggles last October. When Northumbria Police told her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, that Alice had been killed, they immediately suspected Dhillon. At trial, it emerged he had become obsessed with her. Dr Hills later expressed guilt for reassuring Alice—against her sister Emma’s warnings—that the police would protect her and that ignoring Dhillon would deter him. Prof Ruggles admitted none of them fully grasped the danger. In Alice’s memory, her parents have launched the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking, celebrating her “vibrant personality.” Dhillon, 26, denied murder but was found guilty and given a minimum 22‑year sentence.

EDF’s board has approved the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear power project in Somerset—financed mainly by France’s EDF with one‑third from Chinese investors—and prepared to sign contracts, but the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, has paused for a fresh review. EDF CEO Vincent de Rivaz canceled a visit following the announcement, and critics warn of environmental risks, escalating costs and excessive foreign control. Industry bodies—including the Nuclear Industry Association and the EEF manufacturers—urge a swift decision to avoid energy shortfalls, higher bills and reliance on fossil fuels. Greenpeace argues Hinkley is poor value and advocates more renewables. The plant, slated to supply 7% of UK electricity and boost Franco‑British industry and employment, has already prompted EDF share issues, board resignations over financial risk, and follows a decade‑long approval timeline with a guaranteed £92.50/MWh strike price.

The Ministry of Justice has revised the online divorce application for England and Wales to include a box asking applicants to name the person their spouse allegedly committed adultery with. Although guidance makes clear there is no obligation to fill in this field, family lawyers warn that its presence will prompt most petitioners to name third parties, thereby increasing conflict, complexity, potential delays and legal costs. If named, the “co‑respondent” must be served with papers and may contest the proceedings.

In 2015, of just over 100,000 divorces granted, 12,148 cited adultery and 46,815 unreasonable behaviour. Lawyers such as Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin report that while many clients want to involve new partners, courts view this unfavourably and legal advisers often counsel against it. The MoJ emphasizes that naming a third party has always been optional and remains a relevant but non‑mandatory part of proving a marriage has irretrievably broken down.

Welsh ministers are seeking to balance environmental, economic and social goals in forestry, warning that an overemphasis on native broadleaf species and public access risks undermining the commercial timber sector. Britain is the world’s third‑largest wood importer, yet Wales’ conifer forests—established over the past 50 years and now worth over £450 million a year—have shrunk by 16,000 hectares since 2001. Half of Wales’ woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales and half by private companies. The Welsh government’s Glastir scheme and its Woodlands for Wales strategy aim to encourage new planting and create high‑quality woodlands that benefit landscapes, communities and industries. Confor, representing 200 forestry businesses, argues that bureaucracy has limited new planting to just 90 hectares last year, far below the 20,000 hectares a year needed to meet ministerial targets despite strong market demand.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at about 16:40. Emergency crews took him to Glasgow’s Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Captain Oleg Kornienko, Russia’s defence attaché in London, presented surviving World War II Arctic Convoy veterans—including 91‑year‑old Able Seaman Charles Lewis—with the Russian Ushakov Medal, awarded for courage in defending Russia or its interests. The convoys ran from Britain to northern Russia under constant threat of German U‑boats, aircraft, severe cold, storms and ice; by May 1945 they had lost 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and more than 3,000 Allied seamen. The Russian embassy describes them as a “material expression” of the wartime alliance that helped arm Soviet forces to defeat Germany on the Eastern Front. Although London initially blocked the award under its ban on foreign medals for actions more than five years old, a sustained campaign and the institution of Britain’s own Arctic Star in 2012 led the Foreign Office to make an exception. President Vladimir Putin presented the first Ushakov Medals during his 16 June 2013 visit to London.

HM Inspectorate of Probation’s report into “community payback” (40–300 hours of unpaid work for offences such as shoplifting or criminal damage) found serious delays and poor enforcement: some offenders complete only minimal hours long after sentencing (one did 16 hours in 17 months), and many who miss sessions aren’t sanctioned. Inspectors examined 100 cases, interviewed 86 offenders and made 15 recommendations, including reducing unwarranted turn‑aways, matching tasks to offenders’ circumstances and enforcing attendance.

Despite praising instances of high‑quality work and offenders gaining skills and motivation to desist, the report warns that unpaid work is too often treated merely as punishment. Chief Inspector Paul Wilson called for “urgent remedial action.” The Ministry of Justice has accepted all recommendations and says it is already acting to ensure offenders attend on time and face consequences if they do not.

A tabloid labeled comedian Russell Brand a “hypocrite” for advocating economic and political revolution on behalf of the poor while living in a spacious, luxury London home—an accusation viewers of his vlogs are well aware of. When a Channel 4 reporter quizzed him on his own rent, Brand brusquely called the questioner “a snide” and walked off. He has not responded to The Sun’s legal threats but has been tweeting criticisms under the hashtag #TheSunLogic. Brand has long acknowledged the charge, admitting his wealth and fame, insisting that true change requires both personal and systemic overhaul: sharing his own wealth alone would be “a sweet, futile gesture” unless broader inequality and ecological crises are tackled. He concedes past “daft” behavior under capitalism, accepts personal flaws, and argues that hypocrisy can be “taken care of incrementally.”

Dr. J. Craig Venter, born 1946, is a biologist‑entrepreneur whose competitive drive—shaped by Vietnam service—led him to revolutionize genomics. At the NIH in the 1980s he sped sequencing by automating machines and focusing on messenger RNA. After public funding dried up, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992, publishing the first complete genome of a free‑living microbe in 1995. In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to race the public Human Genome Project, with both publishing in 2001. Wealthy and outspoken, he’s often criticized for his private, commercial approach. In 2006 he formed the J. Craig Venter Institute and in 2010 reported creating “Synthia,” the first synthetic life form. He also cruises the world’s oceans on his yacht Sorcerer II, sequencing marine microbes in search of genes with industrial and environmental applications, believing synthetic microbes could drive a new industrial revolution and help reverse climate damage.

A School Food Trust survey of about 1,000 English parents (628 whose children eat school lunches) found that 80% of those children tried foods at school they’d never had at home, and half of parents said their children then asked for those foods at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas; aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were least popular. Trust chairman Rob Rees said school meals help broaden children’s diets, and Mumsnet co‑founder Carrie Longton noted positive peer pressure and improved meal variety and healthiness. School lunches in England now follow strict nutritional guidelines; roughly 40% of primary pupils (and slightly fewer secondary) choose them, compared with about 46% in Scotland. The online survey ran from 26 February to 5 March among parents of 4–17‑year‑olds.

Alvaro Morata, 23, is featuring for Spain at Euro 2016. A product of Real Madrid’s academy, he made his first‑team debut at 18 and scored 10 La Liga goals over four seasons before joining Juventus in 2014. His move included a buy‑back option for Real of up to €30 m. In two years at Juventus the 6 ft 3 in striker scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies, and played in back‑to‑back Champions League finals—coming on as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win and scoring in Juve’s 3‑1 loss to Barcelona in 2015. Previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, he has already netted three times for Spain in France.

30‑year‑old Wilson, after four seasons at Nottingham Forest, rejoined the Championship club from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5 million and made 51 appearances in his second spell. He’s also had earlier stints with Preston North End and Notts County and has been without a team since his release in May.

Tesco, the world’s third‑largest retailer, is selling its loss‑making US grocery chain Fresh & Easy to Los Angeles‑based private equity firm Yucaipa (led by Ron Burkle). Under the deal:

• About 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 employees and most of its 200 California, Nevada and Arizona stores will transfer to Yucaipa; the remaining 50 outlets will close.  
• Tesco will lend the new business £80 million, incur a £150 million brand‑disposal cost (partly structured as a repayable loan) and retain an option to re‑invest if Yucaipa returns the chain to profitability.  
• Tesco describes the arrangement as an “orderly and efficient exit from the US market,” ending Fresh & Easy’s losses since its 2007 launch and coming after Tesco’s first annual profit decline in 20 years.

He tells BBC Sport’s Nick Hope that, after enduring and overcoming racial abuse, he briefly considered representing France but is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. For tips on getting into martial arts, see our special guide.

A recent inventory of roughly 600 French‑Alps glaciers by Marie Gardent et al., presented at the AGU Fall Meeting, used historical maps, satellite and aerial imagery—with manual checks to correct errors from debris cover and shadows—to assess changes since the only previous survey (late 1960s/early 1970s). Key findings:

• Total glacial area shrank from 375 km² in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 340 km² by 1985–86 (despite a brief advance in the late 1970s/early 1980s), then fell further to ~275 km² in the late 2000s—a 26 % loss over 40 years.  
• Losses are uneven: southern massifs suffered most (Belledonne’s glaciers have nearly vanished; Ecrins retreat is over three times that of Mont Blanc’s), while the northern Alps—with higher elevations, more precipitation and cloud cover—retained more ice.  
• Example: La Mer de Glace declined from 31.5 km² to just over 30 km².  
• These trends mirror accelerating glacier mass losses reported elsewhere in the Alps (Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, Germany, France, Italy).

Scotland’s women’s team have won all five of their European Championship qualifiers and host fellow unbeaten side Iceland in Falkirk on Friday, a result that would all but guarantee their first major‑tournament appearance after play‑off defeats in 2013 and 2014. Bayern Munich forward Lisa Evans—one of 12 in Scotland’s 20‑player squad plying their trade abroad—stressed how devastating another near miss would be and praised the boost of a big home crowd. Iceland (FIFA no. 20) and Scotland head the group, with their two fixtures likely to decide the winner; the best six runners‑up qualify automatically, placing Scotland in a strong position for next summer’s finals in the Netherlands.  
Evans, fresh from winning the Frauen‑Bundesliga and celebrating alongside Franck Ribéry and Arjen Robben, believes the experience gained by Scots playing in top leagues enhances the national team’s competitiveness.

Stuart Campbell, the “Wings Over Scotland” blogger and former games reviewer born in Stirling and now based in Bath, was arrested in western England on Friday after a woman in her 30s from south London alleged two years of online harassment via tweets. The Metropolitan Police say they are investigating the claim; Campbell has been released on bail until mid‑September. He insists the tweets were neither threatening nor deleted, accuses the media of “innuendo” and says he will say no more on the matter.

Peta has proposed replacing Skegness’s century‑old Jolly Fisherman mascot with a more animal‑friendly fish character and the slogan “Skegness – A Happy Plaice,” arguing that the current mascot “evokes images of cruelty to animals.” The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway for 12 guineas, featured the slogan “Skegness is so bracing,” and has since become synonymous with the resort. Peta’s Dawn Carr says a new mascot would help rebrand Skegness as a progressive destination that does not celebrate animal mutilation and killing. Skegness mayor Carl Macey, however, insists the Jolly Fisherman is beloved, not seen as endorsing cruelty, and sees no need to change what already works.

Scotland overwhelmed visiting Georgia in a one‑sided Test at Murrayfield. Georgia’s scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze opened the scoring, but Scotland responded with a flurry of first‑half tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try (sin‑binned lock Kote Mikautadze), Sean Maitland and Stuart Hogg, all converted by Greig Laidlaw, to build a commanding lead while enjoying 91% possession. Early in the second half Hamish Watson powered over, and although Lobzhanidze scored again from a Georgian scrum, Scotland sealed the win with further scores: Hogg finished a counter‑attack and, late on, debutant Ali Price broke clear and linked with Rory Hughes to put Hogg in for his second. Coach Vern Cotter hailed the team’s pragmatic game management and Laidlaw’s leadership. Both sides’ full line‑ups and replacements were named.

Widnes built a 14‑6 half‑time lead over Castleford through first‑half tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge, with Cas loanee Paddy Flynn replying. Early in the second half Flynn cut the deficit to 14‑12, but Widnes pulled clear with further tries from Ah Van, two from Lloyd White and one from Joe Mellor to lead 38‑12. Castleford, despite three quick second‑half scores—Larne Patrick (fresh from signing a three‑year deal from Huddersfield), Luke Gale and Flynn’s third—could not complete the comeback, and Widnes held on. The win lifted Widnes above Wakefield into seventh in the table; Castleford remain sixth, one point ahead.

Fawzi al‑Odah, a 37‑year‑old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo since 2002 on suspicion of al‑Qaeda and Taliban links (which he denies), was released after a U.S. Periodic Review Board found he posed no “continuing significant threat.” He had challenged his detention in the Supreme Court and boarded a Kuwaiti government plane to return home, where he’ll spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation centre. His release—the first since May’s exchange of five Taliban detainees for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl—reduces Guantanamo’s population to 148. The facility opened in January 2002, and President Obama has pledged to close it.

Thousands gathered at Hyde Park Corner for the dawn service and some 400 marched to the Cenotaph for wreath‑laying, while a separate service took place at Westminster Abbey. ANZAC Day marks the 1915 Gallipoli landings—Australia and New Zealand’s first major WWI battle—and was first observed in London in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service. Today’s ceremonies—featuring veterans, their families, schoolchildren’s prayers, and the anthems of Australia, New Zealand and Britain—draw expatriates and visitors who honour the courage and sacrifice of ANZAC troops. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer reflected on the Gallipoli landings’ heroism and their enduring significance.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined St Mirren in July and could make his Championship debut against Alloa after notching nine goals for Dundee last season, albeit largely from the bench so far. He says he’s at peak fitness—maintained through U20 matches and hard training—and ready to step in whenever needed. Capped twice by Scotland in 2008 (one goal) and approaching 400 senior club appearances (including Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers), he aims to help St Mirren, currently eighth and seven points clear of the bottom, build confidence, string together wins and climb the table.

Ranjit Boparan’s private investment arm completed its takeover of Bernard Matthews on Tuesday. Unite had feared the new owners might scrap existing pension commitments, but regional officer Steve Harley secured guarantees that all current agreements will be honoured. Bernard Matthews’ final‑salary pension scheme closed in 2004, and its members now belong to an alternative scheme unaffected by the sale. Boparan’s office confirmed that pension arrangements will continue unchanged. At talks held at the Great Witchingham headquarters, Boparan representatives outlined plans to restore profitability through fresh investment, cost savings, and by using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkey.

Council leader Dave Stewart announced that Cowes ferry crossings will be free until 2 July, acknowledged a “frustrating and disappointing” launch of the new chain ferry, and ordered an auditor’s review of the project. Since its 14 May debut the vessel has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training shortfalls, and damaged cars during boarding. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth warned that nearby businesses have lost six months’ trade and asked about compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is under discussion, described the ferry as a prototype with “teething problems” (now partly fixed, including electrical faults and ramp extensions), and said seamanship issues causing groundings have been resolved.

Britain’s fishing industry—though small (0.5 % of GDP; 12,000 fishers)—was a strong driver of the Leave vote and hopes Brexit will restore full UK control over a 200‑mile zone.   
 
A recent House of Lords report cautions that, because most valuable stocks and markets are shared with or in the EU, the UK may have to grant EU boats continued access to its waters in exchange for tariff‑free trade. It recommends retaining key elements of the Common Fisheries Policy—scientific quotas, total allowable catches and international cooperation—while warning against marginalising fishing in wider Brexit talks or fragmenting management across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.   
 
Despite these risks, industry leaders point to fresh EU quota increases (plaice, haddock, prawns) as a positive sign and express optimism that, as an independent coastal state, the UK can secure fairer shares, sustainable stocks and stronger coastal communities.   
 
The government says it will seek both maximum market access and the chance to overhaul fisheries management for fair quotas, healthy stocks and a thriving marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, then 69, admitted that between April 2004 and February 2014 he took or allowed erotic images of partially dressed boys. In February at Dumfries Sheriff Court he received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register and ordered into a specialist sex‑offender programme. A subsequent General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his prolonged pattern of child‑abuse imagery offences fundamentally incompatible with teaching, removed him from the professional register and barred him from reapplying for two years.

On 2 March a fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site left firefighters working for several days, disrupted train services and prompted travel delays. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service—whose crews had inspected the Asset and Land‑run facility nine times in the past year—found the operators “broadly compliant” with fire‑safety law but raised February concerns with the Environment Agency about risks to residents, transport and the environment. The EA has since revoked the company’s environmental permit (effective 7 August, pending any appeal) and suspended its waste‑acceptance activities; the site must remove all stored waste. The fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that, despite missing Wednesday’s deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, Syria is “doing its best” to meet the timetable to destroy its roughly 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons. He said two shipments from Damascus to Latakia were twice attacked by “terrorist groups” and urged critics to consider that Syria is at war. Mekdad also rejected US Secretary of State John Kerry’s condemnation of government barrel‑bombing in Aleppo, accusing the US of “still supporting terrorist elements.” The UK‑based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports 246 people, including 73 children, killed in Aleppo over five days; activists say 14 died in Masaken Hanano alone on Thursday. The government denied rebels had seized Aleppo central prison—held by some reports to contain 3,000 detainees—even as the Observatory and rebel sources say hundreds were freed. To date only about 4 percent (30 tonnes) of Syria’s chemical stockpile has been removed. US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel and Russia have urged Damascus to speed transfers to the coast by 1 March ahead of a June destruction deadline. The OPCW, overseeing the process, says security concerns are slowing progress; Mekdad insists Syria remains committed to all UN and OPCW obligations.

England levelled the series with a crushing innings-and-330-run victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, their second‑largest win by runs in the fixture. Batting first, England made 589‑8 declared and, after bowling Pakistan out for 234, declared a second innings at 173‑1; Pakistan then managed just 198. Promoted to No. 3, Joe Root was named Man of the Match for his 254 and an unbeaten 71, plus four catches and one wicket; captain Alastair Cook also starred with 105 and 76*. Coach Trevor Bayliss and former captain Michael Vaughan hailed Root’s turnaround after early series errors, while Geoffrey Boycott praised England’s disciplined batting and bowling on a benign pitch. Only Misbah‑ul‑Haq and Asad Shafiq have reached fifty for Pakistan so far; Misbah blamed poor shot selection and low confidence but vowed his side would regroup. England, confident but cautioned by Vaughan to expect a tight contest, now turn to a tour game at Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on August 3.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is launching a review of the quality of life and care for older people in Welsh residential homes. She is gathering firsthand testimonies from residents, their families and staff to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Having witnessed both exemplary and substandard care during her travels, she will assess factors such as physical and mental health, social relationships and the care‑home environment. Her goal is to ensure decision‑makers understand residents’ daily realities and enact improvements. Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but regrets that no residential‑care expert sits on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, 39, the former Aberdeen midfielder who has been player‑manager of Arbroath since 2010, has been appointed assistant manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after “a comprehensive process,” and praised Arbroath chairman John Christison’s cooperation in allowing Sheerin to return. Sheerin, who won a Scotland Under‑21 cap in the mid‑1990s and played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds (Sweden), led Arbroath to their first national trophy—the Scottish Third Division title and promotion—in 2011 before their relegation from League One in 2013‑14.

Swansea City have sacked Bob Bradley and will be led for Saturday’s match against Bournemouth by first-team coach Curtis (a former player) and assistant manager Paul Williams, as they search for a permanent replacement—ex-Derby boss Paul Clement is their leading candidate. Bradley warned that escaping relegation will be hard and that an immediate return from the Championship is far from guaranteed despite examples like Norwich, Burnley or Newcastle. Promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after recovering from near‑bankruptcy in 2003, Swansea built a reputation for possession football but, Curtis argues, have “lost the Swansea Way” since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 exit amid frequent managerial changes and insufficient player reinforcements. He believes the current squad can still avoid the drop and uses the club’s “Jack to a King” documentary to instill in new signings the importance of preserving Swansea’s top‑flight status—for the club and its community.

J. Craig Venter is a provocative biologist‑entrepreneur who turned genome mapping into a high‑stakes private race, drawing both acclaim for speeding up the Human Genome Project and censure for sidestepping conventional open‑access science. Born in 1946, his Vietnam service spurred a lifelong sense of urgency; during his NIH tenure he acquired an automated sequencer and, by targeting RNA rather than whole DNA, achieved unprecedented gene‑sequencing speeds. In 1992 he left NIH to found The Institute for Genomic Research, published the first free‑living microbial genome in 1995, and in 1998 launched Celera Genomics’ three‑year human‑genome bid, whose 2001 results matched the public consortia. In 2006 he created the J. Craig Venter Institute, which recently reported the first synthetic organism, “Synthia,” and has been cataloguing ocean microbes via the Sorcerer II yacht expedition. Venter envisions synthetic microbes driving a new industrial revolution and helping reverse environmental damage.

The Sutton Trust’s Boston Consulting Group study warns that England’s apprenticeships are often too short and low‑quality. Of the 520,000 annual starts, fewer than 200,000 are level 3 (A‑level equivalent), only 20% of employers offer apprenticeships (vs. 51% in Germany), and just 61,000 places go to young people (vs. 570,000 in Germany, 90% at A‑level equivalent). England has 18,000 vocational qualifications (Germany has 330); since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level 3 and 75% aimed at workers over 25, with 11 young applicants per place. Sir Peter Lampl of the Sutton Trust calls the current expansion “a cruel deception” and urges a radical boost to 300,000 new starts yearly—mostly three‑year level 3 courses and some four‑year level 4—capping two‑year level 2 schemes at 10%. The Association of Colleges agrees on prioritizing level 3 but warns of the challenge in creating so many new places and argues that some well‑regarded level 2 apprenticeships should be retained. The Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships—mandating minimum one‑year durations, English and maths, and job‑linked training—and will publish further plans soon.

Storey, 37, dominated the time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland—finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska—and can claim a 17th title in Saturday’s road race. She’s aiming for further Paralympic success at Rio 2016. As Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian, she has 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) from six Games—including four golds in London 2012—and has won 21 world titles across cycling and swimming. She began in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United were expelled from the Conference Premier on 10 June after repeatedly missing payment deadlines set to clear their £148,000 football‑creditor debt (part of overall debts of around £225,000 plus £70,000 owed in PAYE). Despite a takeover by Tommy Agombar and three extensions (from 5 to 12 June), the club failed to satisfy the league’s requirements. Chester FC (reformed from Chester City) were reinstated in their place, while Hayes & Yeading remained in Conference South. An offer by the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust to buy the club for £1 and cover £220,000 of debts was not accepted. Hereford’s financial decline—exacerbated by relegation from the Football League in 2012 and dwindling average attendances (3,270 to 1,758)—culminated in winding‑up actions over unpaid wages, including by former boss Martin Foyle.

James Milner, 30 and formerly of Manchester City, has retired from England duty. He won 61 senior caps after debuting in 2009, featured in two World Cups and two European Championships (playing just three minutes at Euro 2016), and scored his only England goal in a 5–0 2014 World Cup qualifier win over Moldova. He also holds the record for most England Under‑21 appearances (46 caps since 2004). Milner described his decision as “about common sense” and wished Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters well.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness of several months; his funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow. A pioneer of the early‑music movement, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and led it worldwide for about 30 years, making over 200 recordings—including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments—and a landmark 1980 Handel’s Messiah. Trained in keyboard at Cambridge and with masters such as Gustav Leonhardt, he began his career with the Academy of Saint Martin‑in‑the‑Fields and the Early Music Consort of London, later directing the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and holding posts at Harvard, Cambridge and Cornell. Colleagues lauded his generosity, scholarly insight and commitment to letting the music “speak for itself,” noting his profound influence on generations of early‑music performers.

A boy in Northern Ireland, whose family’s anonymity is protected, was withdrawn from mainstream school in June because he wasn’t coping, and his mother gave up work to care for him. The parents applied for a place at a special school but were told in September that all schools in their Education Board area are full with no timeline for openings. The boy, who misses social interaction, remains isolated while the family waits. They have since been informed that an extra classroom assistant has been hired at a nearby special school and hope he can start there soon. His mother fears other families will face the same over‑subscription problem. The Education Authority, citing child privacy, declined to comment on the case but says it is reviewing special‑school demand and aiming to secure places close to children’s homes by 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union has launched a takeover bid for Rodney Parade tenant Newport Gwent Dragons, viewing the ground “as a rugby venue.” Newport County, who signed a 10‑year lease in 2013 and retain primary fixture rights through 2023 if they remain in the Football League, insist their contract must be honored. A Newport Rugby shareholder vote on the WRU takeover is set for 9 May. County and the on‑site squash club remain protected under existing agreements, though the WRU intends to install an artificial pitch—something barred by Football League rules. On the field, County sit two points above League Two’s relegation zone with two games left; a win this weekend and a Hartlepool defeat would secure their survival. County chairman Les Foxall warned that dropping back into the National League would be “devastating” for both fans and the city.

Last weekend Sierra Leone was declared free of Ebola after the virus killed nearly 4,000 people there over 18 months. The speaker was kidnapped at 15 by Revolutionary United Front rebels during the 1991–2002 civil war, forced to commit atrocities under drugs, branded with “RUF” and threatened with mutilation or death, and witnessed cannibalism. He escaped to Freetown, fell into petty crime, then in jail met Richard Cole of Lifeline Nehemiah, who helped him resume schooling and envision rebuilding his nation. When Ebola struck in 2014, he and his team—though not medical professionals—opened a clinic for suspected cases and carried out three key activities: educating over 10,000 people in Temne, Krio and Limba; delivering food and supplies to 11,000 households; and partnering to build a treatment unit. Overcoming fear and mistrust, they saved many lives. He now dedicates himself to investing in youth as Sierra Leone’s future. The wider epidemic caused 11,314 deaths (4,808 in Liberia; 3,955 in Sierra Leone; 2,536 in Guinea; 8 in Nigeria; plus one in the US and six in Mali).

In September the Art Fund launched a public campaign that, within a month, raised enough to save some 80,000 Wedgwood artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs from auction to cover the pottery firm’s pension debt. Administrators Begbies Traynor announced the collection will remain on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, after being gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and loaned back. Stakeholders—administrator Bob Young, descendant Alison Wedgwood and MP Tristram Hunt—praised the effort for preserving an important part of Staffordshire and Britain’s cultural heritage. The sale had been authorized in 2011 following Waterford Wedgwood plc’s 2009 collapse, the museum’s 2010 administration and a high court ruling allowing its disposal to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

Billericay Town are finalizing a deal that would see 30‑year‑old Wright—best known as the 2011 runner‑up on I’m a Celebrity…Get Me Out of Here and a former non‑league player for Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds—buy a 20% stake in the club and join the board. Currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points outside the play‑off places, Billericay were recently taken over by millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week, and in early March signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United played out a 1–1 draw. After 12 minutes Nathan Delfouneso’s chip set up Jamille Matt to open the scoring for Blackpool. Five minutes later Colchester equalised when Kurtis Guthrie bundled home from a corner. Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe made several key saves, including denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie hit the bar and Tom Aldred missed a late header from close range. In injury time Colchester were reduced to ten men when substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

Fawley Waterside plans to transform the 198 m chimney of the decommissioned Fawley oil‑fired power station (1971–2013; 2,000 MW, once powering a million homes) into the tallest visitor attraction south of London’s Shard. As the centrepiece of a £1 billion “merchant city” on the 300‑acre former power‐station site (acquired 2016), it will anchor a petal‑shaped glass structure surrounded by a marina, housing, restaurants and fast‐ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Outline planning permission is due later this year, with construction targeted to begin in 2018. Company directors say the existing chimney already rivals structures like Brighton’s i360 and Portsmouth’s Spinnaker Tower, requiring relatively little extra investment to create a spectacular landmark.

Great Britain secured two medals at the World Track Championships in Hong Kong. In the men’s scratch race, 23‑year‑old Corbin Latham powered past his rivals to claim bronze behind Poland’s Adrian Tekliński (gold) and Germany’s Lucas Liss (silver). This followed Elinor Barker’s silver in the women’s scratch. In team events, GB’s men were edged out by Italy for bronze in the pursuit, while the women’s quartet—including Barker, Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd and Ellie Dickinson—finished fifth in the heats and missed out on a medal.  

Individually, Joe Truman was eliminated in the men’s keirin semi‑final, and Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant exited the women’s sprint in the first round, losing to China’s Lin Junhong; she will still contest the 500 m time‑trial and keirin.  

Latham celebrated his “final sprint” timing, while Sir Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised his tactical positioning and explosive finish. Elinor Barker and Joanna Rowsell‑Shand highlighted the women’s team’s promise, noting their youth and potential ahead of Tokyo 2020.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return as Grant Mitchell in EastEnders for Peggy Mitchell’s final episodes. He last played Grant in 2006 (after an initial run from 1990–1999 and a return in 2005–2006) and agreed to come back when Dame Barbara’s character reappeared to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned. Producers have confirmed Peggy will die of the disease in emotional spring scenes. Kemp said reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother “felt right,” and executive producer Dominic Treadwell‑Collins called it an opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden at their very best.

Spurs suffered a heavy 2-0 defeat at Anfield as Sadio Mané struck twice in 138 seconds, prompting manager Mauricio Pochettino to lament his side’s “lack of desire” and poor start. He warned that if Chelsea beat Burnley on Sunday and go 12 points clear, Spurs’ title hopes will be in jeopardy. Second on goal difference, Tottenham have won just twice away since late September and taken only one victory in 17 top‑six away matches. Pochettino and pundit Danny Murphy both criticized their defensive frailties, tactical choices and away‑game mentality, insisting urgent improvement is needed.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governorships in Saturday’s elections—the Peoples Democratic Party’s (PDP) worst defeat since 1999 and its second loss in as many months after the presidential poll. The PDP held eight states (mostly in the south‑east) and retained oil‑rich Rivers; results in Taraba are pending and Imo was declared inconclusive. APC gains included key northern states (Katsina, Kaduna) and Lagos, relegating the once‑dominant PDP to a regional party. Yet the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria’s five oil‐producing states, raising concerns about future federal revenue under incoming president Muhammadu Buhari, who is inaugurated on 29 May. Though there were 66 violent incidents—mainly in Rivers and other southern states—the elections were calmer than in previous cycles. The PDP, battered by defections, corruption accusations and an ineffective response to the Boko Haram insurgency, must now rebuild under new leadership.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) takes place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19–22 July. This year, organisers are introducing an augmented‑reality app that lets visitors scan on‑site signs and posters to access videos, artist interviews and other online content on their phones or tablets. Headliners include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan says the feature will enhance the live experience and, by updating content before and during the event, allow people worldwide to explore festival information, buy tickets and share in its atmosphere.

Birmingham’s Park View and Nansen Primary academies, both rated “inadequate” by Ofsted, have been served termination notices on their funding agreements; Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running them. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, likewise judged inadequate, face similar warnings unless they comply with requirements—set out by Education Minister Lord Nash—to promote non‑discriminatory, broad and balanced curricula, end gender segregation and ensure equal treatment of non‑Muslims by a 4 July deadline. Ofsted published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted in the “Trojan Horse” affair, five of which—including Park View and Oldknow—were found inadequate. An anonymous head teacher described parents’ attempts to undermine her authority during an inspection and her isolation until the scandal broke. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw warned of a “culture of fear and intimidation” aimed at imposing a narrow faith‑based ideology. Parents have accused inspectors of bias and are calling for an open meeting to review the evidence behind the reports.

Vincent “Vinnie” Barker died in July 2012 from raised intracranial pressure, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. At Ipswich Crown Court, prosecutors allege 35‑year‑old optometrist Honey Rose failed to spot his swollen optic discs or refer him for further investigation—a lapse they say was so far below expected standards it amounted to gross negligence manslaughter. Rose denies the charge. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he sourced via an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014, filming their encounters and sending an explicit clip to her sister on Christmas Day 2014. He was also convicted of forcing the woman’s sister and father to view sexual images and of threatening or abusive behaviour on 25 December 2014. Denying the charges, he was placed on the sex offenders register and, as a first offender assessed to pose a moderate risk of re‑offending, had his case remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. Lady Wolffe said the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence of his conduct, while defence counsel described his remand as “a dramatic shock.”

Ireland posted 165‑5 in the first T20 at Greater Noida, thanks to Stuart Thompson’s 56, William Porterfield’s 39 and an unbeaten 41 from Gary Wilson, despite losing Paul Stirling for a duck. Afghanistan replied with 171‑4 in eight overs to spare, led by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47), with only spinner Amir Hamza (2‑23) claiming multiple wickets. Porterfield felt Ireland “fell a little short” of the 180 they had targeted and “didn’t quite execute” with the ball. The teams meet again at the same venue on Friday. Ireland also lost paceman Boyd Rankin to a back problem for the T20s; he is expected back for the five ODIs beginning 15 March.

Barcelona insists it committed no tax offence over Neymar’s 2013 transfer, saying it made a voluntary payment to cover any divergent interpretations of its fiscal obligations. The club initially reported a €57 m fee (£48.6 m)—including €34 m to the player’s parents—but, when signing-on fees, five years’ wages, agents’ fees and taxes are included, Neymar’s total cost reaches £106.8 m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation allegations and is under investigation. A Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue probing the transfer. To defend its reputation, Barça declared an additional €13,550,830.56 in tax, though it maintains its original payment was compliant. This season Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 La Liga games and three in seven Champions League matches.

On 15 September the bodies of British tourists David Miller (24) and Hannah Witheridge (23) were found on a beach in Koh Tao. Thai police have arrested two 21‑year‑old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the rape, robbery and murder; authorities deny reports they later retracted their confessions. The suspects, charged with conspiracy to murder, rape and robbery, face the death penalty if convicted. Metropolitan Police detectives flew to Thailand to review the case, have completed their work and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims’ families. The UK Foreign Office summoned Thailand’s chargé d’affaires over concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects. Post‑mortem results showed Miller died of drowning and a head injury, and Witheridge of head wounds; Thai police say DNA on Witheridge matched the suspects.

Scotland’s women’s team have won all five World Cup qualifiers so far and face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday; a victory would almost guarantee their spot in next summer’s finals in the Netherlands. Defender Lisa Evans, haunted by play‑off defeats for Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup, says failure now would be “devastating.” Iceland, ranked 20th to Scotland’s 21st, are also unbeaten after four wins and the two matches between them will likely decide the group winner. With the top six runners‑up qualifying automatically, Scotland are well placed to avoid another play‑off. Evans—one of 12 squad members plying their trade abroad (five in England, four in Sweden, two in the US, including Kim Little)—recently won the Frauen‑Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern Munich, where she trained alongside stars like Franck Ribéry and Arjen Robben. She believes the experience gained by players in top leagues is accelerating Scotland’s development and bringing fresh styles and competitiveness to the national side.

Apple has extended its optional two‑step verification to cover iCloud backups after hackers used third‑party “forensic” software (Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker) to steal celebrities’ private photos. The enhanced process requires, in addition to a password, a four‑digit code sent to a trusted device or via Find My iPhone; alternatively, users can regain access with a 14‑character recovery key. Previously, backups were unprotected, so attackers could download data despite two‑factor protection. Elcomsoft’s owner confirms the update prevents his tool from listing or downloading linked devices and adds immediate email alerts when backups begin.
