Though some warn recovery keys can be forgotten or stolen, experts argue two‑factor authentication should be enabled by default. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage 2FA and stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook emphasizing increased user awareness.

Between 23 January and polling day on 22 May, the six highest‑spending parties on the European election campaign spent a combined £9.35 million:

• Conservatives: £2,980,815 (79p per vote)  
• UKIP: £2,956,737 (68p per vote on 4,376,635 votes; overall winner)  
• Liberal Democrats: £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote; lost 11 of 12 MEPs)  
• Labour: £1,027,339 (26p per vote; runners‑up)  
• Green Party: £534,249 (43p per vote on 1,255,573 votes; finished fourth)  
• SNP: £267,372  

All except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. The ex‑Aldershot, Exeter and Italian‑league player could face Barrow on February 18. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21—recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams—arrives from spells at Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Nicholson describes Anderson as the “leader‑type” he needed and Keating as “young, raw but hungry.” The Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six games. For more transfers, see our dedicated page.

Ten‑year‑old Irish‑bred Many Clouds collapsed and died from a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage” after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. Veterinary staff treated him on track, but he was later pronounced dead. The British Horseracing Authority’s acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, noted such episodes are rare, can occur in horses with no underlying health issues, and across all sport‑horse disciplines. Many Clouds had previously suffered post‑race ataxia—overheating and “wobbling”—but had never collapsed and showed no such symptoms on Saturday. His major wins included the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup; trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the “horse of a lifetime.” Despite questions about a link to his past overheating, the report concluded his death was due to an uncommon track‑side haemorrhage.

• Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved to tears by the valedictory speeches of veteran MSPs Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond.  
• Marwick, Salmond, McNeil and former Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie are all standing down before the 5 May election.  
• In his farewell, Salmond—first minister from 2007–14—reiterated that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed additional powers under the Scotland Bill but said it fell short of referendum pledges, and joked about competing for attention with the UK budget and Cheltenham races. He closed by praising the honour of serving as an MSP and bidding “goodbye… for now.”  
• McNeil, an MSP since 1999, urged Holyrood to strengthen its committee system by learning from Westminster to ensure proper accountability, scrutiny and opposition.  
• Goldie quipped she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “huge outbursts of faux indignation.”

Disney’s live‑action Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and opens in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson stars as Belle; Dan Stevens is the Beast; Luke Evans plays Gaston; Josh Gad is LeFou; Kevin Kline portrays Belle’s father Maurice; and a major star will take on Mrs Potts, originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film.

The Crown Prosecution Service will meet Hillsborough victims’ relatives at 11:00 BST in Warrington to announce whether it will charge 23 suspects over the 1989 disaster that killed 96 Liverpool fans at an FA Cup semi‑final. Last year’s inquests ruled the deaths were unlawful. Of the 23, 15 are linked to Operation Resolve (investigating the disaster’s causes) and eight to an IPCC probe of South Yorkshire and West Midlands police conduct. Sue Hemming, head of CPS special crime and counter‑terrorism, will deliver the decisions. Campaigner Margaret Aspinall said it has been a “long, long struggle” and families seek nothing more than accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has seen “numerous incidents” of contraband—especially mobile phones and synthetic cannabis—being thrown over its walls, with a local resident reporting four such deliveries in two weeks. A former inmate claimed drones were also used, but the Ministry of Justice says there’s no evidence of that at Chelmsford and that staff are working hard to stop smuggling. New laws now allow up to two years’ imprisonment for anyone caught tossing packages into prisons, and the Justice Secretary is exploring additional measures to give jails better tools against contraband.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72‑year‑old school crossing patrol (“lollipop lady”) of 20 years and mother of three, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December and is now in residential care. At Luton Crown Court, 55‑year‑old Brian Wright of Kempston admitted striking her with his VW Golf after failing to stop at a red light but denies dangerous driving causing serious injury. He told the court he was “blinded by the setting sun,” could not recall the light’s colour and was “in total shock” after hearing the impact. Judge Michael Kay QC paused the hearing so Wright could compose himself after expressing remorse. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir has ruled herself out of next April’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final‐year veterinary medicine exams fall in May. The 24‐year‑old, who placed fourth in the 1,500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the recent World Championships (where she set an outdoor personal best of 14:52.07), returns to university immediately. She says she’s “gutted” to miss a rare chance to represent Scotland but must prioritise her degree. Looking ahead, Muir sees “potential” for the World Indoor Championships in Birmingham in March and expects to contest at least two or three more Olympic Games.

Gardaí have begun a multi‐week excavation of a three‑acre woodland site beside the R112 in Chapelizod, Dublin, in the 2000 disappearance of 22‑year‑old Trevor Deely. Deely was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. Earlier this year, six detectives reviewed the case and enhanced CCTV from the night he vanished, showing him speaking to a man in black outside his Baggot Street workplace before fetching an umbrella. That same man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road. Gardaí have not identified him and have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martín del Potro, ranked 165th after over two years out with wrist injuries, came from a set down to defeat Stan Wawrinka 3‑6, 6‑3, 7‑6 (7‑2), 6‑3 at Wimbledon. It was his first Grand Slam match since the 2014 Australian Open; he will next face Lucas Pouille or Donald Young in the same half as Andy Murray. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, said he feels “alive” again after multiple surgeries.

Also in Murray’s half, 15th seed Nick Kyrgios edged Dustin Brown 6‑7 (3‑7), 6‑1, 2‑6, 6‑4, 6‑4 after rain delays and will play Feliciano López, who rallied from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini 3‑6, 6‑7, 6‑3, 6‑3, 6‑3. The winner meets Murray or John Millman in the last 16.

Elsewhere, 10th seed Tomas Berdych beat Benjamin Becker 6‑4, 6‑1, 6‑2, and 12th seed Jo‑Wilfried Tsonga defeated Juan Monaco 6‑1, 6‑4, 6‑3.

Tunisia and Morocco both overcame CAF sanctions to enter the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers. Tunisia had been threatened with expulsion after protesting a disputed 2015 quarter‑final penalty against Equatorial Guinea; following a March 2015 apology to CAF president Issa Hayatou, their 2017 spot was confirmed. Morocco, stripped of the 2015 hosting rights over Ebola‑related safety concerns and fined $1 million, saw the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturn its participation ban and cut its fine to $50,000, allowing it into the 2017 draw. Tunisia face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A (and, if they qualify, will mark a record 13th consecutive finals), while Morocco are in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé. Both federations express optimism about their restored status.

McLaren, one of F1’s most successful teams with 182 Grand Prix wins (23.18% win rate), 12 drivers’ titles and eight constructors’ championships, is currently qualifying no higher than the fourth row and scoring only modest points. Despite fielding two world champions—including Fernando Alonso—they’ve been in a slump since 2013, when chassis design faltered even as their engine remained strong. Today the car is competitive but hampered by an underpowered Honda power unit.

Their golden era came with Honda in 1988–92 (15 wins of 16 races with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost) and again with Mika Häkkinen and Mercedes in 1998–99, the latter bringing their last constructors’ title. Highs have been offset by lows: the 2007 espionage scandal (excluded from the constructors’ standings and fined $100 million), the 2009 “lie‑gate,” and a titles drought since Lewis Hamilton’s 2008 championship.

Ron Dennis, architect of McLaren’s past dominance, returned after 2013 to restore success. He and Alonso believe the chassis is world‑class and that a maturing Honda engine will soon deliver “championships, plural,” though for now belief is their chief asset.

On 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven. Police found patrons still drinking; till receipts showed alcohol served until 04:49 BST. At Limavady Magistrates Court, license holder Colleen O’Neill (43) was charged with two counts of permitting liquor sales outside licensed hours and co‑defendant James Thomas (44) with one count. The defence admitted the bar “was not run properly” and operated into the early morning. The judge, describing O’Neill’s record as “appalling” and lamenting his inability to impose a custodial sentence, ordered the premises closed for three months and fined O’Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry scored 45 points and drilled eight 3‑pointers—surpassing his own single‑season NBA record of 272—while adding nine assists to rally the Golden State Warriors to a 116‑105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers. Klay Thompson chipped in 26 points; Portland’s LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard finished with 20 points and eight assists.  
Elsewhere, the Chicago Bulls erased a 19‑point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89‑78. Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds, Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson scored 14 apiece, and Mike Dunleavy and Derrick Rose added 12 each. Miami’s Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds, but Dwyane Wade managed just nine points as the Heat were outscored 57‑27 after intermission.

YouTube dead‑ball specialist Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool’s Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Marković at Melwood by posing as a competition‑winning fan and then unleashing a series of top‑corner free‑kicks. Van Velzen—who’s become known online for his set‑piece videos—said it was “amazing” to meet his idols, enjoyed “pretending that I wasn’t very good” before dazzling them, and even revealed Balotelli’s famous “Why Always Me?” slogan from City’s 6–1 win over United.

Women who inherit BRCA1 mutations face a lifetime breast‑cancer risk of up to 70–80% and are also prone to ovarian tumors. A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations (345 of whom underwent oophorectomy) found that removing the ovaries:

• Cut breast‑cancer mortality by 62% in BRCA1 carriers (no significant effect in BRCA2 carriers)  
• Reduced all‑cause mortality by 65%  
• Delivered an immediate protective effect lasting at least 15 years, especially in estrogen‑receptor–negative cancers  
• Yielded a 73% mortality reduction when performed within two years of diagnosis  

Angelina Jolie (a BRCA1 carrier) had a double mastectomy followed by oophorectomy, setting a high‑profile example. The authors and journal editors recommend that oophorectomy be discussed as part of initial treatment for BRCA1 carriers. Genetic testing for BRCA1/2 (and TP53, PTEN) is advised for women with significant family histories or Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry.

On Easter Sunday shortly before 10 a.m. in Durham, North Carolina, a northbound Amtrak train (No. 80, the Carolinian, running from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk Southern tracks) struck and killed a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, who were lingering on the rails. Both were pronounced dead at the scene; none of the 166 passengers aboard were injured, though one fell ill during the resulting delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. Witnesses say the Lowes may have been living in a nearby homeless camp and were seen pushing a grocery cart across the tracks, asking for assistance. After the pause, the train resumed its journey—typically a 13½‑hour trip—continuing toward its next stop, Raleigh, 25 miles to the southeast.

Carlos Toro, 66, is a former mid‑level member of the Medellín cartel who fled Colombia in the 1980s, then spent 27 years working undercover for the DEA—helping to bring down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega—in exchange for a promised U.S. citizenship that never materialized. After retiring on health grounds, his temporary visa expired on January 1, leaving him illegally in the U.S., unable to obtain a green card or collect benefits. The DEA has refused to assist him now that he’s gone public about his plight, and he fears deportation would be a death sentence. His former handler, Mike McManus, privately gave him $5,000 for surgery, but Toro remains in limbo, desperately seeking the citizenship he was promised.

ICANN is investigating Vox Populi Registry, a Canadian company behind the new “.sucks” top‑level domain, after complaints that it’s charging trademark holders and celebrities exorbitant fees—around $2,499/year—to register or remove brands like youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, yahoo.sucks and names such as Kevin Spacey’s. Celebrities including Spacey (and previously Taylor Swift) have paid to take down negative “.sucks” sites. An ICANN advisory panel of industry groups (Microsoft, Verizon, eBay, etc.) has labeled the rollout a “shakedown scheme” and urged regulators to act. ICANN has asked the U.S. FTC and Canada’s consumer affairs office to determine if Vox Populi’s practices are illegal; if so, ICANN may declare the registry in breach of contract and impose remedies. Starting September, general consumers can register “.sucks” domains for $10/year.

In June 1988, the body of a newborn boy was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating in Windmill Pit, a village pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. Unable to identify his mother, villagers paid for his burial at St Peter’s Church, marking the grave with a simple wooden cross reading “Unknown Baby Boy 1988.” 

Twenty-seven years later, as part of a routine unsolved‑case review, police exhumed his remains and extracted DNA from a leg bone. A national database search—comparing five million profiles—yielded a family match that led detectives to a woman who, when interviewed, admitted concealing her pregnancy and placing her stillborn son in the pond. No third‑party involvement or foul play was ever found. 

Infanticide charges were dropped; the mother remains on bail while prosecutors consider lesser counts (failing to register a birth, preventing a lawful burial). The boy was reinterred on June 5, 2014, with a new headstone naming him “Peter,” funded by Hana’s Gift charity, and police formally closed the case.

In November 2010, 23‑year‑old Kristopher Hicks jumped from a moving taxi in Bath—travelling at over 20 mph—after driver Michael Young, 56, suspected (without basis) that Hicks intended to dodge the fare and instead drove him almost a mile back toward the taxi rank to “teach him a lesson.” Hicks suffered catastrophic brain injuries, developed epilepsy and now requires 24‑hour care. In a High Court judgment, Mr Justice Edis found Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages (to be set at roughly 50% of the family’s claim, believed to total “hundreds of thousands” of pounds, plus £250 for false imprisonment). The judge applied a 50% reduction for Hicks’s contributory negligence in jumping from the vehicle. Both parties have permission to appeal before the final compensation amount is fixed.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night across Kansas as storms spawned at least one twister six miles northwest of Goddard (15 miles west of Wichita). That funnel moved northeast, missing Wichita but threatening nearby towns. CNN’s Chad Myers warned that “nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly.” The Storm Prediction Center also logged three sightings near Aetna, in southwestern Kansas.  

Missouri saw possible touchdown in Potosi, about 70 miles from St. Louis, with reports of wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree and roof damage captured in aerial footage. Nearby Leadington residents posted images of ominous clouds, and in Farmington a Twitter user reported “baseball‑size” hail. The National Weather Service forecasts more storms Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida meet this Saturday in New Jersey, each coming off a recent win and eyeing a title shot. Rockhold, riding three straight victories since his 2013 loss to Vitor Belfort, says he’ll be the “bull” to Machida’s “matador,” using forward pressure, wrestling, kicks and punches to exploit the Brazilian’s holes and limit his movement. He praises Machida’s long career and fighting style but insists he’ll dominate and “chase him down.” Machida, fresh from beating C.B. Dollaway in Brazil, believes his counter‑striking and technique can stop Rockhold, points to perceived weaknesses in Luke’s game, and feels fully prepared after an eight‑week camp with training partners like Glover Teixeira. Both agree the winner deserves the next middleweight title opportunity.

A light twin‑engine Aerostar aircraft missed lowering its landing gear and belly‑landed at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding along the runway as its propellers ricocheted and wings bounced. The pilot re‑engaged full throttle mid‑skid, somehow keeping the engines running despite damaged propeller tips, and climbed away. The 85‑year‑old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, then flew the plane—and his dog Buddy—100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. Gear‑up landings are most often caused by pilot error (or occasionally mechanical failure), and the FAA is investigating.

Manuel Pellegrini has admitted he’s disappointed with Yaya Touré’s underwhelming performances this season but insists he will continue to back the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the campaign. Sportsmail reports City will consider offers for the 31‑year‑old Ivorian—who has two years left on a £220,000‑a‑week contract—as part of an end‑of‑season squad overhaul. City have managed just 18 points from their last 13 Premier League games and, ahead of Sunday’s game at West Ham, will also be without captain Vincent Kompany through injury.

Goalkeeper Joe Hart said the players must take responsibility for their dip in form but reaffirmed the squad’s support for Pellegrini, describing him as “hard” and honest. Meanwhile, West Ham boss Sam Allardyce—whose side host City—has warned his left‑back Aaron Cresswell against moving to Manchester City or Chelsea, citing past cases like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, and questioned whether players are prepared to sacrifice wages for regular football.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65‑year‑old Sicilian mafioso nicknamed the “Godfather of Uxbridge,” was convicted in absentia in 1999 of Cosa Nostra membership and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment. He fled to the UK in 1995, living for two decades as “Marc Skinner,” and was arrested on a European Arrest Warrant in 2013. Although he lost his final extradition appeal in February 2015, Italian law extinguished his sentence in October 2014 once twice the penalty period had passed, and Italy has now withdrawn the warrant. His conviction remains on record, but no further UK proceedings will follow once the Crown Prosecution Service signs the consent order and a magistrate approves his discharge. Legal experts have criticized the time and expense of the case, and the Italian embassy confirmed that a CPS filing error delayed Italy’s appeal, allowing the sentence to lapse.

Paul Nicholls’s Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co‑favourites for Saturday’s Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown. He’s jointly tipped alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville in place of the injured Barry Geraghty. Mr Mole and McCoy will face six rivals, including Mick Channon’s Somersby. This contest will be McCoy’s final ride in a Grade One race, with his book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey to be finalised on Friday. Ironically, McCoy announced his retirement after Mr Mole’s victory at Newbury in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter finally viewed the graphic crime‐scene photos of her daughter Marcia—who was raped, strangled and left under a shower curtain in a Nashville garage 33 days after her 1975 disappearance—and says she now “wants revenge.” Marcia’s body showed severe head swelling, pulled‐out hair, vomit and blood, and her missing cookie money was strewn around her. The case stayed cold for 33 years: a teenage neighbor was briefly charged in 1979 but never tried. In 2006 police matched DNA from Marcia’s clothing to Jerome Sidney Barrett—then living in Memphis and later convicted of another 1975 murder—leading to Barrett’s 2009 second‐degree murder conviction and 44‐year sentence.

World number one Rory McIlroy believes it is “unthinkable” that he won’t one day win the Masters and complete golf’s career grand slam. The 25‑year‑old says his final‑round collapse at Augusta in 2011—when he squandered a four‑shot lead with an 80—proved the most important day of his career, teaching him how to handle pressure and helping him secure four majors since (2011 US Open, 2012 PGA, 2014 Open and PGA). Despite just one top‑10 in six Masters starts (T8 in 2014), he is determined not only to win his first green jacket later this month but to claim multiple titles there, joining only Sarazen, Hogan, Player, Nicklaus and Woods. McIlroy credits Augusta’s course as a “sanctuary” from off‑course distractions—most recently a broken engagement and a legal dispute—and plans to focus solely on playing his best.

Here’s a concise summary of the passage’s key points:

CNN’s weekly trending roundup included:
• A striking early‑morning photo of four rainbows over New York, taken by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis  
• China’s crackdown on hiring exotic dancers at rural funeral wakes  
• Robert Downey Jr. growing agitated during a UK TV interview  
• The viral “#KylieJennerChallenge” lip‑plumping trend (sucking on a jar)  
• 102‑year‑old Alice Barker recreating past moments with filmmakers  
• A bomb‑referencing prom‑posal banned by a school amid racism claims  
• Ewan McGregor cast as Lumière in Disney’s Beauty and the Beast  
• Johnny Depp’s nearly unrecognizable look in the Black Mass trailer  
• A pregnancy announcement inspired by The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air  
• A military dad photobombing his son’s picture

Last year, 272 children in England were hospitalised with disabilities caused by foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), official health data show, though experts warn many more go undiagnosed. World Health Organization research suggests at least 1% of UK babies—about 7,500 annually—suffer learning, behavioural or physical problems from prenatal alcohol exposure. Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome calls FAS “an enormous problem” that is irreversible and under‑diagnosed. Among those affected is 15‑year‑old Niamh Brown, who was diagnosed at age five and will never live independently; her adoptive parents founded the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust in 2007 to support others. FAS can also cause liver, kidney and heart damage, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Current UK guidelines advise pregnant women to limit alcohol to two units twice a week, but campaigners urge total abstinence.

A 31‑year‑old ex‑juvenile offender, Shaun Andrew McKerry, burst into the Shildon Post Office in County Durham on March 15 waving an axe and demanding cash. Shopkeeper Sab Dhillon rugby‑tackled him to the floor as shelves collapsed, and Dhillon’s wife Sam twice struck McKerry with a baseball bat, forcing him to drop the weapon. Police arrived minutes later and arrested him. At Durham Crown Court he pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years’ imprisonment. McKerry, from Coundon near Bishop Auckland, began shoplifting at 12 and by 15 had been arrested 80 times, earning nicknames like “boomerang boy” or “homing pigeon boy” for repeatedly returning to crime. His youthful offences included aggravated vehicle‑taking, sending indecent letters, burglary and once stealing 22 charity boxes while disguised as a woman.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31) and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged in Canada with group sexual assault causing bodily harm, alleged to have occurred on April 10 after an alcohol‑fuelled party at the Shearwater naval base near Halifax. In Dartmouth provincial court they were granted bail (over £2,000 each), surrendered their passports, forbidden contact with the victim and six witnesses, barred from leaving Nova Scotia and ordered to live on Halifax’s Stadacona naval base, where they will continue drawing Royal Navy pay. They must remain employed by the Navy and return to court on May 27. The British high commission and Canadian military police are assisting the ongoing forensic investigation; convictions carry up to 14 years’ imprisonment.

Valerie Jackson’s four‑year‑old son RJ has Netherton’s syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disorder (fewer than 70 known cases worldwide) that makes his skin red, scaly, cracked and prone to infection. Since infancy, RJ has been bathed sparingly and slathered in creams and Vaseline every few hours to soothe his painful symptoms. Despite their careful care, the Jacksons face constant ignorance and cruelty—bullies in the street, denial of entry to play centres and even a stranger’s child‑abuse report that prompted armed police to surround them before apologizing. Valerie discovered the diagnosis through an international Facebook support group and, with her husband Reginald, continues daily symptom management. Though there’s no cure, symptoms often improve with age, and Valerie hopes greater awareness will end the stigma and allow RJ to grow up accepted and understood.

Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” campaign—featuring bikini model Renee Somerfield on posters around the London Underground—sparked widespread criticism for promoting an unrealistic female ideal. A Change.org petition amassed over 50,000 signatures, the Advertising Standards Authority logged 216 complaints, and many ads were defaced. Transport for London confirmed the posters would be removed at the end of their paid three‑week run and said customer feedback would guide future campaigns. A protest in Hyde Park on May 2 is planned, and the ASA is still assessing the complaints. Protein World defended the unretouched images on social media—at times with abrasive responses—and revealed it has faced bomb and violent threats. Good Morning Britain hosts described the adverts as “anxiety‑inducing,” but the company’s global marketing head labeled the campaign “fantastic” and says its advertising approach won’t change, even as UK protein‑powder sales surge.

Rail operators have announced fare increases of up to 87 per cent, despite both main parties pledging a real‑terms freeze after the election. Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western asking it to “urgently review” its planned jump in off‑peak returns between Charlbury (Oxfordshire) and London—from £33.30 to £62.40. FGW says the rise simply aligns this route with its other services and is offering advance singles that could cut the return to £20. Other hikes include a London Midland off‑peak first‑class single from Crewe to Northampton (£30→£37), a Virgin anytime return Stafford–Liverpool (£26.50→£33) and a Virgin first‑class day return Manchester–Stoke (£29→£35.30). Virgin insists most increases apply to its “Virgin‑only” fares and that its overall west‑coast rise is just 1.65 per cent, below the industry average. Industry data show hundreds of anytime and off‑peak returns jumped by around 40 per cent in January, prompting passenger anger over broken fare‑freeze promises.

John Young, 66, a retired HGV driver and ex‑Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers soldier, was blinded in his left eye when vandals hurled a brick at him after smashing the window of his Oldham home on April 18. He and his new wife Elaine, 54, had been writing wedding thank‑you cards—just three weeks after their marriage—when stones first struck their front‐room window; Young opened the door to confront the attackers and was hit. Despite emergency surgery, his sight could not be saved. Greater Manchester Police, who say there’s no known motive and that it may have been random “messing around,” are investigating and urging anyone with information to call 101. Shaken and feeling unsafe, the couple plan to relocate to Southport.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25 and a former England Under‑19 international, has signed a one‑year contract extension through the end of the 2016 season after making a successful comeback from leg injuries suffered in a road accident last April that killed his father. Following ankle surgery, he returned to action on Derbyshire’s Abu Dhabi pre‑season tour and will be available for the start of the upcoming campaign. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton’s resilience, hard work and good form, saying the new deal should give him the confidence to excel this summer.

Five‑year‑old Harley Renshaw has been declared cancer‑free after a year‑long battle with aggressive, metastatic neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs and bones. His treatment included 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumor, a stem‑cell transplant, and radiotherapy—during which he famously decorated his immobilization mask as a Ninja Turtle to bolster his courage. Harley’s story attracted global attention, earning him Ninja Turtle gifts from Nickelodeon, a Cancer Research UK “Little Star” award, and a role as the face of its Kids & Teens campaign. His parents, Oliver and Stacey, say he’s back to running around and they hope he’ll soon return to school full time; he will continue to undergo regular check‑ups. Neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer of nerve‑forming cells—fewer than 100 UK cases per year—that most often arises in the adrenal glands or along the spinal cord and is treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and, in some cases, antibody therapies.

Tim Sherwood, impressed by 19‑year‑old Jack Grealish’s FA Cup semi‑final display for Aston Villa, insists Grealish should focus on establishing himself in Villa’s first team rather than rushing to choose between England and the Republic of Ireland. Sherwood says the international decision is entirely up to Grealish—much like his past advice to Nabil Bentaleb—and that he should wait until the season’s end after gaining more club experience. Grealish’s father, Kevin, agrees, emphasizing that maintaining his club form must come first, even though Grealish has already featured for Ireland’s youth sides.

Private‑jet landing fees vary widely, revealing some surprisingly expensive hubs used by the rich and famous. Private‑jet travel is booming—2.5 million US flights and 705,000 in Europe in 2013—and the US market alone is worth $16.7 trillion. Peak weekends coincide with major events like the Super Bowl (flights from New York to Glendale: ~$38 000–$54 000 round‑trip) and the Monaco Grand Prix (London–Cannes/Nice: ~£8 800 one‑way).  

“The Richest” lists the top ten most expensive landing fees for a 767‑400 private configuration:  
1. Haneda (Tokyo): £4 559 ($6 850)  
2. Narita (Tokyo): £3 728 ($5 600)  
3. Kansai (Osaka): £3 594 ($5 400)  
4. Toronto Pearson: £3 461 ($5 200)  
5. Darwin: £3 059 ($4 600)  
6. Bristol: £2 929 ($4 400)  
7. Chūbu Centrair (Nagoya): £2 863 ($4 300)  
8. Dublin: £2 729 ($4 100)  
9. LaGuardia (New York): £2 630 ($3 950)  
10. Salzburg: £2 530 ($3 800)  

Notable points: three Japanese airports top the list; Bristol is the only UK entry and LaGuardia the sole US airport; Salzburg and Darwin are unexpected high‑fee hubs. Popular private routes include Los Angeles–Las Vegas (~£2 890) and Milan–Rome (~$5 880 one‑way).

Katie Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort in Clackamas County, Oregon, takes her Labrador Cooper and smaller pup Daisy on weekly outings for creamy treats. In a viral video watched over seven million times, Daisy licks her McDonald’s ice cream cone daintily while Cooper gobbles his in one bite. Viewers have called the scene “cute” and “hilarious,” though some criticized feeding dogs ice cream. Gallegos—an experienced animal lover—insists occasional treats are harmless, noting her late 19‑year‑old dog Sammy enjoyed weekly ice creams. The pair also enjoyed a “pup‑uccino” (whipped cream only) at Starbucks, again with Cooper downing it instantly.

Gary Locke, formerly an assistant at Kilmarnock and ex‑Hearts boss, has been appointed the club’s permanent manager on a three‑year contract. He took over as interim boss in early February after Allan Johnston’s departure, has since lost only once in seven games at Rugby Park, and will address the media at a Friday press conference.

Florida mother Jessica Kemp says Seminole County elementary threatened to suspend her five‑year‑old autistic son, Logan, because the dōTERRA essential oils (lavender, chamomile and sandalwood) she applies to keep him calm and focused smell distracting to other students. After a teacher’s aide complained and the school board labeled the oils “a problem,” Kemp received a warning letter but insists the natural treatment benefits her son. The Lake County district later confirmed it won’t suspend Logan, classifying the issue as health‑related; dōTERRA has been contacted for comment.

On Wednesday at 3 PM, a blaze tore through the Sandpiper complex, a beach‑side holiday apartment building in Westhampton Beach, destroying all 90 condos and eventually causing the structure to collapse. Smoke—visible three miles away—poured toward the ocean and was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews, using cranes, were unable to enter the burning building.  

The cause remains under investigation, with fire officials probing claims it began near a parked car. Residents and owners—who occupy the complex between May and November—were left distraught; building manager Rob Taber “lost everything.” Westhampton Fire Chief Ross Donneson noted that offshore winds helped maintain clear visibility for firefighting efforts.

Queen Elizabeth II, approaching her 89th birthday, was recently seen enjoying a spring ride through Windsor Great Park on her black fell pony Carltonlima Emma, accompanied by a groom on another pony. True to form, she declined a riding helmet in favor of one of her silk scarves—she has never worn helmets, reportedly to preserve her hair. A lifelong equestrienne, she first mounted a shetland pony named Peggy at age four and over the decades has kept mounts such as Betsy, Surprise and Burmese. Though a chronic knee injury has curtailed her riding and ended her horseback role at Trooping the Colour, she remains a familiar sight at her Windsor stables and now shares her horses and ponies—including those bred at her Hampton Court and Balmoral studs—with her grandchildren, notably Lady Louise Windsor and James, Viscount Severn.

The fell pony itself is one of the oldest surviving equine breeds, native to the Cumbrian moors since the Neolithic. Docile, hardy and thick‑set, most stand 13–14 hands high and come in black, grey or bay. Valued by the Iron Age Carvetii, developed further by the Romans, and used for pack work by Vikings and Normans, fell ponies later hauled iron ore and coal during Britain’s industrial era. After a stint in trotting races, they became popular family riding ponies in the 1950s. Today they remain prized mounts, and the Queen continues to breed them at Hampton Court.

A noise dispute in North Brisbane ended in tragedy when 28‑year‑old warehouse worker Phillip Pama allegedly knocked out his neighbour, 55‑year‑old Leon Yeaman, with a single punch during an argument over loud music. Yeaman died at the scene; Pama has been charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail—surrendering his passport, observing a 6 pm–2 am curfew and reporting to police twice weekly—with the case returning to court on May 18. Pama’s lawyer says he “threw the punch blindly” after being pushed, and neighbours recall Yeaman as a generous but frequently drunken and noisy pensioner.

Yulia Simonova, a 52‑year‑old music teacher in Shatura, Russia, plotted to torture and murder her 15‑year‑old pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their year‑long affair. She offered 100,000 rubles (about £1,400) to a “hitman,” instructing him to break the boy’s arms and legs, damage his kidneys, let him bleed out slowly, then “finish” him. An undercover officer posed as the killer, secretly filmed her detailed orders and accepted an expense payment, and then arrested her in her car. Simonova now faces attempted murder charges carrying up to 15 years in prison; Vanya says he hopes “they throw away the key.”

Chelsea manager José Mourinho, 52, says he prays to God every day—only about personal matters, never about football—and visits church mainly when he’s in Portugal. He strives to keep his family life separate from his high‑pressure job, sees himself as a “good family person” and World Food Programme hunger‑ambassador, and acknowledges the competitive, emotional demands of management (and occasional mistakes). Chelsea top the league, and earlier this season Mourinho was fined £25,000 for alleging a media “campaign” against his side.

On the April 1 edition of The Price Is Right, 91‑year‑old former host Bob Barker—who led the show for 35 years before retiring in 2007—returned for the first time in eight years. He kicked off the program by emceeing the opening “Lucky Seven” game, then passed the reins back to current host Drew Carey, looking as spry and adept as ever.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington, D.C., at 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave; court records show his arraignment was scheduled for Friday afternoon and list no attorney for him. Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch at the State Department. His arrest follows a separate misconduct probe into a high‑ranking supervisor and adds to recent scrutiny by the Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general, which is also investigating a March 4 incident in which two senior agents drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

Atif Saeed, a 38‑year‑old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at the city’s safari park by leaving his car and crawling to within ten feet of a hungry male lion. Lying on the ground and armed only with a camera, he fired off a few shots to capture the lion’s character. The shutter noise alerted the animal, which leapt toward him, forcing Saeed to scramble back into his car. He later admitted it was a “pretty close encounter” he wouldn’t dare repeat.

New York police have released images of a distinctive tattoo—a heart topped with a rose and a ribbon bearing the name “Monique”—found on the right leg of an unnamed woman believed to be 25–45 years old. She was discovered unconscious and without ID on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn’s Gravesend section, and was pronounced dead at the scene. Investigators are awaiting the medical examiner’s report on her cause of death. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800‑577‑TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, unable to afford traditional property after returning from the UK in 2009, bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent a year and a half converting its steel frame into a two‑bedroom, wood‑lined home. Powered almost entirely by solar panels (their first power bill was $25) with gas for the stove and hot water and spring water for plumbing, the $25,000 build includes a wood‑fired stove, stained‑glass windows and a loft spare room. Now parked on their lot in Nelson amid cypress trees and a brook, the off‑grid home lets them live nearly self‑sufficiently—and they plan to build another one day.

Researchers led by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern tracked 352 kindergarteners in a Midwestern suburban district over an academic year and found that those who shared iPads in class scored about 30 points higher on early literacy tests than peers with individual devices or none. Blackwell attributes the improvement to collaborative learning around the tablets rather than the devices themselves. The study—coming after the National Association of Head Teachers’ general secretary voiced doubts about tech in non‑IT lessons—recommends schools rethink tablet use in early grades. Findings will be presented at the International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, has learned to walk and forage on its front trotters, wobbling but always regaining its balance. A video on People’s Daily Online shows it mingling with its four‑legged littermates—one of which even tries to mimic its stance—and has turned the animal, nicknamed “Super Pig,” into an internet sensation that draws curious villagers. Owned by farmer Ms Duan, the two‑legged piglet joins other Chinese animal stars—such as a Liuzhou Zoo rabbit that hops on its front paws—in captivating thousands of admirers.

During Sunday’s inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana in Avondale, Francesco Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25 for tires and fuel and struck Dayle Coyne Racing’s front‑outside tire changer, Todd Phillips. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, received stitches for a leg cut, and was released. Rain‑soaked conditions had caused traction problems for many cars. Dracone did not finish and was classified 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, has been arrested in Rio de Janeiro after security‑camera footage showed him dragging his new wife, 29‑year‑old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), into their apartment garden, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her repeatedly and then shooting her in the face five times at point‑blank range. Neighbors say the couple, married just four days, argued loudly as he called her a “slut” and vowed she’d be better off dead. After the killing, Severiano stole a neighbor’s car but crashed it and was captured by police, who found four handguns, a shotgun and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He confessed that jealousy over other men looking at his wife drove him to commit the brutal murder and now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, 41, journalist and author of the best‑selling “I Quit Sugar,” has shared that her severe anxiety—exacerbated by stress, thyroid disease and family distance—once drove her to consider suicide. In a Women’s Weekly Australia interview she described feeling isolated, lacking life’s “guide book,” and unable to see a way forward. Having recently found some peace, Wilson argues that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and calls anxiety the “new depression,” noting one in three Australian women will experience it. She urges greater recognition of this link and provides help‑line contacts: Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) and Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a 23‑year‑old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant in November 2014, was charged with second‑degree assault after she struck her boyfriend’s former girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar upon finding her shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom. Scheduled for trial this week in Multnomah County Circuit Court, the charge was dropped when prosecutors deemed Curtin’s actions “completely justified in her outrage” under Oregon’s law permitting force against an intruder who refuses to leave. Curtin gave birth in January and now lives with her parents. Her defense attorney said the ex‑girlfriend had harassed and threatened Curtin for years, while the ex and Curtin’s boyfriend—who struggled with heroin—have since reconciled and share a five‑year‑old child. A conviction would have carried a nearly six‑year mandatory prison sentence.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed making a disgusted face, chomping on a broccoli spear her owner had hidden among her treats, and then spitting it out. She lives with two children—who hopefully won’t imitate her dislike of greens—and, in other videos, is shown enjoying sleep and time with her human family.

HSBC has apologised after a link on its official website—originally pointing to its Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was discontinued in 2011—began directing visitors to a pornographic site. The awards’ domain registration lapsed and was taken over by the adult site. Upon discovering the error, HSBC removed the hyperlink, issued a public statement on April 20 denying any association with the external site, apologised for the inconvenience, and affirmed that its own internet banking services remain secure.

A 13‑year‑old Maryland boy named Marcus and his nine‑year‑old sister Aaliyah were trapped on the second floor of their Clinton home after a fire broke out downstairs early Sunday. Smelling smoke, Marcus called 911 just before 7 a.m., stayed calm through the 11‑minute call, reassured Aaliyah when she panicked, and gave firefighters clear directions—“go up the steps right in the back hallway… it’s a black door to the right.” Prince George’s County crews reached them by breaking a window. Lieutenant Kenny Ward handed Marcus out first and then gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both children were treated at Children’s Hospital for non‑life‑threatening injuries. Their mother, older brother and stepfather escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital. Assistant Fire Chief Alan Doubleday called the rescue “a heroic effort.”

Stunning photos from Jervis Bay on New South Wales’s south coast show the beach aglow with brilliant blue light as millions of plankton emit a neon fluorescence. Photographer Andy Hutchinson called it a “beautiful supernatural scene.” A similar bioluminescent display occurred at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014. According to UNSW oceanographer Iain Suthers, the effect comes from Noctiluca scintillans—a single‑celled, carnivorous phytoplankton that thrives in spring and autumn and lights up naturally (about 90% of the time) as a defense mechanism.

New genetic tests—most notably Endopredict—analyze tumour markers after surgery to gauge breast cancer aggressiveness and recurrence risk, with results delivered in days. For some women, a low‑risk score (as little as 5% chance of return) matches or exceeds the benefit of chemotherapy, allowing them to forgo its harsh side effects. Currently, most patients still receive routine chemo post‑tumor removal, but specialists argue that tests (about £2,500 privately, and hoped to be NHS‑funded) can reduce unnecessary treatment and save overall costs. Surgeons Hemant Singhal and Kefah Mokbel praise the tests for enabling informed decisions. In one case, patient Becca Cornford avoided chemotherapy after Endopredict showed her ten‑year recurrence risk was just 5%, opting instead for regular monitoring.

More than 25 Royal Navy sailors have been airlifted off ships in nine years because they became pregnant at sea—HMS Ocean alone accounted for five medevacs, and at least one case came from the decommissioned HMS Illustrious. Freedom‑of‑information data show 18 other vessels (including HMS Dragon, Enterprise and Richmond) also carried out emergency pregnancy evacuations. A Ministry of Defence “no touching” rule at sea implies most pregnancies occur before deployment or during leave. 

This follows the high‑profile return of Commander Sarah West from HMS Portland amid a conduct inquiry into her alleged relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990 (9 percent of personnel in 2014), and in 2013 the first female submariners joined the fleet. 

Separately, between 2006 and 2013, 99 British servicewomen were flown home from Afghanistan for pregnancy (16 in 2013, 18 in 2011) and another 102 from Iraq, in line with rules barring pregnant personnel from war zones. Most pregnancies are conceived before deployment, though a few occur on tour, and the MoD returns pregnant service members “at the first convenient opportunity.”

A small four‑propeller drone was found Wednesday on the roof of Japan’s prime ministerial residence in Tokyo, carrying a camera, smoke flares and a plastic bottle with trace, non‑harmful amounts of cesium—a radioactive byproduct of nuclear reactors. Its discovery coincided with a court’s approval to restart two Sendai nuclear plant reactors, part of Shinzo Abe’s unpopular nuclear energy push since Fukushima. Authorities fear the incident signals a new terrorism threat involving drones, especially ahead of the Olympics and G7 summit, and plan to review drone‑operation rules. Currently, Japan restricts drones near airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Abe was in Indonesia at the time.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84‑year‑old mother—who suffers from Alzheimer’s—to work on the back of his motorbike every day. After his father’s death, and with his wife working elsewhere and his son at school, he feared leaving her alone because she used to wander off collecting firewood. Each morning he wakes her at 5 am, ties a sash around them both, and makes a slow, four‑kilometer, one‑hour ride so she feels safe; at work the bank has provided her a room which he regularly checks. He explains he cares for her now in return for her lifelong devotion: “I was an apple in my mum’s eye, and now she’s my apple.”

A large University of Washington study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, used 2005–2012 county‑level data from 3.7 million adults in the CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System to track U.S. drinking patterns. It found a 17.2 percent rise in heavy drinking—defined by the CDC as over one drink per day for women and two for men—and a sharp increase in binge drinking (four-plus drinks per occasion for women, five-plus for men). Much of the increase was driven by women: nationwide, women’s binge‑drinking rates climbed over seven times faster than men’s; in Santa Clara County, CA, women’s binge rates rose nearly 36 percent versus 23 percent for men. By 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent binge drinkers. County extremes included a 6 percent binge rate in Madison County, ID, versus 36 percent in Menominee County, WI; heavy‑drinking rates ranged from 2 percent in Hancock County, TN, to 22 percent in Esmeralda County, NV. Alcohol contributed to about 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and cost over $220 billion annually. Experts attribute rising consumption to changing social norms (especially for women), greater affluence among young professionals, cheaper alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened sales restrictions.

UN and WHO experts warn that caesarean sections are being overused in England—now accounting for just over 25% of births, more than double the early 1990s rate—and should be limited to medically necessary cases. They recommend an ideal C‑section rate of 10–15% because unnecessary procedures carry risks of infection (affecting up to 1 in 10), serious complications, long‑term health problems, disability or death, and divert funds from other patients. A planned C‑section costs the NHS £2,369 versus £1,665 for a natural birth. This warning conflicts with current NICE guidelines, which allow women to request C‑sections for non‑medical reasons such as severe fear of childbirth (tokophobia), previous complicated deliveries, age over 40 or conditions like asthma, diabetes or depression.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into and living inside a Martha’s Vineyard summer home in Edgartown for at least a week. Owner Mark Conklin, who discovered her in his $800,000 property’s living room, confronted her as she claimed ownership; she then fled in a gray Nissan pickup but was detained hours later trying to re‑enter. Filkins faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and is due in court on May 14. Police say she sold items from the home—deck chairs, a Weber grill, side tables, lamps, framed posters, cookware, linens and a painting—at a yard sale, and are asking anyone who received or bought these items to return them or contact the Edgartown Police Department at 508‑627‑4343 for restitution assistance.

Bella Crooke of Melbourne lost her iPhone at a friend’s birthday party on Saturday night, and it was handed in unlocked to Albury Police Station on the NSW–Victoria border the next morning. While waiting for her to claim it, officers used the phone to post a series of humorous selfies, puns and status updates on Bella’s Facebook page—jokes about “cells,” “charging,” “good behaviour” and “bail”—to entice her to come in. By the time Bella arrived around 1 pm, the posts had gone viral among her friends, and officers recognized her from the photos, allowing her to retrieve the phone without giving any ID. Amused by the stunt, Bella has since set a password and praised the “boys in blue” for their creativity.

A five‑day‑old hippo calf was killed during a fight between two male hippos in iSimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa. As the rivals tussled, a sub‑adult male grabbed the calf, flung it into the air and dragged it along the water’s surface. The calf’s mother—who had stayed with her herd and chased off other young hippos—tried to rescue her offspring but was unable to dislodge it. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the attack; the injured calf died hours later.

• A three‑bedroom, 1,990 sq ft flat in Knightsbridge’s Egerton Place is on the market for £575,000—about the cost to rent it for three years at £15,000/month—because it has only three years left on its lease.  
• The unmodernised maisonette includes two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking and communal garden; a second, larger flat on the same street (2,500 sq ft) is priced at £595,000, also with three years remaining.  
• Extending the lease (likely to 90 years) via the freeholder, the Wellcome Trust, would cost an estimated £3.35–4.5 million, but would boost the flat’s value to around £6 million (or £7.5 million for the larger unit) at £2,750–3,000 per sq ft once modernised.  
• Built in 1893 by John Grover & Son to designs by Mervyn Macartney, Egerton Place is noted for its high‑quality red and orange brick architecture and prestigious early occupants.  
• Agents from Russell Simpson report unusually high interest, while Hanover Private Office warns buyers of the “massive premium” needed to extend such a short lease.

Starbucks late Friday night announced that a computer outage—caused by a failure during a daily system refresh—had disabled point‑of‑sale registers at roughly 8,000 stores (7,000 in the US, 1,000 in Canada) since early evening. Baristas, some accepting cash to keep serving and others giving away free drinks and baked goods, closed many locations early to stem giveaways. The outage, which also hit Evolution Fresh and Teavana outlets, generated a flurry of social‑media posts from customers flaunting their free beverages. By Friday night the issue was resolved, with “business as usual” expected Saturday. The snafu came just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly net revenues of $4.6 billion and saw its shares jump 4.4 percent.

Rural areas of west Wales—specifically Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire—are being used to train and radicalise Muslims, Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit has disclosed. Extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998, when Abu Hamza sent recruits to train in the Brecon Beacons. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white‑water rafting at Bala, and in 2010 a Cardiff‑based Al Qaeda‑inspired cell plotting “Mumbai‑style” attacks met secretly in a Welsh country park. Michael Adebowale, one of Lee Rigby’s killers, studied Arabic at a former Islamic institute near Llanybydder. Jones warned that these individuals often appear to participate in ordinary community life but have hidden motives, and he urged the public to share any relevant intelligence.

After Tropical Cyclone Olwyn hit last month, a 5.68 m juvenile female Omura’s whale was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach at the tip of WA’s North West Cape. It’s the first record of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia, confirmed by DNA profiling after initial identification difficulties. Described in 2003 and normally found in tropical/subtropical waters off Indonesia, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan, Omura’s whales have sleek bodies, 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the discovery “highly significant” for improving field identification guides and understanding regional distribution. The carcass has been buried; its skeleton will be exhumed in a few years for scientific study and possible museum display.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, argues that women—because of their “hormones”—shouldn’t be president, warning that Hillary Clinton’s might make her irrational or prone to unnecessary war. Yet studies show male leaders’ testosterone often drives poor decisions and risk‑taking, and women generally take fewer unnecessary risks. While some—even Time magazine—worry about female biology, the real barrier to a woman president is persistent gender bias. Women now outnumber men in higher education and the workforce, but they’re underestimated: corporate boards still feature more men named John, Robert, William or James than there are women; students call male professors “geniuses” but describe female ones as merely “nice.” Eliminating these stereotypes would benefit everyone—companies with more women leaders earn more, shared parenting boosts children’s well‑being, and balanced household roles strengthen marriages. Rather than blaming hormones, we should challenge the biases that still limit women’s potential—proof that Rios’s threat to “move to Canada” ignores the fact that Canada elected its first female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling more than 200 antiques—estimated at around £100,000—in a 238‑lot auction run by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, this Saturday. To downsize his Cotswolds home, he’s offering Victorian furniture by Gillows, paintings (including a hand‑painted 1960s limewood diorama of Agincourt by L.M. Rendall), a medieval yew longbow with mother‑of‑pearl handle and portrait, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers and 17th‑century books. A military historian and English graduate taught by J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, Hardy has published two books on the longbow and consulted on the Mary Rose recovery. Best known as Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small, he’s also portrayed Winston Churchill, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Cornelius Fudge in Harry Potter. Though saddened to part with his collection, he hopes buyers enjoy it as much as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky, 57, is wanted in Winter Garden, Florida, as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was found Saturday at their shared home following an out‑of‑state family member’s welfare check. He failed to appear later that day for a supervised visit with his son. Shemansky, on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar disorder and a prior suicide attempt; his mother had been supporting him through a divorce during which his estranged wife obtained a domestic violence injunction two years ago. Neighbors say divorce stress—and his mother’s insistence that he skip the visitation—may have triggered the killing. Police have recovered the murder weapon but haven’t released details of the homicide. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication; anyone with information is asked to call 407‑656‑3636.

Eugene, Oregon, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the IAAF Council — bypassing the usual bidding process — seized a “unique strategic opportunity” to stage the event for the first time in the USA. Eugene had lost its 2019 bid to Doha but persuaded the IAAF with a strong presentation and the prospect of coordinated support from public authorities, the private sector, the U.S. Olympic Committee, NBC and an enthusiastic local audience. IAAF President Lamine Diack said the move, though unorthodox, serves the sport’s global development and market access. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka were also awarded without bidding, and at the 2013 Moscow championships Mo Farah won gold in the men’s 10,000 m.

Leonie Granger, a 25‑year‑old aspiring model from Kent, was jailed for 16 years after orchestrating a “honey trap” to lure 56‑year‑old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death and steal his winnings. Posing as his friend at a West End casino, she won his trust, then returned to his Islington flat one night, leaving the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson (28), and accomplice Nicholas Chandler (29). The pair bound and fatally beat Hassan as they searched for his cash stash. Granger was convicted of manslaughter; Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and given life sentences with minimum terms of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy called the attack “pitiless and wicked.” Investigators recovered CCTV footage and Granger’s phone records, and the victim’s family said his death “will haunt them forever.”

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fàbregas has again shown a marked drop in form in the second half of the season. After a sparkling start—amassing 15 Premier League assists by mid‑January and looking set to break Thierry Henry’s single‑season record—he has managed just one assist in his last five club games and four in 15 matches for club and country in 2015. His struggles were underlined in Spain’s 2-0 defeat to the Netherlands, where he was rated four out of ten. Manager José Mourinho and observers attribute his dip to fatigue from playing almost every minute since his £30 million move from Barcelona, mirroring a late‑season slump he also suffered there. With nine league games remaining and several teams he has previously supplied among the fixtures, Chelsea still rely on a revived Fàbregas to secure the title, and Mourinho will be looking for further signs of resurgence after Fabregas set up Diego Costa’s winner at Hull.

West Ham United are close to signing 17‑year‑old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two‑week trial with their academy, despite having offers from Belgian clubs. Beckford, regarded as one of the Caribbean’s top prospects, has drawn interest from several European sides. Separately, West Ham have announced Olympic Stadium season tickets starting at £289—the lowest in the Premier League—to help fill all 54,000 seats when they move there for 2016‑17.

Three months after Mike Lane, 40 and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was brutally beaten by balaclava‑clad hunt saboteurs armed with iron‑barred ropes at Everleigh (during a drag hunt using an artificial scent), Wiltshire Police have shelved the investigation for “insufficient evidence.” Lane—knocked out, kicked in the head, hospitalised with concussion, broken teeth and subsequent memory loss—had provided a video, a dossier naming suspects and car registrations. Despite releasing a photo of the main attacker, no one has been identified, charged or prosecuted. Hunt supporters and witnesses condemn the decision as “pathetic” and “disgraceful,” and the Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings among saboteurs. Wiltshire Police say the case remains “undetected” but could reopen if new evidence emerges.

The White House announced that Adam Gadahn—born Adam Pearlman in 1978 and known as Azzam the American or Abu Suhayb—was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in which he was not specifically targeted. Ahmed Farouq, another U.S. citizen al Qaeda operative, also died—likely in a separate strike that killed U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein (abducted in Pakistan in 2011) and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto.  

Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995, left the U.S. for Pakistan in 1998, and by the mid‑2000s had become al Qaeda’s chief English‑language propagandist. Under indictment since 2006 for treason and material support, he appeared in videos threatening Western and Jewish targets, urging lone‑wolf attacks, criticizing Presidents Bush and Obama, and praising other attacks. Documents seized from Osama bin Laden’s Abbottabad compound included a 2011 letter from Gadahn advising on al Qaeda’s media strategy. He was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child.

Chinese parents’ drive to raise prodigies has produced a new basketball sensation: five‑year‑old Mai Zizhuo, who’s been shooting hoops since age two and a half. A viral video shows him sinking successive shots and dribbling two balls at once without losing rhythm, earning him thousands of fans across basketball‑crazy China. Netizens—amazed to the point of suspecting special effects, asking about his father and comparing him favorably even to former NBA star Yao Ming—have flooded comment threads with praise and disbelief.

Tom O’Carroll, a former Open University information officer and leading 1970s–80s activist in the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE)—which, in alliance with the NCCL, campaigned to lower the age of consent to ten and legalize sex with children and incest—has joined the supporters of Hacked Off. On February 25 he attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament, chaired by John Cleese, to lobby MPs for a statutory press regulator as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. Hacked Off, founded after the phone‑hacking scandal to challenge the “biased and unfair” Independent Press Standards Organisation, says the event was open to all; O’Carroll, jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals,” confirmed his attendance on his blog, a development the group finds embarrassing.

On Thursday, Bondi’s iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as an unconventional runway for Ten Pieces’ ten‑item, monochrome, unisex capsule collection—designed by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss to be worn in 20 ways—during Mercedes‑Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop, while guests on the club balcony and passing beachgoers watched under clear blue skies and 28 °C sunshine, enjoying Icebergs’ nibbles and Santa Vittoria drinks. Some regular lap swimmers were reportedly displeased by the pool’s temporary closure.

Bolton‑born boxer Amir Khan, 28, spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa, feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week he announced his next fight—a welterweight bout against former light‑welterweight champion Chris Algieri on May 30—turning down calls to face British rival Kell Brook in June and dismissing links to Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16‑year‑old Palestinian who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, was mistakenly listed on Jerusalem’s Mount Herzl memorial wall for fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His family, led by his father Hussein, and Almagor—a victims‑of‑terror group—objected, arguing no permission was sought and that his death was a “rogue” criminal act, not terrorism. After threats by Almagor to remove its own honorees if Abu Khdeir’s name remained, Israel’s National Insurance Institute agreed to take it off the wall; his name has already been deleted from the memorial website. Meanwhile, a court panel began hearing evidence against the three suspects in January.

California YouTuber Lionel Hutz captured his toddler using the family cat as a makeshift pillow in their garden. The footage shows the boy plonking himself onto the cat’s belly, prompting the feline to relocate each time. After the third move, the cat retreats indoors. A follow‑up clip reveals the pair reconciled, with the child gently offering the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, 32, one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying in Philadelphia’s federal police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after admitting this week that he sold marijuana for years. He told jurors that undercover officers stole $81,000 in cash and seven pounds of marijuana during his 2007 arrest—a conviction later expunged—and on cross-examination acknowledged a 2008 DUI and a 2011 arrest carrying a four‑year probation. Kushner says he never meant to deceive the school, where he passed a 2010 background check, and insists he’s innocent of the 2011 charges. Meanwhile, six former drug squad officers face a 26‑count indictment—including racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug dealing—and have argued the government’s case rests on testimony from “lying drug dealers” and a rogue ex‑cop.

An oil storage tank at a paraxylene (PX) plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, exploded Monday night after an oil leak, sparking a large fire but no reported toxic spill. Six workers were injured—five by broken glass—and hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters brought the blaze under control by Tuesday morning. Residents heard the blast, felt tremors and shared photos on Weibo. The plant, relocated from densely populated Xiamen after 2007 pollution protests, had previously experienced a non‑injurious explosion in July 2013; PX facilities have repeatedly drawn public opposition in China over health and environmental concerns.

Jack Grealish, the Ireland Under‑21 midfielder at Aston Villa, insists on wearing his socks low over children’s‑size shinpads—a superstition he won’t abandon despite referees telling him to pull them up and noting he’s never been kicked in the shin. He made his first Premier League start in Tuesday’s 3‑3 relegation‑scrap draw with QPR and says he’s grateful for his manager’s faith, hoping it earns him more starts before season’s end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22, has “global and irreversible brain damage,” her grandmother Cissy Houston said, and although she’s been taken off a medically induced coma she remains unresponsive. A CNN source reports that for nearly three months she has shown no response to visitors or familiar voices, her eyes do not track people, and she now has a tracheostomy. Two days earlier, her father Bobby Brown—speaking emotionally at a Dallas concert—said she was awake and watching him. Family attorney Christopher Brown confirmed her condition has improved and that doctors expect her to live a long life, but said the ultimate quality of that life won’t be known for years as she embarks on a lengthy rehabilitation. Bobby Brown’s wife, Alicia Etheredge‑Brown, added that Bobbi Kristina has left the ICU, opened her eyes and begun what will be a “long and hard” rehab process.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Görges in straight sets and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to overcome Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with 13 double faults while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved decisive. Pavlyuchenkova said Lisicki’s “boom‑boom” power disrupted her rhythm; Lisicki admitted her tiebreak was poor. Russia now needs just one win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and secure its first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents across New South Wales still recovering from last week’s east coast low are being warned to brace for another storm, with heavy rain possible from Thursday through Saturday. The State Emergency Service has over 4,000 of 24,196 assistance requests still outstanding and fears further storms will hamper clean‑up—particularly in the hard‑hit Hunter region. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills urged communities to prepare their homes and families. Weatherzone’s Kim Westcott says the new low is farther offshore and likely to bring two days of rain, mainly to northern parts of the state, rather than a repeat of Sydney’s three‑day storm. Bureau of Meteorology regional director Barry Hanstrum warns northeast coastal catchments and southeast Queensland may again face intense rainfall and flooding. Over 1,000 SES personnel, including 200 interstate responders, remain deployed.

Italian model Nina Moric—known for appearing in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” video—has denied recent reports that she tried to take her own life. After collapsing at home, she was treated in hospital for low blood pressure and posted photos of bruises on Instagram, explaining she hit her head in a “domestic accident.” Italian media had claimed she attempted suicide and quoted her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, as confirming it; Moric said those reports were incorrect and that he was in Naples at the time. She’s now recovering at home. Media also recall that in 2009 she was alleged to have taken an overdose. Moric was formerly married to celebrity photographer Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria (b. 2002). Corona served jail time for blackmailing public figures with compromising photos—a practice he defended as merely offering subjects the first chance to buy their own images—and was recorded in police wiretaps admitting he “ruined lives.”

• As they await their second child, a YouGov/Sunday Times poll of 2,200 Britons finds 12% would name a baby girl “Diana” (after William’s mother), with “Alice” and “Charlotte” each on 9%.  
• If it’s a boy, 13% favor “James,” followed by “Alexander.”  
• Overall, 25% hope for a daughter versus just 3% for another son after Prince George.  
• Social media users also voiced strong enthusiasm for the name Diana.  
• The poll shows 68% support Prince William taking six weeks’ paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday at about 10 a.m., killing 17 people and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The demonstrators, led by MP Humayoon Humayoon, were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility and no other group has claimed the attack, police said.

Dani Alves will leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final contract offer. The 31‑year‑old Brazilian right‑back, who has spent seven trophy‑laden years at Barça—winning four La Liga titles and two Champions League crowns—turned down a proposed three‑year extension contingent on featuring in 60 percent of matches. His agent and ex‑wife, Dinorah Santana, announced that negotiations are over.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan to Boca Juniors from Southampton, has scored three goals in six games and is urging Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him in Argentina. He believes their “South American–style” playmaking would suit Boca and that La Bombonera fans would embrace them. Pirlo is widely regarded as one of the world’s best midfielders and Totti is a Roma icon—Osvaldo says both would be perfect additions.

Eighteen‑year‑old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson suffered only a small cut to his nose after a widely viewed double‑somersault fall from the favourite Merrion Square in the 4.20 at Wincanton. Back in Paul Nicholls’s yard on Thursday morning, he was mucking out stables as usual and is keen to ride again. Ferguson described the incident as “a blur,” only realising its scale after watching the replay with fellow jockeys, who watched in horror. He considers himself very lucky, has since picked up a few hundred Twitter followers amid good‑natured banter, and even joked about a future gymnastics career.

London Wasps captain James Haskell marked the Westfield London premiere of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man with the caption, “avengers movie is out so thought i would release the inner iron man….” A Windsor‑born flanker, Haskell first joined Wasps in 2002 and won his first England cap in 2007. He left in 2009 for two seasons at Stade Français, then had brief stints with Japan’s Ricoh Black Rams and New Zealand’s Highlanders before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return he’s made over 100 club appearances and earned 57 England caps.

Wide-leg trousers are the key SS15 alternative to skinny jeans, coming in denim, cropped, printed and striped styles. Endorsed by Louise Redknapp—who first tried them seven years ago—and worn by Poppy Delevingne on the AW15 Chloe runway, they offer an effortless, seventies-inspired silhouette. To balance the volume, pair them with high-heeled, open-top shoes and a simple knit, tee or shirt; for extra leg length, choose high‑waisted, full‑length cuts. Denim versions featured on Gucci and Celine runways; high‑street takes include Topshop’s Miller jean and Finery London’s budget-friendly options. More inspiration is at astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel an “American Sniper” screening as part of its UMix student‐social series, despite a petition by over 200 students who felt the film’s portrayal of the Iraq War cast the Middle East and its people in a negative light (noting Detroit’s large Arab‑American community). Bradley Cooper earned an Oscar nomination for playing Navy SEAL Chris Kyle, who became America’s deadliest sniper before being fatally shot in 2013. After a backlash and counter‑petition, Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper apologized for the initial cancellation, emphasizing the university’s commitment to free expression, and confirmed the screening will proceed—while offering “Paddington” as a family‑friendly alternative. The decision drew public praise from head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Quokkas are cat‑sized marsupials native to small islands off Western Australia—notably Rottnest Island (near Perth) and Bald Island (near Albany).
