On April 3, two French tourists (men aged 18 and 24, living in Cockburn Central) allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter on Rottnest Island, singeing a quokka that survived the attack. Detectives seized video evidence, questioned and evicted the men; both have been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

At 102, former chorus‐line dancer Alice Barker—who performed at New York’s Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar in the 1930s–40s alongside stars like Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra—finally saw herself on film for the first time. Having lost all her photographs and memorabilia, she’d never viewed the “soundies” (early music videos) in which she appeared. Filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled these clips and screened them at her nursing home, delighting Barker: “It’s just fabulous.”

Once a Sunday ritual, car self‑washing in Britain is now in decline. An OSV survey of 1,100 adults finds 31% of men and 75% of women have never washed their own car, and only 12% of those who do wash it regularly. Just 5% pay their children to help. Factors include shops opening on Sundays, live football on TV, the rise of hand‑washes and larger 4×4s that are hard to clean. Around 15 million cars were owner‑washed last Easter—often simply as an excuse to get out of the house. Regionally, Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield lead in DIY washes; Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh trail. Audis, Toyotas and BMWs are most often self‑washed; Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes least. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley cites time pressures, bigger cars and cheap automated services as the key reasons.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard’s influence since his 2008 arrival at Anfield, calling him “one of the best players in the world” and synonymous with Liverpool. Gerrard is set to captain the side in Sunday’s FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa, aiming to reach the May 30 final against Arsenal—which will be his last Anfield appearance before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel credits Gerrard with helping him settle at the club and, while he admits Liverpool will feel his absence, believes they have players capable of filling the No. 8 role. Both Skrtel and Gerrard are available for the Villa match after serving three‑game bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus made his first-ever hole‑in‑one at Augusta National—his shot on the 130‑yard 4th hole sailed past the flag then spun in—during the Masters par‑3 contest alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. The day produced five aces (tying the record), including two by Camilo Villegas, who nonetheless lost the par‑3 title to world No. 74 Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, youngest green‑jacket winner in 1963 and six‑time Masters champion (last in 1986), is one of only five men to complete golf’s career Grand Slam.

Wednesday night severe storms in Kansas prompted tornado sirens after spotters reported a twister six miles northwest of Goddard (17 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast, sparing Wichita but threatening nearby towns. The Storm Prediction Center also logged three tornado reports near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. In Missouri, the National Weather Service said a tornado may have hit Potosi (70 miles from St. Louis), where CNN affiliate KMOV received reports of wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage and flooded streets. Residents in Leadington posted images of ominous clouds, and a Farmington resident reported “baseball‑size” hail. CNN’s Chad Myers cautioned that nighttime tornadoes are especially deadly, and the Weather Service forecasts additional storms Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys and the southern Great Lakes region.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty Tuesday to second‑degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris—whom he says he meant to stun with a Taser—during an April 2 weapons sting. The judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, a decision Harris’s family condemned as tone‑deaf. Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2; his lawyer, Clark Brewster, said they look forward to airing facts in court. Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized, but Harris’s family lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment—claims the sheriff’s office denies. Over the weekend, one of Bates’s attorneys released training records showing he was properly trained. Two other deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned amid threats.

Conor McGregor, 26, will challenge José Aldo for the UFC featherweight title in Las Vegas on July 11. Ahead of the fight, he unveiled a new tiger-stomach tattoo—adding to his chest gorilla ink—and taunted Aldo on Instagram (“if you see the tiger, it’s too late, you’re food”). McGregor insists Aldo lacks his motivation to fight or defend the belt, a claim underscored when he grabbed Aldo’s championship belt during a Dublin promotional event.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott drew both cheers and criticism when, at a University of Technology Sydney–hosted Australian rules football event, he “skolled” (downed) a schooner of beer in roughly six seconds amid chants of “skol” and “Tony.” Cultural studies professor Julie Robert condemned the stunt as glorifying binge drinking and equating masculinity with rapid, excessive alcohol consumption, warning it fosters a “show‑off” drinking culture. Opposition leader Bill Shorten quipped that Abbott had finally mastered beer without lemonade, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended the prime minister’s fitness and found nothing objectionable in his antics. Critics urged that public figures set examples of responsible drinking rather than perpetuate “true blue Aussie bloke” stereotypes.

Indiana’s Scott County HIV outbreak, now at 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary cases—up from 106 last week—has prompted Gov. Mike Pence’s 30‑day emergency needle exchange program, approved March 26. In just over two weeks, 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed to 86 participants (with about 1,400 returned), aided by a mobile unit building trust among IV opana users. Pence will decide early next week whether to extend the program beyond April 25, even as he and some legislators oppose exchanges as drug policy, and the legislature weighs a bill (House‑approved 54‑39) allowing 23 high-hepatitis C counties to run their own exchanges. Observers warn that without long‑term funding—federal law bars public support—and broader harm‑reduction framing, the state risks repeating or worsening such outbreaks.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, sit a 50‑point “exam” on everything from the meaning of “FC” and the club nickname, to naming the current manager, starting XI by position, FA Cup trivia and explaining in her own words why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard. The school‑style test (multiple choice, tables to fill in, short‑answer questions and “helpful” instructions like “read every question twice” and “calculators may be used”) earned her 43.5/50 (87%). Her boyfriend praised her performance—while noting she could have done better on one question, needs to learn all player positions and remember “Tottenham are scum”—and rewarded her by not dumping her. Saskia posted the test on Twitter, where many fans applauded her as “proper girlfriend material” and others joked that football supporters are “nuts” or criticized the boyfriend’s over‑the‑top quiz.

Carlos Toro, 66, is a former mid‑level member of Colombia’s Medellín cartel who fled to the United States in the 1980s after a violent split with his boss.  In exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship, he spent the next 27 years working as a DEA undercover informant—helping to dismantle major figures such as cartel co‑founder Carlos Lehder and Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega.  

Now retired on medical grounds, Toro’s final temporary visa expired on January 1 and he has received neither citizenship nor operational support from the DEA.  Technically undocumented, he faces imminent deportation—despite fearing for his life if returned to Colombia—and cannot obtain a green card, passport or social‑security benefits.  After Toro went public with his plight, his former DEA handler and another associate each gave him $5,000 for medical care, but the agency itself has refused further assistance.

A 14‑year‑old girl in Kosi Kalan, Mathura district, Uttar Pradesh, was allegedly gang‑raped by five men while she went outside to relieve herself; her family told her to keep quiet. On Tuesday she set herself alight with kerosene, suffering 70 percent burns, and is now fighting for her life in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital; the accused men have been arrested. The case comes as India grapples with heightened sensitivity over sexual violence—underscored by last month’s ban on the documentary “India’s Daughter” (which recounts the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of 23‑year‑old Jyoti Singh, a case that sparked nationwide protests and death sentences) and recent instances of mob justice in Nagaland against alleged rapists.

• Louis van Gaal is “dreaming” of beating Manchester City in Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford—his first home derby in charge.  
• Key absentees: Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw are both ruled out, deemed not match‑fit despite claiming fitness.  
• United trained in fine weather with players like Rooney, Di Maria, Falcao, Mata, Herrera and Carrick preparing for the clash.  
• A victory would lift United as high as third, strengthening their Champions League prospects and exceeding pre‑season targets.  
• Van Gaal downplays a revenge motive for City’s earlier 1–0 win, instead emphasising controlled aggression and lessons learned.  
• He also praises the “marvellous” Old Trafford support, saying he genuinely feels the fans’ backing.

Arsenal and Liverpool supporters staged a ten‑minute boycott at the sold‑out Emirates Stadium—leaving their seats empty for the first ten minutes of the 12.45pm kickoff—to protest soaring ticket prices, which began at £64 for this match despite the Premier League’s new £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, fans displayed banners reading “£5 bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing,” decrying “extortionate” costs, late fixture changes and unreasonable kickoff times. Leaders Kelvin Meadows and Roy Bentham warned that without price reductions aligned to working‑class incomes, the game risks losing a generation of supporters. Further protests were expected after full‑time.

A baby girl named Star Reader, born in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed within days of life with biliary atresia—a rare, potentially fatal condition in which bile ducts are blocked or absent. After a failed attempt to unblock her ducts, doctors said Star would need a liver transplant. Neither parent proved a suitable donor, so Star’s maternal aunt, Shanell Reader—who is the twin sister of Star’s mother, Jade—volunteered and donated part of her liver. The transplant took place in November; Star spent six weeks in hospital and has since gone home, requiring weekly blood and liver-function tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Both Jade and Shanell say they felt no hesitation in saving Star’s life. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 newborns; left untreated, it leads to liver failure and death.

Chelsea stars Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake faced team‑mates Loïc Rémy and Willian in Audi’s branded football challenge.  
• Round 1: from close range, Hazard/Ake outscored Rémy/Willian 5–3 by firing balls into a car boot.  
• Round 2: playing “tennis” over a £127 000 Audi R8 V10 Plus used as the net, Hazard/Ake won again to go 2–0 up.  
• Round 3: long‑range shots through the tops of convertible Audis saw Rémy/Willian win the decider, though Willian also smashed one car’s wing mirror in the process. Willian later enjoyed a spin in one of the Audis.

Robert Dellinger, 54, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, drove his pickup across a highway median on December 7, 2013, at over 100 mph and collided with an oncoming SUV, killing 24‑year‑old Amanda Murphy—who was eight months pregnant—her fiancé Jason Timmons, 29, and their unborn child. Prosecutors say Dellinger told investigators he had been trying to kill himself, but at his sentencing hearing he denied any suicidal intent. In February he pleaded guilty to two counts of negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus’s death and now faces 12–24 years in prison. His wife expressed remorse to the victims’ families and praised his character, while his attorneys blamed Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drugs and advanced multiple sclerosis for the crash. He also faces a wrongful‑death lawsuit filed by Murphy’s estate.

Lacey Spears, a 27‑year‑old mother from Chestnut Ridge, New York, was sentenced to 20 years to life for second‑degree murder in the 2014 salt poisoning death of her five‑year‑old son, Garnett‑Paul Spears. Prosecutors portrayed her as a “bizarre” attention‑seeker who repeatedly hospitalized her son, injected his feeding tube with lethal salt, and chronicled his suffering on social media. The judge—citing Spears’s mental illness and the crime’s cruelty—spared her the maximum 25‑to‑life term. Defense counsel argued hospital negligence and has vowed to appeal. Garnett’s father, Chris Hill, publicly denounced Spears on Facebook, urging she be placed in general population and expressing hopes she would die behind bars.

Australian health authorities have delayed this year’s influenza vaccine by one month to include protection against two newly problematic strains—A/H3N2 and B/Phuket—after a surge in flu‑related deaths from those strains in Europe and the US. The updated vaccine, which also covers A/H1N1, arrives in time for Australia’s winter and will be offered free to high‑risk groups (the very young, the elderly and most Indigenous Australians) from April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the influenza specialist group, says the revised formulation should closely match circulating global strains, reduce mortality, and will also be used in the coming northern‑hemisphere season. He urges everyone to book their flu shot now to help protect themselves and vulnerable contacts.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s Tomb in Springfield are under pressure from a critical National Geographic review—calling the interior “all the historical character of an office lobby”—and looming state budget cuts. Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed folding the state historic preservation agency into another department after lawmakers trimmed $1.1 million from Springfield sites last year, leading to reduced hours and staff. On the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s shooting, visitors found the tomb locked outside its posted times. Agency officials counter that visitor information is online and highlight over $2.5 million in recent repairs (including $730,000 in lighting upgrades and a $390,000 vault waterproofing). Designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874 by President Grant, the circular, obelisk‑topped tomb features black‑and‑tan marble interiors and a family burial chamber inscribed “Now he belongs to the ages.” Supporters and visitors dispute the magazine’s negative portrayal, calling the site impressive and well maintained.

The passage argues that many outrageously impractical 1990s/20000s trends are back in style, illustrating each with original adopters and modern wearers:

1. JNCO “rave” jeans (50″ leg openings) are returning, much to the horror of their first fans.  
2. Bucket hats—once worn by Christina Aguilera in 2001—are now sported by Rihanna.  
3. Camouflage print, favoured by Destiny’s Child in 2001, resurfaces in Jourdan Dunn’s streetwear.  
4. “Maxed‑out” looks like double denim, loved by early‑00s stars (Beckham, Spears, Timberlake), are now embraced by Kylie Jenner.  
5. Ugg boots—Paris Hilton’s off‑duty staple in 2006—remain popular with Kristen Bell.  
6. Daisy Duke micro‑shorts, reintroduced by Jessica Simpson in 2005’s Dukes of Hazzard, are kept alive by Miley Cyrus.  
7. Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, worn by Britney Spears and Paris Hilton in the noughties, are revived by Nicki Minaj.  
8. Coloured mirrored sunglasses, a 90s boy‑band accessory, are now spotted on Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner.  
9. Corsets-as-outerwear, popularised by Victoria Beckham in the 2000s, feature in Selena Gomez’s red‑carpet gowns.  
10. Harem trousers—championed by Kim Kardashian in 2009—still appear on Elle Macpherson.

Together, these examples highlight how boldly nostalgic elements of 90s/00s fashion have been re‑adopted by today’s celebrities.

CNN’s weekly roundup of viral moments included: in New York, CEO Amanda Curtis captured four rainbows arching across the sky after heavy rain; China’s latest anti‑vice campaign bans exotic dancers at wakes; Robert Downey Jr. bristled when a UK interviewer probed his private life; the “#KylieJennerChallenge” saw people lip‑plumping by jar suction; 102‑year‑old Alice Barker teamed with filmmakers to “go back in time”; a bomb‑themed prom proposal was rejected by one school amid racism claims; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumière in Disney’s Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; one couple announced their pregnancy with a Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air nod; and a military dad photobombed his son’s portrait.

The Miami Open has begun marking player milestones with giant cakes—first celebrating Andy Murray’s 500th career win, then wheeling one out for Serena Williams’s 700th after she beat Sabine Lisicki 7‑6, 1‑6, 6‑3 in the quarter‑finals. Williams, the world No. 1 playing near her home base, avenged her shock 2013 Wimbledon loss to Lisicki and moved into the semis. A potential all‑Williams showdown ended when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro, and Serena now faces third seed Simona Halep—who defeated Sloane Stephens 6‑1, 7‑5—for a spot in the final.

Sabeen Mahmud ran T2F, a brightly painted café‑gallery on a Karachi industrial road where she hosted discussions on technology, human rights and women’s entrepreneurship and promoted secular, progressive culture. Despite death threats, she had just convened a banned university debate on Balochistan’s mass disappearances when, late Friday, two gunmen shot her dead at point‑blank range, wounding her mother. No one has claimed responsibility or given a motive. Mahmud—hailed as a symbol of free speech, humanism and tolerance—shocked Pakistan’s nonviolent and progressive communities. Online and artistic tributes praised her warmth, courage and vision for a just, open society. T2F’s graffiti‑sprayed walls and homey atmosphere embodied her mission to create rare public space for fearless dialogue in a climate of fear.

Mangu Ram, an 82‑year‑old Hindu healer in Jammu, has lived as a West Pakistan Refugee (WPR) for nearly 70 years, having fled Punjab during the 1947 partition. Although most of the roughly 100,000 WPRs have never been to Pakistan, Jammu and Kashmir’s successive governments have denied them “state‑subject” rights—property ownership, voting in state elections and state government jobs—fearing any shift in the region’s Muslim‑majority demographic. Trapped in slum settlements, three generations of WPR families remain mired in poverty and barred from state‑run colleges. Under a pre‑independence law, only those born in the former princely state qualify for citizenship, yet about 35,000 Hindus who fled from Pakistan‑administered Kashmir have been naturalized. After December’s state election, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party joined the ruling coalition and pledged to normalize WPR status. Refugee activists, hopeful but cautious, warn they will protest if promised reforms do not materialize. Source: Associated Press.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto has confirmed he’s weighing a summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea after club president Naoki Ogane revealed a reported £4 million bid, with Chelsea planning to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem. The 22‑year‑old insists he will only join a team where he can play regularly and continue his development. His former coach at FC Tokyo, Ranko Popović, has lauded Muto’s speed, intelligence and confidence, calling him an outstanding prospect. Chelsea manager José Mourinho said he knows “a little” about Muto but declined to comment further on a player from another club, emphasizing that transfers are guided by both financial‑fair‑play considerations (including a recent £200 million Yokohama sponsorship) and genuine sporting need.

Australia’s decision to drop its ban on overseas‑based players—allowing stars like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell back into Wallabies contention—recognizes the modern, global nature of rugby. England, by contrast, still bars England‑eligible players who ply their trade abroad, a stance Stuart Lancaster has maintained despite clear evidence (e.g. Toulon’s Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon and even Jonny Wilkinson) that moving to top foreign clubs can improve performances. The article argues that for England to field its strongest side at the home World Cup, boost squad morale and honor the tournament’s “best‑of‑the‑world” ideal, it must follow Australia, South Africa and Wales in selecting England‑qualified players regardless of where they play.

Open Garden’s FireChat app lets users send encrypted, anonymous messages and photos off the grid by turning each phone into a node in a Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi direct “mesh” network. Launched with Apple’s iOS 7 multipeer‑connectivity framework (and a similar Android feature), it offers “nearby” chats (within ~30 ft/9 m) and an “everyone” mode that relays messages hop‑by‑hop up to ~200 ft (61 m). FireChat has over five million downloads and is popular where cellular or Wi‑Fi are unavailable or unreliable. To extend its range, Open Garden is developing Greenstone, an egg‑shaped beacon that stores up to 1,000 messages, runs for a year on battery, and forwards messages when another FireChat device comes within about 20 ft (6 m). Greenstone aims to bolster resilient communication in communities, events, protests or emergencies; commercial release depends on manufacturing partnerships.

In her recent TED Talk, New Jersey burlesque performer Lillian Bustle reclaimed “fat” as a neutral, body‑positive self‑descriptor—alongside “short” and “wife”—arguing it need not imply ugliness. She cited a 66 % rise in workplace size discrimination over 30 years and noted that girls’ top “magic wish” is to be thinner, yet studies show exposure to diverse bodies increases acceptance. Since starting burlesque in 2012 at 240 lbs, she’s found performing empowering and recommends everyone identify a personal “courage reference” to boost self‑esteem. Her talk, posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback—including stories of viewers rethinking their body image—affirming her belief that body positivity is winning.

Arsenal winger Theo Walcott, 26, who has been named among the substitutes in 17 of the club’s 33 Premier League games this season and made only a six‑minute cameo in the recent 0‑0 draw with Chelsea, joined six team‑mates—Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Özil—and runway model Olga Sherer for an official portrait by Paris fashion house Lanvin, Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013. The first‑team squad will wear the same Lanvin outfits for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa at Wembley on May 30. Walcott, unused as a starter since Arsenal’s 3‑0 win over West Ham on March 14, hopes to regain a place in the XI at Hull City next Monday.

Legendary make‑up effects artist Rick Baker is selling 417 props and puppets from his Cinovation Studio—spanning more than 50 films—at a no‑reserve auction on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online via PropStore.com. The collection is valued at about $746,100 in total and includes highlights such as:

• Edgar bug from Men in Black (est. $40,000)  
• “Mikey” alien from Men in Black (est. $30,000)  
• Jim Carrey’s Grinch costume (est. $8,000)  
• Two‑Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500)  
• Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons (est. $6,000)  
• Various Gremlins 2 puppets (each around $6,000–$8,000)  
• Frosty, the frozen thug from Batman & Robin (est. $4,000)  
• Worm Guy from Men in Black II (est. $10,000)  
• Michael Jackson’s robotic face from Moonwalker (est. $3,000)  
• Hero Joe head from Mighty Joe Young (est. $6,000)

Over his 30‑year career, Baker also worked on classics like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy and Michael Jackson’s Thriller. Prop Store’s Brandon Alinger calls the sale “an exciting opportunity for collectors and fans to own a piece of Hollywood history.”

Seven‑year‑old Carwyn Scott‑Howell from Talybont‑on‑Usk, Wales, was killed in the French Alps on 15 February after separating from his mother and sister on the resort of Flaine’s last run of the day. A competent skier and snowboarder who began skiing at three and idolised TV adventurer Bear Grylls, he pressed on ahead when his nine‑year‑old sister’s ski came off, left the piste into dense woodland, and fell 164 ft. Police traced his footprints—and sliding marks from his descent—to find his body.

Carwyn’s family described him as “daring, outgoing and determined” with a “handsome smile” that “lit up any room,” saying his death “has left a vast void in our hearts.” His body is to be repatriated while his school, community and local councillors in Wales mourn him as a “lively, likeable pupil” whose loss has devastated friends, teachers and neighbours.

Laura Scurr, a 15‑year‑old from Whitley Bay, developed severe anorexia at age 13 after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressure to be a “size zero.” At her worst she survived on as little as one piece of fruit (about 100 calories) a day, hid food, and lied to her mother until her heart rate slowed, she collapsed, and spent a week on a heart monitor. With help from eating‑disorder organisations and CAMHS, she’s now recovering, regained a healthy body image, and reached the semi‑final of Miss Teen GB, which promotes positive, confidence‑building experiences for girls. The passage also notes that anorexia nervosa is a serious mental health condition marked by extreme food restriction, affecting around 725,000 people in the UK, and urges gentle intervention and specialist support for sufferers.

Liverpool officially unveiled their 2015/16 home kit—the first under a record £300 million, four‑year deal with New Balance—at Anfield’s Centenary Stand. Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel, Simon Mignolet, Adam Lallana, Jordan Henderson and Philippe Coutinho modeled the new gingham‑style shirt, which features all‑white branding, a revised collar and a “96” Hillsborough tribute. Legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush also attended.

Fans publicly urged Sterling to stay at the club after he rejected a reported £100,000‑a‑week contract extension and acknowledged Arsenal interest, but Liverpool insist the 20‑year‑old—with two years left on his deal—will not leave this summer. Players spoke of the “massive boost” of Anfield’s support as they prepare for the FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa at Wembley, hoping a cup win will spark further success. Steven Gerrard, though departing, still aims to bow out in the final on his May 31 birthday.

University of Manchester researchers led by Dr Sarah Bridle have released the first high‑definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4 percent of the sky (about 150 full‑moon areas), based on two years of galaxy‑shape measurements from the Dark Energy Survey’s 570‑megapixel camera on the 4 m Blanco telescope at CTIO. Using gravitational lensing to detect the invisible substance that makes up roughly 80–85 percent of cosmic matter, the map reveals clumps and filaments of dark matter that align with galaxy locations and cosmic voids. Generated from 130 million images and millions of hours of supercomputer time (to measure distortions to one part in 1 000), it was unveiled at the April APS meeting in Baltimore. This is the first of a five‑year effort—due to complete by 2018—to map 12.5 percent of the sky in three dimensions, thereby probing galaxy formation processes and the nature of dark energy through the evolution of dark‑matter clumpiness.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21‑year‑old Dutch winger Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay, who thrived under van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup—scoring against Australia and Chile—has enjoyed a prolific Eredivisie season, netting 20 goals in 26 league games to help PSV claim their first Dutch title in seven years. PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands confirmed interest not only from United but also Paris Saint‑Germain and another major European club, with PSV valuing Depay well above the £15 million Tottenham bid of last summer. A product of VV Moordrecht, Sparta Rotterdam and PSV’s academy, Depay has made over 100 senior appearances. Fast, skillful and known for his dribbling and powerful right‑foot shot, he’s been compared to Arjen Robben and even a young Cristiano Ronaldo, though he’s still refining his decision‑making on the ball.

Chelsea’s youth side beat Manchester City 3-1 at the Academy Stadium to take a commanding lead back to West London in the Youth Cup tie. Tammy Abraham netted twice—first with a fierce drive and then an acrobatic finish—to give Chelsea a 2-1 half‑time advantage after Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts had briefly pegged City level. Dominic Solanke added a late third to seal the victory. Chelsea’s defence, marshalled by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke‑Salter and backed by keeper Bradley Collins, limited City’s chances. Manchester City youngsters like Tosin Adarabioyo, Brandon Barker and Aaron Nemane showed promise but squandered openings under Chelsea’s pressure.

Marco Rubio, a new presidential candidate, says sexual orientation is innate but that marriage—defined as one man and one woman—should be regulated by state legislatures, not guaranteed as a constitutional right. He told CBS’s Face the Nation he opposes court‑mandated same‑sex marriage but would attend the wedding of a family member or staffer even if he disagrees. As a Catholic, he likewise views divorce as wrong yet wouldn’t stop loving someone who divorces. Rubio announced his run last week and has already attracted over $51 million in donor commitments.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian Ilze Zebolde (31) quit their Manchester restaurant jobs in 2014 and set off from London on an open‑ended, low‑budget world tour by bicycle. In 356 days they’ve ridden nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries—France (west and south coasts), Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia‑Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey (entire northern coast), Georgia and Armenia—and plan to press onward into Asia, cross the Pacific, then cycle the length of the Americas. With no set itinerary, they average just €0.10 per kilometre (under €3 per person per day), camping under the stars (161 nights), using free hosts via Couchsurfing and Warmshowers (110 nights total), and relying on pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce—and occasional dumpster foraging—for food. Their journey, fueled by simple gear and a spirit of discovery, has taken them from the Alps and Sierra Nevada to Greek seasides and Turkish tunnels, and they expect to remain on the road for years to come.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 say their wedding photo‑booth operator, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed the racial slur “poor n***** party” on their Bell Tower (Houston) snapshots. They only learned of it months later when the bride’s sister came forward. Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, they’ve sued under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the claim, refused to apologize—telling them “sue me”—and says there’s no proof his service produced the caption or that the couple suffered mental anguish. The couple insists they want only an apology; mediation is tomorrow, with trial set for July if no settlement is reached.

Mike Brown, England and Harlequins full‑back, says he will adopt a cautious, stage‑by‑stage recovery from his latest concussion—unsure when he’ll return after withdrawing from Harlequins’ Premiership match at Wembley. He suffered headaches after France in the Six Nations and was knocked out against Italy in February, derailing his planned comeback for the Ireland game in March. Brown refuses to risk a prolonged lay‑off like Northampton’s George North (advised to end his season after four recent concussions) or Ireland’s Johnny Sexton, and credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules with teaching him to recognise symptoms and be honest about them. He made his comments at the launch of Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2032 grassroots campaign.

Since the internet’s arrival, Britons’ monthly sex frequency has fallen from about five times (1990) to four (2000) and now three, according to Prof. David Spiegelhalter’s book Sex by Numbers. He argues that constant smartphone and email use has blurred work‑home boundaries and eaten into the “empty” private time couples once had. Other factors include more people living alone and ever‑rising competing demands—late‑night work emails in particular—so that, as researcher Catherine Mercer puts it, “sex just falls down our list of priorities.”

Tibetan mastiffs—heavy, loyal herding dogs weighing up to 80 kg—saw a dramatic crash in China’s market. Just over a year ago a puppy sold for £1.2 million, but an anti‑corruption campaign (which ended the practice of gifting expensive dogs to officials) and city bans on dogs over 50 kg have all but wiped out demand. Dozens are now rounded up, sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather, stolen by gangs or discarded by breeders after profiteering cross‑breeding degraded the breed’s quality. A recent rescue of 20 mastiffs bound for slaughter—with many already dead or injured—highlights the scale of the crisis, exacerbated by rapid urbanization making the breed impractical for city living.

A poll of 600 women in Paris found that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on the city’s buses or trains, with half first targeted before age 18. Harassment—from insults, whistling and unsolicited comments on appearance to sexual assault or rape—has left six in ten women afraid to use public transport (versus three in ten men) and forced many to alter their routes, schedules or clothing. The High Council for Gender Equality has called for a campaign to curb sexist or threatening behavior, stressing that perpetrators often feel they act with impunity and that victims must be made aware such abuse is neither normal nor unpunishable (up to five years’ jail and a €75,005 fine).

Leeds‑based insurer Direct Line has launched the #everydayfix competition, asking designers (via a Makerversity “design makeathon”) to create prototypes that solve common “everyday emergencies” identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top ten emergencies included sleeplessness (46%), losing keys (37%), traffic delays (35%), lost documents (33%), no parking (32%), printer failure (31%), phone battery drain (31%), running out of toilet roll (30%), machine‑operated customer service (26%) and forgetting your bank card (25%).

Three prototypes were shortlisted:
• Snooze (by Instruments): an alarm clock that links to your phone and silences notifications to ensure uninterrupted sleep.  
• Forget Me Lock (by Onn Studio): a key‑attached swivel indicator that turns red when the door is locked and green when it’s open, viewable remotely.  
• Nipper (by Impulse): described as the world’s smallest mobile charger, it clips onto any household battery to give your phone a power boost.

The public can vote for their favourite prototype via Twitter retweets using #everydayfix; whichever tweet has the most retweets by 46 April will progress to a Kickstarter campaign and into production. Organizers praised the “smart and simple solutions” generated. Other concepts that didn’t make the final three included a bone‑conduction cycling helmet, a parking‑space alert pin and Relay, an app that forwards messages when your phone dies.

Northumbria’s police and crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under Ministry of Justice investigation for awarding over £500,000 of public victims‑services funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she co‑directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics—including Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz—denounce it as a clear conflict of interest and “soap opera” within the force, arguing PCCs should not fund bodies they run. Baird insists all MoJ procedures were followed; the MoJ will decide if funding must cease. Sim, who rose to prominence after the 2010 Raoul Moat manhunt and faced past bullying allegations (also investigated by Baird), will retire in June. The charity was set up after contacts to its predecessor, Victim Support, fell sharply, though some worry victims may be deterred by Sim’s involvement.

In late March 2014 in Mayfair, Philadelphia, 21‑year‑old Corry “Corey” Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng (19) and friend Carl Halin (18) abducted 53‑year‑old Greg Valecce—whom Campbell suspected of injuring his cat and stealing from him—and held him in a basement for about 42 hours. They beat him, tied him to a chair, filmed the abuse and forcibly tattooed “RIP Pebbles,” swastikas, racial slurs and other offensive images on his body. Valecce sustained multiple broken ribs, wrists and facial bones and escaped April 1 to summon police, who found tattoo gear, drugs and his stolen debit card. All three pleaded guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy and false imprisonment; Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years, Ng to 23 months. Two other defendants—David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt—await sentencing or trial. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but remains left with lasting physical and psychological trauma.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21‑year‑old PSV Eindhoven and Holland winger Memphis Depay, with new manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings. PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands confirmed United—and reportedly Paris Saint‑Germain and another big European club—are ready to pay a fee well above the £15 million Tottenham offered last summer.

Depay has enjoyed a breakout season at PSV’s Philips Stadion, scoring 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games as he helped them clinch their first league title in seven years. A product of VV Moordrecht, Sparta Rotterdam and PSV’s academy, he debuted for the PSV first team in September 2011, signed professionally in June 2012, and has since made over 100 appearances.

Known for his pace, dribbling and powerful right foot—completing more dribbles than anyone in the 2013/14 Eredivisie—Depay prefers playing on the left and cutting inside. While still refining his decision‑making, he’s been likened to Arjen Robben and even compared favorably to a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Internationally he debuted in 2013, starred under Van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup—scoring against Australia and Chile—and was nominated for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea’s under‑18s beat Manchester City’s youngsters 3-1 at the Academy Stadium to take a commanding lead into the second leg. Tammy Abraham’s first‑half brace gave Chelsea the initiative before Dominic Solanke added a late third; Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts had briefly levelled for City. 

Key performers for Chelsea included:
• Tammy Abraham – two fierce volleys, taken off injured after 67 minutes.  
• Dominic Solanke – strong link‑up play and a neat third goal.  
• Fikayo Tomori & Jake Clarke‑Salter – a commanding centre‑back partnership.  
• Ola Aina & Jay DaSilva – incisive contributions down the flanks.  
• Charlie Colkett – captained the midfield and won the central battle.

City’s young side showed promise but lacked a killer final ball:
• Tosin Adarabioyo – led the back four with maturity and movement.  
• Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts – poacher’s finish for City’s goal.  
• Brandon Barker – creative surges but forced the issue at times.  
• Kjetil Haug – shaky under high balls and powerless to prevent Chelsea’s strikes.

Florida Senator and presidential candidate Marco Rubio said he believes sexual orientation is “something that people are born with,” but that the definition of marriage as between one man and one woman should be left to state legislatures, not the courts, and is not a constitutional right. He affirmed he would personally attend a same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer—even if he disagreed with the decision—and compared it to his stance as a Catholic who opposes divorce yet would continue to love divorced friends or relatives. Rubio, who announced his presidential bid last week, has already secured over $47 million in donor commitments ahead of a competitive Republican primary.

Pablo Mandado (27) from Spain and Ilze Zebolde (31) from Latvia quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle the world with no fixed itinerary. In 356 days they’ve ridden almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries—starting in London and heading southeast through France (west and south coasts), Spain, Portugal, northern Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey’s northern coast, Georgia and Armenia.

They keep costs under €3 per person per day (about €0.10 per km) by camping 161 nights, using Couchsurfing (66) and Warmshowers (44), and spending just €2.74 daily on food (staples, wild fruits, occasional invitations or dumpster finds). After symbolically crossing from Greece into Turkey, they plan to continue into Asia, cross the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas—an open‑ended odyssey “for the following years.”

Mike Brown, England and Harlequins full‑back, has withdrawn from Harlequins’ Aviva Premiership match and remains unsure when he’ll return after suffering a concussion. Having been knocked out against Italy in the Six Nations and experiencing post‑France‑game headaches, he’ll follow a staged, cautious recovery—starting with light bike sessions—rather than risk a longer lay‑off like Johnny Sexton (12 weeks) or Northampton’s George North (ruled out for the season after four concussions). Brown credits World Rugby’s online concussion‑awareness modules with helping him recognise symptoms early, emphasises honesty about head injuries, and spoke about these issues at Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” grassroots rugby campaign.

Since the rise of the internet and smartphones, average monthly sexual frequency among British heterosexual couples has fallen from five times in 1990 and four times in 2000 to three times today, according to Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book Sex by Numbers. Spiegelhalter argues—citing emails and constant connectivity—that technological integration blurs home‑work boundaries, fills formerly idle moments and squeezes out partner time. While more people living alone may play a role, he and researcher Catherine Mercer contend that competing demands and late‑evening work emails leave couples too distracted or busy to prioritize sex.

Once prized as expensive status symbols, Tibetan mastiffs in China—large, loyal herding dogs weighing up to 80 kg—could fetch up to £1.2 million at the peak of a breed boom that began in 2005. A recent government anti‑corruption drive halted the practice of gifting them to officials, while bans in major cities on dogs over 50 kg and rapid urbanization exposed their unsuitability for city life. Overbreeding for profit produced a surplus of poor‑quality animals that now cannot be sold. As demand has collapsed, many mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat or leather; rescues have found dozens crammed, starving and injured en route. Theft by gangs and the off‑loading of “imperfect” dogs mean hundreds more may suffer the same fate.

Leeds‑based insurer Direct Line ran the #everydayfix competition to turn solutions for common “everyday emergencies” into real products via Kickstarter. A survey of 2,000 people ranked their top ten daily stresses (not being able to sleep 46 %, losing keys 37 %, traffic delays 35 %, etc.). London’s Makerversity design teams produced prototypes addressing the top issues. The three shortlisted entries are:

• Snooze (by Instruments): an alarm clock that syncs with your phone to mute notifications for better sleep  
• Forget Me Lock (by ONN Studio): a key‑mounted indicator that swivels green when the door is open and red when locked, viewable remotely  
• Nipper (by Impulse): a pocket‑sized phone charger that clips onto any household battery  

From now until April 40, Twitter users vote for their favorite by retweeting its #everydayfix post; the most popular will be crowdfunded and developed. Direct Line and Makerversity praised the smart, simple designs. Other concepts that fell just short included a bone‑conduction “Hat Nav” cycling helmet, a parking‑space alert pin, and a message‑relay app for dead phone batteries.

In the ongoing Hebron riots—marked in part by settlers’ commemorations of gunman Baruch Goldstein—between 29 and 52 Muslims were killed and over 100 others wounded.
In the ongoing Hebron unrest, settlers commemorated gunman Baruch Goldstein as riots continued, resulting in 29 Muslims killed and over 100 wounded.
As of 26 March, COVID‑19 had been linked to over 21,300 deaths.
As of 27 March, COVID‑19 had been linked to over 26,300 deaths.
As of 28 March, there had been at least 5,138 COVID‑19 deaths, 4,165 patients in intensive care (including 1,312 in the Community of Madrid), and over 350,000 tests performed.
By 28 March, at least 5,812 COVID‑19 deaths had been recorded, 4,165 patients were in intensive care (1,312 of them in the Community of Madrid), and over 350,000 tests had been conducted.
By 29 February, Italy had conducted over 18,500 tests for the virus.
By March 1, Italy had conducted 21,127 tests for the virus.

Qatar Airways, based in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha, operates a hub‑and‑spoke network from Hamad International Airport. Using over 200 aircraft, it serves more than 160 destinations across Africa, Central Asia, Europe, the Far East, South Asia, the Middle East, North and South America, and Oceania.

Qatar Airways, headquartered in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha, operates a hub‑and‑spoke network from its base at Hamad International Airport. Using a fleet of over 200 aircraft, it serves more than 150 destinations across Africa, Central Asia, the Far East, South Asia, the Middle East, Europe, North America, South America and Oceania.
Maxthon is a web browser that ranks as China’s second most popular and has been downloaded over 400 million times worldwide.
Maxthon is China’s second most popular browser and has been downloaded over 500 million times worldwide.
Worldwide, among the reported cases, more than 16,700 people have died and over 102,000 have recovered.
Globally, there have been over 392,000 reported cases, more than 17,100 deaths, and upwards of 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson reignited his public spat with Andros Townsend after Townsend was brought on in the 83rd minute of Tottenham’s 0‑0 draw with Burnley, tweeting “did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes.” Merson had earlier angered Townsend by writing that if Townsend could make the England squad “it opens it up to anybody.” Townsend hit back on Twitter after scoring England’s equaliser in a 1‑1 friendly draw with Italy, mocking Merson’s critique of his international place. Although Merson later admitted he was wrong—praised the goal and held up his hands—he still couldn’t resist another dig following Townsend’s brief Burnley cameo.

Chelsea have submitted a formal £4 million bid for 22‑year‑old FC Tokyo and Japan international forward Yoshinori Muto, aiming to complete the transfer this summer. If the deal proceeds, Muto would be loaned to Chelsea’s Dutch partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, for next season. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane stresses Chelsea’s interest is unrelated to their recent £200 million, five‑year shirt‑sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre maker Yokohama Rubber. Since signing his first professional contract in 2014, Muto has made 37 J‑League appearances (16 goals), earned 11 caps (one goal) for Japan and been named in the league’s Best XI after scoring 13 times in his debut season. A Keio University economics graduate as of two weeks ago, Muto has scored three goals in four games this campaign but says he has yet to decide whether to accept Chelsea’s offer.

A large-scale Finnish study of over 12,000 healthy two‑year‑olds, published in Pediatrics, found that infants given antibiotics in their first six months—and those with repeated prescriptions before age two—were more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with boys showing the greatest weight—and slight height—increases. The researchers suggest antibiotics may promote weight gain by disrupting gut bacteria that normally consume calories and help regulate appetite. While causation isn’t proven, lead author Dr. Antti Saari warned that early and frequent antibiotic use “was associated with increased body mass in healthy children” and could contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic. Previous studies have also linked infant antibiotic exposure to higher risks of eczema and digestive problems, and growing over‑prescription raises concerns about antibiotic resistance.

A Queen’s Guard at Buckingham Palace slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, knocking his bearskin, dropping his rifle and falling in front of hundreds of tourists. Holidaymaker David Meadwell captured the entire incident on video, prompting gasps as the embarrassed soldier quickly scrambled to his feet. The slip was blamed on metal protectors nailed to his boots. The daily summer ceremony (held every other day in winter) features two detachments under the Captain of The Queen’s Guard—fully operational soldiers, not merely ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the guard’s tumble.

A&E Networks, Lifetime and History will jointly simulcast in 2016 a new, “original” and “contemporary” remake of the 1977 miniseries Roots—Alex Haley’s saga of Kunta Kinte and his descendants, which originally drew over 100 million viewers. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the 1977 version, serves as co‑executive producer alongside Mark Wolper, son of the original’s producer. This adaptation will more closely follow Haley’s novel and enlist African and African‑American history scholars for authenticity. Network executives say the goal is to honor longtime fans and introduce Kinte’s story to a generation shaped by Obama’s presidency, 12 Years a Slave and ongoing racial debates.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 he was pinned to a chair, groped and threatened by several male staff who tried to force him into a sexual orgy. The 27‑year‑old, then working for the Queen Mother’s household, escaped, resigned immediately and says his complaint was met with hostility and ignored. Haunted by the incident, he wrote to the Palace last year amid wider inquiries into historic VIP child‑sex abuse; after two rebuffs his case was finally sent to Scotland Yard. A retired aide has denied involvement. The Palace now says it will “exhaustively and co‑operatively” assist any police investigation; Scotland Yard declines to comment.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video parodying the ’90s Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air theme. Filmed over five takes as they drove around Happy Valley, Oregon, the clip riffs on conceiving in two months, discovering a positive test (“Now we’re three, not a pair”) and ends with a sonogram reveal. Originally made to tell distant loved ones, it’s garnered over 1.7 million YouTube views. Jesse, a great‑great‑grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and Melissa may follow up with a gender‑reveal video. Melissa had earlier captured Jesse’s reaction via a dog‑tag announcement, and a Pennsylvania couple made a similar Fresh Prince–style pregnancy video last year.

At a Beverly Hills Heritage Auctions sale, Vivien Leigh’s costume from the 1939 classic Gone With the Wind—a slate blue‑gray jacket and skirt ensemble now faded to light gray—sold for $137,000. It was one of more than 150 items from James Tumblin’s private collection; Tumblin, formerly Universal Studios’ hair and makeup chief, bought the dress for $20 in the 1960s and amassed over 300,000 Hollywood artifacts. Other top lots included Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit ($55,000) and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The auction marked the film’s 75th anniversary and honored stars like Hattie McDaniel, the first African‑American Oscar winner.

At the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday around 3 p.m., a two‑year‑old boy slipped from his mother’s arms while she dangled him over the cheetah exhibit railing and fell 10–12 feet into the pit. His parents rescued him before firefighters and paramedics arrived; he suffered minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury and remains in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach or harm him. Zoo officials, citing eyewitness reports, say the child was indeed dangled over the railing, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed after the incident.

A bright yellow Gatso speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham—switched off along with some 300 fixed cameras in the West Midlands in March 2013 when their technology became obsolete—has been mysteriously turned to face a private house. Since 2013, speed enforcement in the region has relied on a few mobile units, motorway cameras and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council, now aware of the misaligned, non‑functioning device, will send an engineer and may remove it; it will not be included in their upcoming digital‑technology pilot. The homeowners could not be reached for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six‑time Olympic gold medallist, will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced. Bolt said he’s “fit, healthy and ready to run,” praised last year’s meet atmosphere and Jamaica’s relay tradition, and vowed to “make the country proud.” JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed the world’s fastest man to the squad and promised “sprint magic” in the Bahamas. The full Jamaican team list will be released shortly.

Neymar and team‑mate Dani Alves attended Barcelona’s EuroLeague basketball El Clásico against Real Madrid on Thursday, joined by Neymar’s sister Rafaella, as Barça secured an 85‑80 win. Despite the defeat, Real Madrid remain top of their EuroLeague group on points difference. Earlier, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1‑0 friendly victory over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, surviving several heavy challenges. Before the international break, Luis Enrique’s Barcelona had beaten Real Madrid in the football El Clásico to move four points clear atop La Liga. Neymar and his Barça team‑mates return to league action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they chase a treble.

Italy’s coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants between Friday and Monday, fielding SOS calls Monday from 20 boats. Save the Children says 400 may be missing after survivors reported a 550‑person vessel capsized 80 miles off Libya; the coast guard, however, has found no evidence of such an incident. Migrant crossings to Italy have surged: the International Organization for Migration recorded over 10,000 arrivals in January–March 2015 and about 2,000 rescued in one April weekend in the Sicily Channel. Most migrants hail from West Africa, Somalia and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 have died this year—often due to bad weather, overcrowding and crew abandonment—and last week 978 were rescued in a single day.

Arsène Wenger says only Alexis Sanchez knows why he chose Arsenal over Liverpool, but he’s delighted the £32 million Chilean signed for the Emirates. After Barcelona let him leave, Sanchez was persuaded post‑World Cup to join Wenger’s side, immediately making an impact in England with 19 goals so far. Wenger admits Liverpool’s reported interest may have been used as leverage in Barcelona’s Luis Suárez talks. He praises Sanchez’s quality, work‑rate and game‑changing ability. Ahead of Arsenal’s clash with Liverpool, Wenger downplays any interest in Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers for rebuilding his team after Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, four‑time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt cycling’s prestigious hour record on June 7 at London’s Lee Valley VeloPark. Turning 35 in April, he aims to surpass Australian Rohan Dennis’ current mark of 52.491 km set in February under new UCI rules. Having closed his Team Sky career at Paris‑Roubaix, Wiggins will ride the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on the track. He expects a 6,000‑seat sell‑out—tickets (£49/£39/£29) go on sale April 19—and the bid will be shown live on Sky Sports. Meanwhile, Briton Alex Dowsett will make his own attempt on May 2 in Manchester.

Serena Williams, world No. 1 and two‑time French Open champion, admitted her 4‑6 7‑6(3) 6‑3 Fed Cup play‑off win over Sara Errani was a “big eye‑opener,” saying tough weather and clay unfamiliarity exposed her lack of readiness. Though she improved her head‑to‑head with Errani to 8‑0, Williams and Alison Riske were hammered 6‑0 6‑3 in the doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, costing the US a 3‑2 defeat and relegation to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez urged harder work despite having many top‑100 players, aiming to regain elite status next year.

River Plate have expressed interest in re‑signing 29‑year‑old Colombia striker Radamel Falcao, though admit a deal would be complex. Vice‑president Matias Patanian said, “We dream of Falcao… the doors are open.” Falcao spent eight years at River Plate (2001–09), scoring 34 goals in 90 Primera División appearances. Currently on loan at Manchester United, he has struggled this season with just four Premier League goals, and it’s unclear whether United will buy him or he’ll return to Monaco. Internationally, he’s in strong form, netting three times in two games to equal Colombia’s all‑time record of 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the 19‑year‑old X Factor finalist and pop star, has been named the official face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry‑shampoo campaign—her first-ever brand endorsement. Shot by the MILES agency against a blurred city backdrop, the international campaign showcases Henderson in various hairstyles and outfits and launched with a TV spot featuring her single “Mirror Man.” A regular Batiste user, she expressed excitement about the partnership, which her manager Mark Hargreaves praised as a natural fit between a platinum‑award artist and the UK’s top dry‑shampoo brand.

In Kenosha, Wisconsin, the Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres and his dog, thanking the community for its support after Torres fatally shot 26‑year‑old Aaron Siler on March 14. Torres—now on leave—had confronted Siler, who was wanted on a felony warrant and allegedly armed himself during a vehicle and foot pursuit. Siler’s family and friends, led by family friend Kathy Willie, condemned the billboard as “disrespectful” and called for its removal, saying it felt like a celebration of his death. The association insists the billboard was simply an expression of gratitude, while the state Division of Criminal Investigation continues to probe Siler’s shooting; a previous Torres shooting of a 66‑year‑old man with knives ten days earlier was ruled justified by the district attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed Monday in clashes with militants who crossed into southeastern Iran’s Sistan‑Baluchestan province from Pakistan; Iranian forces killed three of the attackers. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal—active in Pakistan’s Balochistan region, targeting Shiites and opposing Iranian influence—claimed responsibility. Tehran has urged Islamabad to apprehend the survivors, accusing Pakistan of failing to curb such cross‑border attacks. Islamabad condemned the incident as terrorism, says it is investigating on its territory and will prosecute any militants found there.

CNN reports that during a session of Japan’s Diet, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani said the Air Self‑Defense Force has never encountered a UFO of extraterrestrial origin—though it will scramble jets to visually inspect any unidentified flying object, which has so far turned out to be birds or other mundane objects. His remarks came in response to flamboyant Upper House member Antonio Inoki—a former pro wrestler, WWE star, mixed‑discipline pioneer, New Japan Pro Wrestling founder and colorful political figure—who asked whether jets had ever met alien threats or if research into alien visitors is underway; Inoki himself claims to have seen a UFO but isn’t sure aliens exist. This exchange echoes a 2007 debate in which then‑Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the constitutional legality of defending against an invasion from outer space.

A 35‑year‑old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after a porcelain toilet he was standing on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed. He had stood on the rim to avoid sitting on a “possibly unclean” seat, telephoned friends for help when injured, and received dozens of stitches in hospital. He initially admitted to squatting but later told police he was merely sitting—apparently to limit liability. Authorities ruled it an accident and reminded travelers that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15‑year‑old girl discovered a hidden bathroom camera under her sink. Prosecutors say Rebbie secretly filmed the girl undressing and showering over a three‑ to four‑year span—beginning when she was nine—and molested her in her bedroom from ages nine to 13. Investigators recovered 41 videos (34 showing victims showering), some with close‑ups of children’s genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. He admitted filming multiple juveniles but bought the camera specifically to record the now‑15‑year‑old. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy. His preliminary hearing is May 1; bail is set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new series, published as a book roughly titled Daughter and Salaryman, pairs po-faced teenage daughters in casual clothes with their sharply suited fathers captured mid‑air in dynamic—and sometimes comically pained—leaps against various Japanese landmarks. By turning the normally serious “salaryman” into a leaping, hero‑like figure, Aoyama aims to reveal fathers’ playful side, and the quirky portraits have already drawn widespread online interest.

Following Paul Downton’s dismissal as England’s managing director, attention has turned to the start of the county championship as Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially dropped by Downton in 2014, posed for Surrey’s season‑opening photo at The Kia Oval. Sitting thoughtfully at the end of the front row yet joking with photographers and teammates—including Chris Tremlett, Stuart Meaker, Jason Roy and Jade Dernbach—Pietersen looks to force his way back into England’s Test side. Surrey begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19 and face Oxford MCCU on Sunday, as Pietersen bids to return to international cricket ahead of this summer’s Ashes on home soil.

Romanian side Ceahlăul Piatra Neamț, 16th in the table and six points from safety, have sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. The 41‑year‑old former Inter Milan and Parma right‑back, capped 25 times by Brazil, was dismissed on Wednesday, reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, then axed again after Saturday’s 2‑0 loss to mid‑table FC Botoșani. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January as Ceahlăul’s third coach this season, will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinović.

Nabil Dirar, who played alongside Radamel Falcao at Monaco, says the striker must now regret his season‐long loan to Manchester United. Falcao, still struggling to recapture pre–knee injury form, has scored just four goals and United, facing a £46 million fee to buy him, are unlikely to make the move permanent. Dirar adds that, despite not feeling happy in France, Falcao would have benefited from staying at Monaco—where he’d have Champions League football and regular game time—though the Colombian may also have craved a more vibrant atmosphere.

New Zealand police are seeking help to identify a very tall man who robbed the Union Street dairy in east Christchurch at about 12:30 pm last Saturday. Security footage shows him wearing a fluoro‑orange sweatshirt and a distinctive oversized cartoon mask. He threatened the owner’s daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, then fled with the till drawer and up to $1,500 in cash. No weapon was seen. Anyone with information is urged to call Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or contact police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after a 15‑year‑old student reported that in April she kissed him and let him touch her breasts. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. On Monday she was arrested again after a second 15‑year‑old pupil accused her of having sex with him on January 18 and 19 in her car near another Dallas school. She was booked into the Irving County Jail, released on $50,000 bail, and it’s not yet known how she will plead. The school district says it took immediate action and her leave prevents any contact with students or district property.

A tourist in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, captured video of a large American crocodile gliding through the marina with a dead black dog—owned by a local bike­shop proprietor—in its jaws. New Zealander Tim Weston and his wife watched as the croc lingered for hours near the water’s edge, drawing a horrified crowd before disappearing. The clip has been viewed over 500,000 times on Facebook, prompting comments like “horrible” and “I hate crocodiles now.” Such sightings are common in Puerto Vallarta, which sits amid mangrove habitat and a nearby crocodile sanctuary; urbanization has brought these animals, which can grow up to six meters long, into ever-closer contact with people.

Steve Bruce insists Hull can still avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat at Southampton that leaves them just two points above the drop zone with six games to play – including trips to Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Bruce had aimed for ten wins but has managed only six; he believes “eight or nine might be enough” if the squad can stay positive. He attributes Hull’s struggles to long‑term injuries to key players (Diame, Chester just returning; Dawson, Jelavic and Snodgrass largely sidelined) but points to three strong years—promotion, a cup final and last season’s survival—as proof of their resilience. At St Mary’s, James Ward‑Prowse converted a penalty and Graziano Pelle scored late, while manager Ronald Koeman had to reprimand Sadio Mané for attempting to take that spot‑kick, saying he’ll remind the squad that “team rules cannot be broken by anyone.”

Ian Guffick, a 31‑year‑old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, let pupils—and even altered some himself—change their 11‑year‑olds’ SATs answers after the exam session had ended. A local authority investigation, prompted by a tip‑off, confirmed the breach, and the Department for Education annulled the school’s entire 2014 SATs results. Guffick admitted unacceptable professional conduct (though he said he was merely improving legibility), and a misconduct panel deemed his actions dishonest. Acting for Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, Paul Heathcote imposed a minimum two‑year teaching ban; Guffick has 28 days to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, who has managed just 19 Premier League appearances for Manchester United since joining from Aalesunds in 2010 and is now third‑choice behind David de Gea and Víctor Valdés, has found happier times off the pitch. The Danish keeper married Swedish model Misse Beqiri—who has Albanian roots and over 17,000 Instagram followers—after dating since 2012; they wed in a beach ceremony in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Lindegaard often shares snapshots of their life, most recently a relaxed day in Cheshire, even as he faces an uncertain future at Old Trafford following a collapsed January move to FC Midtjylland.

At Sotheby’s auction, 13 glowing blue letters that had topped Yankee Stadium from 1976 until its final 2008 game went unsold despite a $300,000–$600,000 estimate; the only bid—$260,000—came from a Sotheby’s employee. The 10‑foot‑tall letters are owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought them “on a lark” after the stadium closed, attended the sale, and had vowed to fly out to visit any U.S. buyer. Separately, a late‑1960s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling’s and Jordon Ibe’s recent off‑field lapses—Sterling was filmed inhaling nitrous oxide and both were seen using shisha—reminding them of their responsibilities as professionals. He met with them, but will not impose formal discipline and wants to draw a line under the matter. His immediate focus is Sunday’s FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa at Wembley, for which Steven Gerrard returns from a three‑match ban (though Rodgers has yet to confirm his inclusion). Reflecting on past near‑misses in the title race and cup competitions, Rodgers stressed that learning from defeat is integral to eventual success.

Mesut Özil returned to London after helping Germany to a 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia and shared a “Home Sweet Home” photo relaxing with his dog. The £42.5 million signing from Real Madrid in 2013 missed Arsenal’s recent win at Newcastle through illness—rumoured nightclub sightings were denied by Arsène Wenger—but has since hit form, contributing three goals and four assists after his injury lay‑off. Ozil says he “fits perfectly” into English football’s demanding schedule of frequent fixtures and no winter break.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has ruled out replacing coach Luis Enrique, saying the club are “very happy” with him. Enrique, who signed a two‑year deal last summer and is under contract until 2016, has Barcelona six games from the La Liga title and still in contention for three trophies. Bartomeu praised Enrique’s preparation—especially after the Champions League trip to PSG—and his work ahead of Saturday’s 2‑0 win over Valencia, in which Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi scored.

Liverpool vice‑captain Jordan Henderson has agreed a new deal keeping him at Anfield until summer 2020 on improved terms reportedly worth around £100,000 a week. The 24‑year‑old, signed from Sunderland in 2011 for £16 million, has been one of Brendan Rodgers’s most improved players this season, contributing seven goals and 13 assists from midfield. Henderson’s contract negotiations—underway since the season began with 14 months left on his previous deal—make him the third key player to commit long‑term after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is also the leading candidate to succeed Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy this summer. Talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the end of the season, though Liverpool’s chief executive Ian Ayre expects the England forward to remain at the club. Up to ten players could yet leave before the campaign ends.

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea on a three‑year deal last July but has struggled to secure the left‑back spot, says he is “happy at Chelsea” and intends to see out his contract despite Atletico Madrid’s interest in re‑signing him. After featuring for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, he and the rest of Chelsea now turn their attention to the nine remaining, “really difficult” Premier League fixtures, where manager José Mourinho demands full focus and a win‑by‑win mentality.

Nathan Hughes’s original three‑match ban for accidentally striking George North with his knee as he scored for Northampton on March 27 has been overturned on appeal. Although Hughes was sent off and suspended after North was knocked unconscious (his third concussion in two months), the Wasps successfully argued there was no intent or foul play. Intense criticism of the suspension—from teammates James Haskell and Andy Goode and former players Austin Healey and Joe Marler—helped prompt the appeal. An independent panel, citing fresh evidence, ruled the collision was purely accidental, rescinded the red card and cleared Hughes to return immediately. He sat out Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter‑final defeat to Toulon but, absent from the squad for Saturday’s Premiership trip to London Welsh, is now expected back for the April 26 visit of Exeter. Chairman Jeremy Summers stated that, on review, “no act of foul play took place.”

Seattle photographer Tim Durkan captured a deep red sunset over the city, part of an “amber haze” now visible across Oregon, Washington and British Columbia. The coloration comes from smoke carried on Pacific winds from grass‐fire–started wildfires in southeastern Siberia that, fanned by strong April 14 winds, quickly grew out of control, destroyed dozens of villages and were later extinguished. Smoke particles filter out shorter wavelengths (greens, blues, yellows, purples), letting reds and oranges prevail—an effect amplified at sunrise and sunset by the longer atmospheric path. As the smoke clears, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets’ intensity will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her brand‑new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway just over a month after purchase. On April 1, police recovered it thanks to a tip from Mick Sexton—but the thieves had spray‑painted the rims red, added red side accents and orange steering‑wheel highlights. Instead of anger, Schoenig posted on Facebook joking “I want to thank the car thieves for pimping out my vehicle…this b***h is pimpin now!” She’s having the car professionally cleaned to remove cigarette and marijuana odors. To honor Sexton, she’s debuting a “Sexton on Wheels” smoothie—banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream—at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. A friend describes Schoenig as “vibrant and happy” with a great sense of humor.

Manchester City’s star players – including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Touré – each stand to lose £500,000 in bonuses (around £12 million in total) if the team fails to reach the Champions League group stages, an incentive built into their contracts to satisfy Financial Fair Play rules. Under Manuel Pellegrini they have slipped to fourth place after seven defeats this year, including early FA Cup and Champions League exits, and now must secure at least a top‑four finish (top three qualify automatically; fourth enters a play‑off). With six matches remaining, City also face a transfer‑market battle with Manchester United for targets such as Paul Pogba.

Manchester United’s Under‑18s beat Manchester City’s 1‑0 in a “mini‑derby” at Altrincham’s Moss Lane on Saturday, in front of ~1,000 free‑entry spectators. United deployed a first‑team‑style three‑at‑the‑back formation, fielding 13 English players (10 Mancunians). City’s Marcus Wood and United’s Marcus Rashford both squandered early chances before England U17 Callum Gribbin curled home the winner from a free‑kick just before the hour. Cameron Borthwick‑Jackson rattled the bar and post with a long drive, while late City efforts from Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun went wide or struck the woodwork. The victory leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, and showcased several homegrown talents—echoing FA chief Greg Dyke’s call for more senior opportunities for 18–21‑year‑olds.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italy’s Gianluigi Buffon as “a legend of the game” and an inspiration after Buffon won his 147th cap in a 1–1 draw. Hart, who celebrated his own 50th England appearance in that match, said he’s still learning by watching Buffon’s example at age 37. He expressed pride in reaching 50 caps and ambition to continue playing well for club and country to add more.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food‐delivery market by partnering with Postmates to offer online and mobile delivery in 67 U.S. cities. Orders will incur a nine‑percent service charge plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 (varying by distance and demand). Until now Chipotle had declined third‑party delivery offers; Postmates uses independent contractors in an Uber‑style model. The move comes as other chains—Starbucks (Seattle, New York), Taco Bell, McDonald’s (“McDelivery”) and Burger King (via bkdelivers.com)—also roll out delivery tests. Celebrity diners Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have each been spotted at Chipotle locations this month.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8‑year‑old Martin Richard—the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings—have asked the Justice Department not to seek the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 related charges. In a front‑page Boston Globe opinion piece, they describe the loss of their son, their daughter’s severe injuries, and years of ongoing surgeries and grief. They propose that Tsarnaev be sentenced to life in prison without parole and waive all appeals, arguing that pursuing capital punishment would extend their family’s agony. The Richards stress they speak only for themselves and hope ending the death‑penalty pursuit will help their remaining children and the broader community move forward.

A mystery billionaire spent £400 million and three years converting a Boeing 747‑8—normally a 600‑seat airliner—into a one‑of‑a‑kind flying residence. The ultra‑luxury jet holds just its owner and dozens of guests in hotel‑style suites, lounges, a conference room, an onboard restaurant with private chef’s kitchen, a top‑deck “aeroloft” with eight beds, a master bedroom, multiple state rooms and lounges, and an office/guest cabin—all artfully reconfigured in place of standard passenger rows.

SpaceX on Tuesday launched a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station. Dragon, loaded with over 4,300 lb of supplies—including research gear and an “ISSpresso” coffee maker—will dock in about two days. In its first attempt to land the booster on a floating drone ship, the rocket touched down but tipped over and was destroyed (a similar attempt in January also failed).
