10. Harem trousers—championed by Kim Kardashian in 2009—still appear on Elle Macpherson.

Together, these examples highlight how boldly nostalgic elements of 90s/00s fashion have been re‑adopted by today’s celebrities.

CNN’s weekly roundup of viral moments included: in New York, CEO Amanda Curtis captured four rainbows arching across the sky after heavy rain; China’s latest anti‑vice campaign bans exotic dancers at wakes; Robert Downey Jr. bristled when a UK interviewer probed his private life; the “#KylieJennerChallenge” saw people lip‑plumping by jar suction; 102‑year‑old Alice Barker teamed with filmmakers to “go back in time”; a bomb‑themed prom proposal was rejected by one school amid racism claims; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumière in Disney’s Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; one couple announced their pregnancy with a Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air nod; and a military dad photobombed his son’s portrait.

The Miami Open has begun marking player milestones with giant cakes—first celebrating Andy Murray’s 500th career win, then wheeling one out for Serena Williams’s 700th after she beat Sabine Lisicki 7‑6, 1‑6, 6‑3 in the quarter‑finals. Williams, the world No. 1 playing near her home base, avenged her shock 2013 Wimbledon loss to Lisicki and moved into the semis. A potential all‑Williams showdown ended when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro, and Serena now faces third seed Simona Halep—who defeated Sloane Stephens 6‑1, 7‑5—for a spot in the final.

Sabeen Mahmud ran T2F, a brightly painted café‑gallery on a Karachi industrial road where she hosted discussions on technology, human rights and women’s entrepreneurship and promoted secular, progressive culture. Despite death threats, she had just convened a banned university debate on Balochistan’s mass disappearances when, late Friday, two gunmen shot her dead at point‑blank range, wounding her mother. No one has claimed responsibility or given a motive. Mahmud—hailed as a symbol of free speech, humanism and tolerance—shocked Pakistan’s nonviolent and progressive communities. Online and artistic tributes praised her warmth, courage and vision for a just, open society. T2F’s graffiti‑sprayed walls and homey atmosphere embodied her mission to create rare public space for fearless dialogue in a climate of fear.

Mangu Ram, an 82‑year‑old Hindu healer in Jammu, has lived as a West Pakistan Refugee (WPR) for nearly 70 years, having fled Punjab during the 1947 partition. Although most of the roughly 100,000 WPRs have never been to Pakistan, Jammu and Kashmir’s successive governments have denied them “state‑subject” rights—property ownership, voting in state elections and state government jobs—fearing any shift in the region’s Muslim‑majority demographic. Trapped in slum settlements, three generations of WPR families remain mired in poverty and barred from state‑run colleges. Under a pre‑independence law, only those born in the former princely state qualify for citizenship, yet about 35,000 Hindus who fled from Pakistan‑administered Kashmir have been naturalized. After December’s state election, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party joined the ruling coalition and pledged to normalize WPR status. Refugee activists, hopeful but cautious, warn they will protest if promised reforms do not materialize. Source: Associated Press.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto has confirmed he’s weighing a summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea after club president Naoki Ogane revealed a reported £4 million bid, with Chelsea planning to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem. The 22‑year‑old insists he will only join a team where he can play regularly and continue his development. His former coach at FC Tokyo, Ranko Popović, has lauded Muto’s speed, intelligence and confidence, calling him an outstanding prospect. Chelsea manager José Mourinho said he knows “a little” about Muto but declined to comment further on a player from another club, emphasizing that transfers are guided by both financial‑fair‑play considerations (including a recent £200 million Yokohama sponsorship) and genuine sporting need.

Australia’s decision to drop its ban on overseas‑based players—allowing stars like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell back into Wallabies contention—recognizes the modern, global nature of rugby. England, by contrast, still bars England‑eligible players who ply their trade abroad, a stance Stuart Lancaster has maintained despite clear evidence (e.g. Toulon’s Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon and even Jonny Wilkinson) that moving to top foreign clubs can improve performances. The article argues that for England to field its strongest side at the home World Cup, boost squad morale and honor the tournament’s “best‑of‑the‑world” ideal, it must follow Australia, South Africa and Wales in selecting England‑qualified players regardless of where they play.

Open Garden’s FireChat app lets users send encrypted, anonymous messages and photos off the grid by turning each phone into a node in a Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi direct “mesh” network. Launched with Apple’s iOS 7 multipeer‑connectivity framework (and a similar Android feature), it offers “nearby” chats (within ~30 ft/9 m) and an “everyone” mode that relays messages hop‑by‑hop up to ~200 ft (61 m). FireChat has over five million downloads and is popular where cellular or Wi‑Fi are unavailable or unreliable. To extend its range, Open Garden is developing Greenstone, an egg‑shaped beacon that stores up to 1,000 messages, runs for a year on battery, and forwards messages when another FireChat device comes within about 20 ft (6 m). Greenstone aims to bolster resilient communication in communities, events, protests or emergencies; commercial release depends on manufacturing partnerships.

In her recent TED Talk, New Jersey burlesque performer Lillian Bustle reclaimed “fat” as a neutral, body‑positive self‑descriptor—alongside “short” and “wife”—arguing it need not imply ugliness. She cited a 66 % rise in workplace size discrimination over 30 years and noted that girls’ top “magic wish” is to be thinner, yet studies show exposure to diverse bodies increases acceptance. Since starting burlesque in 2012 at 240 lbs, she’s found performing empowering and recommends everyone identify a personal “courage reference” to boost self‑esteem. Her talk, posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback—including stories of viewers rethinking their body image—affirming her belief that body positivity is winning.

Arsenal winger Theo Walcott, 26, who has been named among the substitutes in 17 of the club’s 33 Premier League games this season and made only a six‑minute cameo in the recent 0‑0 draw with Chelsea, joined six team‑mates—Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Özil—and runway model Olga Sherer for an official portrait by Paris fashion house Lanvin, Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013. The first‑team squad will wear the same Lanvin outfits for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa at Wembley on May 30. Walcott, unused as a starter since Arsenal’s 3‑0 win over West Ham on March 14, hopes to regain a place in the XI at Hull City next Monday.

Legendary make‑up effects artist Rick Baker is selling 417 props and puppets from his Cinovation Studio—spanning more than 50 films—at a no‑reserve auction on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online via PropStore.com. The collection is valued at about $746,100 in total and includes highlights such as:

• Edgar bug from Men in Black (est. $40,000)  
• “Mikey” alien from Men in Black (est. $30,000)  
• Jim Carrey’s Grinch costume (est. $8,000)  
• Two‑Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500)  
• Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons (est. $6,000)  
• Various Gremlins 2 puppets (each around $6,000–$8,000)  
• Frosty, the frozen thug from Batman & Robin (est. $4,000)  
• Worm Guy from Men in Black II (est. $10,000)  
• Michael Jackson’s robotic face from Moonwalker (est. $3,000)  
• Hero Joe head from Mighty Joe Young (est. $6,000)

Over his 30‑year career, Baker also worked on classics like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy and Michael Jackson’s Thriller. Prop Store’s Brandon Alinger calls the sale “an exciting opportunity for collectors and fans to own a piece of Hollywood history.”

Seven‑year‑old Carwyn Scott‑Howell from Talybont‑on‑Usk, Wales, was killed in the French Alps on 15 February after separating from his mother and sister on the resort of Flaine’s last run of the day. A competent skier and snowboarder who began skiing at three and idolised TV adventurer Bear Grylls, he pressed on ahead when his nine‑year‑old sister’s ski came off, left the piste into dense woodland, and fell 164 ft. Police traced his footprints—and sliding marks from his descent—to find his body.

Carwyn’s family described him as “daring, outgoing and determined” with a “handsome smile” that “lit up any room,” saying his death “has left a vast void in our hearts.” His body is to be repatriated while his school, community and local councillors in Wales mourn him as a “lively, likeable pupil” whose loss has devastated friends, teachers and neighbours.

Laura Scurr, a 15‑year‑old from Whitley Bay, developed severe anorexia at age 13 after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressure to be a “size zero.” At her worst she survived on as little as one piece of fruit (about 100 calories) a day, hid food, and lied to her mother until her heart rate slowed, she collapsed, and spent a week on a heart monitor. With help from eating‑disorder organisations and CAMHS, she’s now recovering, regained a healthy body image, and reached the semi‑final of Miss Teen GB, which promotes positive, confidence‑building experiences for girls. The passage also notes that anorexia nervosa is a serious mental health condition marked by extreme food restriction, affecting around 725,000 people in the UK, and urges gentle intervention and specialist support for sufferers.

Liverpool officially unveiled their 2015/16 home kit—the first under a record £300 million, four‑year deal with New Balance—at Anfield’s Centenary Stand. Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel, Simon Mignolet, Adam Lallana, Jordan Henderson and Philippe Coutinho modeled the new gingham‑style shirt, which features all‑white branding, a revised collar and a “96” Hillsborough tribute. Legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush also attended.

Fans publicly urged Sterling to stay at the club after he rejected a reported £100,000‑a‑week contract extension and acknowledged Arsenal interest, but Liverpool insist the 20‑year‑old—with two years left on his deal—will not leave this summer. Players spoke of the “massive boost” of Anfield’s support as they prepare for the FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa at Wembley, hoping a cup win will spark further success. Steven Gerrard, though departing, still aims to bow out in the final on his May 31 birthday.

University of Manchester researchers led by Dr Sarah Bridle have released the first high‑definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4 percent of the sky (about 150 full‑moon areas), based on two years of galaxy‑shape measurements from the Dark Energy Survey’s 570‑megapixel camera on the 4 m Blanco telescope at CTIO. Using gravitational lensing to detect the invisible substance that makes up roughly 80–85 percent of cosmic matter, the map reveals clumps and filaments of dark matter that align with galaxy locations and cosmic voids. Generated from 130 million images and millions of hours of supercomputer time (to measure distortions to one part in 1 000), it was unveiled at the April APS meeting in Baltimore. This is the first of a five‑year effort—due to complete by 2018—to map 12.5 percent of the sky in three dimensions, thereby probing galaxy formation processes and the nature of dark energy through the evolution of dark‑matter clumpiness.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21‑year‑old Dutch winger Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay, who thrived under van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup—scoring against Australia and Chile—has enjoyed a prolific Eredivisie season, netting 20 goals in 26 league games to help PSV claim their first Dutch title in seven years. PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands confirmed interest not only from United but also Paris Saint‑Germain and another major European club, with PSV valuing Depay well above the £15 million Tottenham bid of last summer. A product of VV Moordrecht, Sparta Rotterdam and PSV’s academy, Depay has made over 100 senior appearances. Fast, skillful and known for his dribbling and powerful right‑foot shot, he’s been compared to Arjen Robben and even a young Cristiano Ronaldo, though he’s still refining his decision‑making on the ball.

Chelsea’s youth side beat Manchester City 3-1 at the Academy Stadium to take a commanding lead back to West London in the Youth Cup tie. Tammy Abraham netted twice—first with a fierce drive and then an acrobatic finish—to give Chelsea a 2-1 half‑time advantage after Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts had briefly pegged City level. Dominic Solanke added a late third to seal the victory. Chelsea’s defence, marshalled by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke‑Salter and backed by keeper Bradley Collins, limited City’s chances. Manchester City youngsters like Tosin Adarabioyo, Brandon Barker and Aaron Nemane showed promise but squandered openings under Chelsea’s pressure.

Marco Rubio, a new presidential candidate, says sexual orientation is innate but that marriage—defined as one man and one woman—should be regulated by state legislatures, not guaranteed as a constitutional right. He told CBS’s Face the Nation he opposes court‑mandated same‑sex marriage but would attend the wedding of a family member or staffer even if he disagrees. As a Catholic, he likewise views divorce as wrong yet wouldn’t stop loving someone who divorces. Rubio announced his run last week and has already attracted over $51 million in donor commitments.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian Ilze Zebolde (31) quit their Manchester restaurant jobs in 2014 and set off from London on an open‑ended, low‑budget world tour by bicycle. In 356 days they’ve ridden nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries—France (west and south coasts), Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia‑Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey (entire northern coast), Georgia and Armenia—and plan to press onward into Asia, cross the Pacific, then cycle the length of the Americas. With no set itinerary, they average just €0.10 per kilometre (under €3 per person per day), camping under the stars (161 nights), using free hosts via Couchsurfing and Warmshowers (110 nights total), and relying on pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce—and occasional dumpster foraging—for food. Their journey, fueled by simple gear and a spirit of discovery, has taken them from the Alps and Sierra Nevada to Greek seasides and Turkish tunnels, and they expect to remain on the road for years to come.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 say their wedding photo‑booth operator, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed the racial slur “poor n***** party” on their Bell Tower (Houston) snapshots. They only learned of it months later when the bride’s sister came forward. Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, they’ve sued under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the claim, refused to apologize—telling them “sue me”—and says there’s no proof his service produced the caption or that the couple suffered mental anguish. The couple insists they want only an apology; mediation is tomorrow, with trial set for July if no settlement is reached.

Mike Brown, England and Harlequins full‑back, says he will adopt a cautious, stage‑by‑stage recovery from his latest concussion—unsure when he’ll return after withdrawing from Harlequins’ Premiership match at Wembley. He suffered headaches after France in the Six Nations and was knocked out against Italy in February, derailing his planned comeback for the Ireland game in March. Brown refuses to risk a prolonged lay‑off like Northampton’s George North (advised to end his season after four recent concussions) or Ireland’s Johnny Sexton, and credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules with teaching him to recognise symptoms and be honest about them. He made his comments at the launch of Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2032 grassroots campaign.

Since the internet’s arrival, Britons’ monthly sex frequency has fallen from about five times (1990) to four (2000) and now three, according to Prof. David Spiegelhalter’s book Sex by Numbers. He argues that constant smartphone and email use has blurred work‑home boundaries and eaten into the “empty” private time couples once had. Other factors include more people living alone and ever‑rising competing demands—late‑night work emails in particular—so that, as researcher Catherine Mercer puts it, “sex just falls down our list of priorities.”

Tibetan mastiffs—heavy, loyal herding dogs weighing up to 80 kg—saw a dramatic crash in China’s market. Just over a year ago a puppy sold for £1.2 million, but an anti‑corruption campaign (which ended the practice of gifting expensive dogs to officials) and city bans on dogs over 50 kg have all but wiped out demand. Dozens are now rounded up, sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather, stolen by gangs or discarded by breeders after profiteering cross‑breeding degraded the breed’s quality. A recent rescue of 20 mastiffs bound for slaughter—with many already dead or injured—highlights the scale of the crisis, exacerbated by rapid urbanization making the breed impractical for city living.

A poll of 600 women in Paris found that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on the city’s buses or trains, with half first targeted before age 18. Harassment—from insults, whistling and unsolicited comments on appearance to sexual assault or rape—has left six in ten women afraid to use public transport (versus three in ten men) and forced many to alter their routes, schedules or clothing. The High Council for Gender Equality has called for a campaign to curb sexist or threatening behavior, stressing that perpetrators often feel they act with impunity and that victims must be made aware such abuse is neither normal nor unpunishable (up to five years’ jail and a €75,005 fine).

Leeds‑based insurer Direct Line has launched the #everydayfix competition, asking designers (via a Makerversity “design makeathon”) to create prototypes that solve common “everyday emergencies” identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top ten emergencies included sleeplessness (46%), losing keys (37%), traffic delays (35%), lost documents (33%), no parking (32%), printer failure (31%), phone battery drain (31%), running out of toilet roll (30%), machine‑operated customer service (26%) and forgetting your bank card (25%).

Three prototypes were shortlisted:
• Snooze (by Instruments): an alarm clock that links to your phone and silences notifications to ensure uninterrupted sleep.  
• Forget Me Lock (by Onn Studio): a key‑attached swivel indicator that turns red when the door is locked and green when it’s open, viewable remotely.  
• Nipper (by Impulse): described as the world’s smallest mobile charger, it clips onto any household battery to give your phone a power boost.

The public can vote for their favourite prototype via Twitter retweets using #everydayfix; whichever tweet has the most retweets by 46 April will progress to a Kickstarter campaign and into production. Organizers praised the “smart and simple solutions” generated. Other concepts that didn’t make the final three included a bone‑conduction cycling helmet, a parking‑space alert pin and Relay, an app that forwards messages when your phone dies.

Northumbria’s police and crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under Ministry of Justice investigation for awarding over £500,000 of public victims‑services funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she co‑directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics—including Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz—denounce it as a clear conflict of interest and “soap opera” within the force, arguing PCCs should not fund bodies they run. Baird insists all MoJ procedures were followed; the MoJ will decide if funding must cease. Sim, who rose to prominence after the 2010 Raoul Moat manhunt and faced past bullying allegations (also investigated by Baird), will retire in June. The charity was set up after contacts to its predecessor, Victim Support, fell sharply, though some worry victims may be deterred by Sim’s involvement.

In late March 2014 in Mayfair, Philadelphia, 21‑year‑old Corry “Corey” Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng (19) and friend Carl Halin (18) abducted 53‑year‑old Greg Valecce—whom Campbell suspected of injuring his cat and stealing from him—and held him in a basement for about 42 hours. They beat him, tied him to a chair, filmed the abuse and forcibly tattooed “RIP Pebbles,” swastikas, racial slurs and other offensive images on his body. Valecce sustained multiple broken ribs, wrists and facial bones and escaped April 1 to summon police, who found tattoo gear, drugs and his stolen debit card. All three pleaded guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy and false imprisonment; Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years, Ng to 23 months. Two other defendants—David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt—await sentencing or trial. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but remains left with lasting physical and psychological trauma.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21‑year‑old PSV Eindhoven and Holland winger Memphis Depay, with new manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings. PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands confirmed United—and reportedly Paris Saint‑Germain and another big European club—are ready to pay a fee well above the £15 million Tottenham offered last summer.

Depay has enjoyed a breakout season at PSV’s Philips Stadion, scoring 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games as he helped them clinch their first league title in seven years. A product of VV Moordrecht, Sparta Rotterdam and PSV’s academy, he debuted for the PSV first team in September 2011, signed professionally in June 2012, and has since made over 100 appearances.

Known for his pace, dribbling and powerful right foot—completing more dribbles than anyone in the 2013/14 Eredivisie—Depay prefers playing on the left and cutting inside. While still refining his decision‑making, he’s been likened to Arjen Robben and even compared favorably to a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Internationally he debuted in 2013, starred under Van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup—scoring against Australia and Chile—and was nominated for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea’s under‑18s beat Manchester City’s youngsters 3-1 at the Academy Stadium to take a commanding lead into the second leg. Tammy Abraham’s first‑half brace gave Chelsea the initiative before Dominic Solanke added a late third; Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts had briefly levelled for City. 

Key performers for Chelsea included:
• Tammy Abraham – two fierce volleys, taken off injured after 67 minutes.  
• Dominic Solanke – strong link‑up play and a neat third goal.  
• Fikayo Tomori & Jake Clarke‑Salter – a commanding centre‑back partnership.  
• Ola Aina & Jay DaSilva – incisive contributions down the flanks.  
• Charlie Colkett – captained the midfield and won the central battle.

City’s young side showed promise but lacked a killer final ball:
• Tosin Adarabioyo – led the back four with maturity and movement.  
• Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts – poacher’s finish for City’s goal.  
• Brandon Barker – creative surges but forced the issue at times.  
• Kjetil Haug – shaky under high balls and powerless to prevent Chelsea’s strikes.

Florida Senator and presidential candidate Marco Rubio said he believes sexual orientation is “something that people are born with,” but that the definition of marriage as between one man and one woman should be left to state legislatures, not the courts, and is not a constitutional right. He affirmed he would personally attend a same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer—even if he disagreed with the decision—and compared it to his stance as a Catholic who opposes divorce yet would continue to love divorced friends or relatives. Rubio, who announced his presidential bid last week, has already secured over $47 million in donor commitments ahead of a competitive Republican primary.

Pablo Mandado (27) from Spain and Ilze Zebolde (31) from Latvia quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle the world with no fixed itinerary. In 356 days they’ve ridden almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries—starting in London and heading southeast through France (west and south coasts), Spain, Portugal, northern Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey’s northern coast, Georgia and Armenia.

They keep costs under €3 per person per day (about €0.10 per km) by camping 161 nights, using Couchsurfing (66) and Warmshowers (44), and spending just €2.74 daily on food (staples, wild fruits, occasional invitations or dumpster finds). After symbolically crossing from Greece into Turkey, they plan to continue into Asia, cross the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas—an open‑ended odyssey “for the following years.”

Mike Brown, England and Harlequins full‑back, has withdrawn from Harlequins’ Aviva Premiership match and remains unsure when he’ll return after suffering a concussion. Having been knocked out against Italy in the Six Nations and experiencing post‑France‑game headaches, he’ll follow a staged, cautious recovery—starting with light bike sessions—rather than risk a longer lay‑off like Johnny Sexton (12 weeks) or Northampton’s George North (ruled out for the season after four concussions). Brown credits World Rugby’s online concussion‑awareness modules with helping him recognise symptoms early, emphasises honesty about head injuries, and spoke about these issues at Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” grassroots rugby campaign.

Since the rise of the internet and smartphones, average monthly sexual frequency among British heterosexual couples has fallen from five times in 1990 and four times in 2000 to three times today, according to Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book Sex by Numbers. Spiegelhalter argues—citing emails and constant connectivity—that technological integration blurs home‑work boundaries, fills formerly idle moments and squeezes out partner time. While more people living alone may play a role, he and researcher Catherine Mercer contend that competing demands and late‑evening work emails leave couples too distracted or busy to prioritize sex.

Once prized as expensive status symbols, Tibetan mastiffs in China—large, loyal herding dogs weighing up to 80 kg—could fetch up to £1.2 million at the peak of a breed boom that began in 2005. A recent government anti‑corruption drive halted the practice of gifting them to officials, while bans in major cities on dogs over 50 kg and rapid urbanization exposed their unsuitability for city life. Overbreeding for profit produced a surplus of poor‑quality animals that now cannot be sold. As demand has collapsed, many mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat or leather; rescues have found dozens crammed, starving and injured en route. Theft by gangs and the off‑loading of “imperfect” dogs mean hundreds more may suffer the same fate.

Leeds‑based insurer Direct Line ran the #everydayfix competition to turn solutions for common “everyday emergencies” into real products via Kickstarter. A survey of 2,000 people ranked their top ten daily stresses (not being able to sleep 46 %, losing keys 37 %, traffic delays 35 %, etc.). London’s Makerversity design teams produced prototypes addressing the top issues. The three shortlisted entries are:

• Snooze (by Instruments): an alarm clock that syncs with your phone to mute notifications for better sleep  
• Forget Me Lock (by ONN Studio): a key‑mounted indicator that swivels green when the door is open and red when locked, viewable remotely  
• Nipper (by Impulse): a pocket‑sized phone charger that clips onto any household battery  

From now until April 40, Twitter users vote for their favorite by retweeting its #everydayfix post; the most popular will be crowdfunded and developed. Direct Line and Makerversity praised the smart, simple designs. Other concepts that fell just short included a bone‑conduction “Hat Nav” cycling helmet, a parking‑space alert pin, and a message‑relay app for dead phone batteries.
